And critically and what's missing in--in all of this also, is parents being good digital role models themselves, putting that phone down at dinner, not texting while driving, giving your kids eye to eye, you know, contact when they come for it. So parents are absolutely a critical part of this, they are the least well served, however, in terms of information and support.

TILLIS: But I do, just on a final note, I don't know if any of y'all, or a final question, and if you have the statistics, there was a news report about a month ago for some of--it may--it may have been Google or YouTube, but you know, they have operations set up where they have people, it's a horrible job, I can't imagine ever doing it, where they're reviewing all this content. Do we have any idea about how much of the maligned content is being interdicted by the current processes versus what's getting through? I think that's another thing that we need to do, to say to what extent do we scale what they're already doing to cast a wider net? Those are the sorts of things we have to talk about if we're going to come up with good, sustainable policy that lets us benefit from all the great things the internet has given us but also address the public safety risks that you're all here today. And I appreciate it.

But that sort of information, if you have any, that can give me an idea of--I know we're--we're doing poorly, but what efforts out there, if we simply scale them, could reduce a lot of the problems so that we can narrowly focus legislative outcomes and regulatory outcomes--

STONE: --Senator--

TILLIS:

--to get your feedback.

STONE: Senator, I may not be able to give you exact numbers on what we're missing, but I will tell you this, our attorney general's office in South Carolina prosecutes about 250 of these offenders every year, but what is more disturbing through the ICAC or the internet crimes against children, what is more disturbing, I think, to me, looking at those gross numbers, is while those indictments are being brought their investigators are working through about 85 new cases every year and in those 85 new cases they are seeing over a million, it's right at 1,860,000 files of child pornography that they are having to go through. So the--the massive--the numbers that we're talking about are massive.

GRAHAM: Senator Blumenthal.

BLUMENTHAL: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

A couple of brief questions. We haven't really talked about data mining and the threat to children's security from the extraordinary exponentially exploding means of gathering information about children, COPPA was never designed for toys connected to the internet, toys with cameras, toys that often have their own security vulnerabilities. I'm part of a working group that is examining proposals to assure protections for privacy and one of our models is the California Consumer Privacy Act that requires businesses to get opt-in consent to sell information of children under the age of 16. I believe that the rest of country ought to follow California's example and impose the strictest protections possible. Does everyone on this panel agree that the standard for consent and strict privacy protections under federal rules should be expanded to cover children and minors under 16?

UNKNOWN: Yes, sir.

UNKNOWN: Yes.

BLUMENTHAL: Mr. McKenna?

MCKENNA: Yes.

BLUMENTHAL: Mr. Clark? I'm glad that everyone agrees.

Ms.--Professor Campbell, you suggest that all child directed content should be placed on a separate platform where targeted advertising, commercial data collection, links to other sites or content, comments, and autoplay are prohibited. And I agree that that kind of separate platform would help protect children. Would legislation be required for it if it were imposed rather than done voluntarily?

CAMPBELL: I think it's possible that that's something that the Federal Trade Commission could negotiate with YouTube as part of--if they are investigating them as and trying to settle the case as part of the settlement, but otherwise, I think it couldn't require that under existing law.

BLUMENTHAL: Would that approach have applications beyond YouTube, in other words, who?

CAMPBELL: Well, that's the problem with consent decrees, they're only binding on the parties to the consent decrees.

BLUMENTHAL: Exactly. So it would probably require legislation.

CAMPBELL: Yes.

BLUMENTHAL: It would require the FTC to impose that kind of separate platform on a variety of other sites.

CAMPBELL: Yes.

BLUMENTHAL: And let me ask, finally, if--if each of you were to design, or let me ask you, Professor Campbell, initially, heightened safeguards for children and minors to protect against this kind of data mining, what additional steps would you take?

CAMPBELL: Well, one of the important things is to limit the data collection to only data that's absolutely necessary and the other is to not allow companies to retain the data beyond the time that's reasonably necessary to use it. And--and we're seeing this happening a lot, for example, with the Amazon Echo Dot speaker for kids, it's specific for kids, but they're saving the voice recordings of children and the translations of those voice recordings, in many cases, indefinitely and there's no way to even delete all of them even when the parent tries so--except to take their child out of the service and a lot of times you want your child to be able to use these services. So I think that--that we really need to focus on data minimization and--and also data security because the data that's available to companies can easily be available through data brokers and other sources, to predators and--and lots of other people.

BLUMENTHAL: And data minimization is another requirement of the California law and the (INAUDIBLE)--

CAMPBELL: --And of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act.

BLUMENTHAL: Exactly. Any other suggestions from other members of the panel on this topic? My thanks, again. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

GRAHAM: Senator Cruz.

CRUZ: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you to each of the witnesses for being here and testifying on this--this very important topic.

Mr. McKenna, an article last month in The New York Times detailed how YouTube's recommendation algorithm can lead users from adult pornography to videos of girls as young as 5 or 6-years-old wearing bathing suits. Do you know--know if YouTube has changed their algorithms regarding child exploitation, and if not, what can and should YouTube do to stop this?

MCKENNA: Senator Cruz, thank you on that very important topic.

I am not aware that YouTube has changed their algorithm. I'm guessing if they would have done that, that that would have been newsworthy and--and parents everywhere would have been celebrating that, but I have not been aware of that news. I--I believe that YouTube, in their vast knowledge, has the ability to, in the same way, that they can recommend videos, they can choose not to recommend videos, and that would simply be a change that they would have to choose to make.

CRUZ: Wired reported that sexual predators use the comments section of YouTube videos to help other predators find videos, for example, they would announce times and videos that would be of particular interest to sexual predators. YouTube, thankfully, disabled commenting on--on many of the videos of children under 13. Has this prevented sexual predators from using YouTube to spread this information or is--or is it simply moving the problem elsewhere?

MCKENNA: Well, I--I believe it's a step in the right direction. I'm--I'm happy that they've made this change. I believe that that should mitigate some of the activity, but based on our experience, these individuals are extremely creative. And the comments section, irrespective of platform, whether it's YouTube, or Instagram, and other platforms that allow comments, are all breeding grounds for this sort of networking of pedophiles. So if it's not going to be on YouTube, it'll simply move to another platform and we've been witness to that.

CRUZ: As you know, a little over a year ago we passed, and the President signed into law, the--the Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act, which amended section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, to strip immunity from online platforms that knowingly assist, facilitate, or support sex trafficking. How successful has SESTA been in--in combating sex trafficking and--and--and what else does Congress need to do? And that's open to anyone who--

CLARK: Senator, good question.

I think SESTA largely has helped takedown, I think of BackPage.com, for example, certain ads that were attractive to networks, as Mr. McKenna said, it shared a likeness for trying to recruit and find, entice young women, kids, into sex for sale. But I would also say that it seems like when--when one disappears, another one appears. That's a global issue as we've been saying, across the--the country, in the United States, plus the world now, we're seeing still an increase on those number of chat sites, video sites, opportunities for exploitation to continue in the digital world.

CRUZ: Last year, a--a Texas woman sued Facebook for providing human traffickers with a way to "stalk, exploit, recruit, groom, and extort children into the sex trade". In--in y'all's judgment, are Facebook and the other social media sites doing enough to combat exploitation of their platforms by--by sex traffickers?

UNKNOWN: Not all at once.

(LAUGHTER)

CLARK: Senator, once again, I'd--I'd say there's room for improvement here. I think a--what we've seen with the cooperation of the tech companies, on the plus side, being--are participating in things that we're doing like cyber tip roundtables, bringing the tech companies together so that we can have a collaborative approach. If there's ever been a cause for, what I call a true public/private partnership, this is it. But of all the tech companies that handle reporting to NCMEC, about 1,500 of them, I'm--would be, I--I think, suffice to say that many of them still can do more.

MCKENNA: Senator Cruz, thank you. What--what I was trying to formulate in my--in my head to say was that not--not enough is--is being done. And in our experience, it doesn't feel as though until there's a huge news report, or there's some pressure, there's always this reactive response to these sort of issues from these large companies. They are brilliant organizations. I am confident that they have in their know-how the ability to, within weeks, take care of many of the problems that we have spoken about here at this hearing but it's not until they're pushed, or there's pressure, or there's reputational damage, or something that they seem to move, and even then, in the case of YouTube, they're still unwilling to do some very simple things that we think would protect children. And so that's my greatest concern, is that there's this continual resistance and reactive approach to the problems that to us feel so obvious.

CRUZ: Well, and I--and I would certainly be interested, I know the committee would, in--in any of the witnesses recommendations for additional steps that--that need to be taken, because this--this has to be continually addressed and vigorously address. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

GRAHAM: Miss Campbell, you wanted to say something?

CAMPBELL: I just wanted to give an example, again, using YouTube, I have to wonder why are so many under 13-year-olds are on YouTube when the terms of service prohibit them from using YouTube? And so I think, again, if--if children were using a different site, or separate site, that you wouldn't have as much problem with predators. And I think that--that it is true that it's a global problem because you'll see the same kids, the same little kids, like you know, in--in a--a outdoor pool in their bathing suit promoting toys, they're being paid by-products to promote these toys, and they're on all of the different platforms as well. And so it is a problem that I think needs to be looked at across platforms.

GRAHAM: Senator Blumenthal:

BLUMENTHAL: I want to thank Senator Cruz for mentioning SESTA and also section 230, which in some ways is the elephant in the room, right. The immunity, which is so broad and uniquely encompassing by many of the tech companies is part of the reason that they are failing to do more. Because you mentioned, Mr. McKenna, the potential duty of care, standard of care, which is enforceable only if there is some accountability and right now, the biggest obstacle to accountability is section 230. So I appreciate Senator Cruz mentioning SESTA. Senator Portman and I were the co-sponsors SESTA. It was strongly supported by NCMEC. We thank you, again, for your help on it. I think it's an example of the bipartisan action that I hope will emerge from this very excellent hearing. And I thank you, Mr. Chairman,

GRAHAM: Thank you.

Just along those lines, to sum up, things would change tomorrow if you could get sued. So the problem with getting sued about providing content, if you're responsible for everything that flows through your business organization in terms of content you'd probably drive at least new people out of business and maybe put the old people in jeopardy of--of folding. But what I'd like to do is make sure that you're earning this liability of protection, that under Section 230, you know, you're a neutral platform for you to have that liability of protection when it comes to exploiting children, that you're earning it, that we come up with best business practices, and if you meet those best business practices you have a safe haven from liability, if you don't, you're going to get sued.

So it seems to me that we need to come up with a set of best business practices to protect children, whether it's the device itself or whatever. You know, if you have a default, we think that's the best thing for the country. That if you have a--set up a system where if you're a minor the default thing kicks in, then you're good to go. So what I want to do is look at what are the best business practices when it comes to protecting children from exploitation on the internet? And if you meet those best business practices you're okay, if you don't, you're going to get sued. It seems to me that will do more good than anything else.

The solutions come from the people in the private sector, as long as they're legitimate, and people like you will tell us if these are legitimate. So rather than the government telling you what to do, you need to find out what does work and we'll certify at the government level whether or not it's genuine and if you pass that sort of government audit, then you're good to go, if you don't, then you're exposed to lawsuits from moms and dads and everybody else. So that's where I'd like to take this discussion because 230 is the elephant in the room. And what I'd like to do is leverage that elephant in the room, that you can have these liability of protections because we want to save the industry and preserve it for competition, but you have to earn it.

And what have I learned from this hearing? You've got a lot of--liability of protections, but you're not doing a whole lot to earn it. Thank you very much for your testimony.

Senate Judiciary Committee Holds Hearing On Digital Antitrust

March 10, 2020 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UTAH), CHAIRMAN

SEN. CHARLES E. GRASSLEY (R-IOWA)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

SEN. MICHAEL D. CRAPO (R-IDAHO)

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TENN.)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-S.C.), EX-OFFICIO

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR (D-MINN.), RANKING MEMBER

SEN. PATRICK J. LEAHY (D-VT.)

SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL (D-CONN.)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-N.J.)

SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN (D-CALIF.), EX-OFFICIO

[*]LEE: Welcome to this hearing on the Subcommittee on Antitrust Competition Policy and Consumer Rights. Today's hearing continues our series, looking at competitive issues in digital technology markets. In September, we looked at acquisitions of nascent competitors by digital platforms. Today, we're going to explore self-preferencing by these platforms in the same industry. That is, what are the potential antitrust issues when platforms favor their own products or their own services over those offered by third parties.

As I said in our hearing in September, I'm encouraged that the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice are investigating whether the tech giants have violated the antitrust laws. If those efforts identify bad conduct that has harmed consumer, then the agencies should--and predictably will--seek to enjoin such infringing behavior.

However, I'm also concerned that we might overshoot the mark in our efforts to reign in these firms. In particular, I'm concerned that antitrust policy could lose focus, forgetting that its purpose is to protect competition and not competitors. And, so, it's always important for us to remain focused on the text of individual statutes and the purpose--and the underlying, overriding purpose of our antitrust laws, which is to protect competition.

Clearly, we should not allow dominant firms to engage in conduct that harms competition. We also cannot fall prey to the mentality that treats big as categorically bad. Far too many politicians and TV pundits fail to understand that our antitrust laws do, in fact, tolerate big firms. E--even in some circumstances, monopolies, if they acquire their large market shares through business acumen or by offering consumers a superior product.

What matters for antitrust law is not the size of the firm, but whether its engaged in anticompetitive conduct. There is a difference and it is a difference that very much matters. With that in mind, we shouldn't mistake harm to competitors as being necessarily indicative of harm c--to competition itself.

This may be the view of the Eur--European Union and, in many respects, it is, but it's not how we enforce antitrust law in this country. Our laws in this country are different. They focus on protecting competition itself, rather than competitors. Appropriate antitrust analysis under U.S. law will distinguish harm to competitors from harm to competition. It does so by focusing on whether the contact involved has benefited consumers or, alternatively, imposed harm on them.

Unfortunately, neither consumers nor taxpayers are well-served when our antitrust agencies are focused more on protecting their own turf than they are on protecting competition. So, before we gin--begin, I want to say a few words, yet again, about ongoing clearance battles between the Federal Trade Commission on the one hand and the Department of Justice's Antitrust Division on the other hand.

I've recon--recently spoken both to FTC Chairman Simons and to Assistant Attorney General Delrahim about this issue. In particular, I have expressed to both my profound frustration that these agencies are conducting monopolization investigations of the very same tech companies, at the very same time. Frankly, it's unacceptable that the FTC and the DOJ are duplicating each other's investigations when they both can see that they're strapped for resources as it is, even when they're not tripping over each other.

Now, I recognize that I must sound like something of a broken record on this issue, but that's not going to stop. The fact is that, given our bizarre institutional setup, these issues continue to come up again and again. And that's not simply going to go away. If anything, I--I--I'm amazed that this hasn't become a bigger, more prominent issue before now than it has at this point.

Absent of change in the--in the law, this is a clash that surely is going to continue into the future. You just can't set up two competing federal agencies covering, basically, the same subject matter without conflict, without uncertainty, without turf battles that are themselves going to cause significant harm, including, among other things, harm to competition itself and harm to those people whose interests are supposed to be protected by their enforcement of the laws they've been charged with administering.

At the very least, the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission should be doing everything they possibly can to minimize the friction that's inherent within our dual system of antitrust enforcement agencies. If they cannot or will not, then Congress must. But, as I've indicated before, this is inevitable. It's not going to work. It's not a question of if, but rather when we change the law and bring our--our country into the 21st century--bring our country at least into conformity with rules of logic and reason that say that you can't have the same subject matter covered by two separate competing federal agencies.

Senator Klobuchar will now deliver her opening statement.

KLOBUCHAR: Very good. Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and it's good to see everyone here. We have been getting complaints about self-preferencing (INAUDIBLE) platforms for years, so I'm glad that you're having this hearing today.

As you know--you and I have discussed this before--I'm a little less obsessed with this overlapping jurisdiction. What I want is action when it comes to some of this conduct. And I think that while it would be nice if everything was nicely divided, but my biggest concern is what's been going on across our country when it comes to consolidation and anticompetitive behavior. Having spent just a little bit of time traveling across the country--

(LAUGHTER)

--In the last year, I've gotten to--as has Senator Booker--I've been able to talk to a lot of people about their hopes and dreams, and about their concerns. And a lot of them have focused on that things are too big. They may not know the nuances of antitrust law or digital competition, but they feel that their costs have been going up, their wages are stagnated, and mostly, a number of them see this startup slump that's real, which is only going to be, of course, potentially hurt even more by the epidemic that we're dealing with with the coronavirus.

But we have seen a 30 percent reduction in new startups in this country. Americans know intuitively that competition is key to the health of our markets, the future of our economy, and their own prosperity. And they know that our country has a monopoly problem, which is what I think we should be focusing on.

We're living in a time when digital platforms have become intimately intertwined with the daily lives of millions of Americans. Many of us carry these platforms with us wherever we go. I was missing one phone today--only had one--and it was like Armageddon had occurred, so--

(LAUGHTER)

--I have it. For example, Google's inter--t--net search platform provides access to its mapping services--Google Map --online video website--YouTube--and reviews for local businesses. Apple's App Store allows users to access third-party apps, as well as Apple's own apps, such as Apple Music and Apple Arcade. Those are just a few examples.

Self-preferencing occurs when the platform operator leverages its market power to advantage its own products and services over those of third-party competitors that also use the platform. There are numerous ways that a platform can do this. It can elevate its own products on a search result page. I remember you, Senator Lee, many, many years ago, showing what your concerns about that--with regard to one of the platforms.

It can build the platform's product into the platform itself so that customers will be less likely to look for, much less find, competing products. It can impose significant costs for third-party competitors to access customers through the platform, harming their ability to compete on the basis of price. It can use the platform's privilege access to customer and competitor data to have an advantage over rivals. And it can degrade access to competing products through the platform so that customers have a more difficult time accessing the products of third-party competitors.

Depending on the circumstances, these types of practices can have a devastating effect on competition. Some point to the example of adding a flashlight app into a smartphone operating system, a type of self-preferencing that may not be good for the business of flashlight app developers, but the end result might be a better experience for consumers. S--now, as far as what we do about it. (LAUGHTER)

--With Senators Blumenthal and Booker. I'm pleased that they--we have worked together on this bill. The legislation would reinvigorate enforcement against anticompetitive conduct and enable enforcers to protect competition across our entire economy. The bill prohibits exclusionary conduct--which is what we're talking about here--that presents a "appreciable risk of harming competition."

For firms that are engaging in exclusionary conduct in markets in which they have market power, the bill shifts the burden to those dominant firms to prove that their exclusionary conduct does not risk harming competition. In addition, the bill imposes substantial civil penalties for violations while allowing for injunctive relief, and it sets aside the most problematic aspects of recent Supreme Court antitrust caselaw.

My name is Thomas Hazlett. I teach economics at Clemson University. Economists have long wondered about the degree to which firms specialize. A producer of automobiles may decide to produce engines but buy the steel inputs from other companies. Tesla, for example, produces both electric vehicles and the batteries that power them, attempting to exploit complementarities that it hopes will allow it to dominate the car market one day, and maybe much more.

This form of coordination across product markets is extremely common--some might call it ubiquitous--but, of course, it is not without controversy. Economists consider a range of possibilities, including that vertical integration may foreclose rivalry, lessening competition. The general empirical conclusion, however, is that scope-and-scale economies prove efficient, promoting consumer welfare even as there are exceptions to the rule. This set of observations motivates U.S. antitrust law.

Horizontal price coordination is anticompetitive, per say, while vertical coordination is governed under a rule of reason. In the recent case of U.S. versus AT&T, the government sought to block a vertical merger--AT&T distributing video programming--purchasing Time Warner, which produces it--and look for evidence to sep--separate an efficiency motivation from an anticompetitive goal in the event the evidence was not found, and the federal court rejected the Department of Justice argument, allowing the merger to proceed.

This is not a unique outcome. Digital platforms from iTunes and music to Google and search, Netflix and movies and video to Facebook and social media, Microsoft and computer platforms, Amazon and ecommerce, AOL and antitru--and--and int--internet access require risky investments that ultimately depend on the creation of a complex ecosystem for success, and vertical integration commonly assists. I'd like to point out just three quick historical examples of how this works.

First--and--and I'll take the three A's--Amazon, Apple, and AOL. Amazon developed as an online bookseller, but integrated into countless other product lines, leveraging its ability with its initial platform. Competing with eBay and other online competitors, it has created wide and deep efficiencies. While accused of excluding independent vendors, it has consistently expanded its appeal to third-party sellers who now dominate the platform, which was the reverse of when Amazon started--almost completely Amazon-provided product. This accounts for Amazon's great market success.

In this, it is always attempting to vertically integrate and to complete with a nonintegrated or less integrated rival, eBay. The business model competition between them improves consumer welfare. Users got happy and artists got paid, yet the vertical links between iTunes and Apple's iPod, exclusively configured to create a curated ecosystem, drew the ire of EU antitrust authorities. The authorities were wrong to see iTunes/iPod as suspect. It was a great leap forward.

AOL pioneered the mass market in internet service in the 1990s, attracting 20 million users to online services, providing not only access but a walled garden of proprietary content. The investments in original programming complimented the easy-to-use approach to ISP subscriptions. As the rise of alternative models developed, including for AOL itself, with unrestricted access to the open internet, this evolved into something quite different. In short, entrepreneurial firms disrupting markets often supply multiple levers of the innovation stack. We've got a tremendous amount of that work, being done in Tennessee, with healthcare, healthcare informatics, financial service delivery systems. So, if you just touch on that. I only have a minute-fifty left.

KIMMELMAN: Sure, thank you, Senator. I'll also say that I think this is a problem with Facebook, as well. With their enormous reach. They have their own ad system. Extremely valuable for advertisers and publishers to be there, and Facebook can control, exactly, all the data and how it's used and how information is presented. So, it's worthy of consideration, too.

In the Google environment, I think the big problem is, it's like a stock exchange, where we're having real-time bidding and trading, we usually don't think we want the people who are running that process, to also have a major stake, in the broker business, and the selling, and the buying portion, as well.

Now Google happens to have that here, and the danger is that if there aren't enough players, and if they actually have too much market power, everyone becomes more dependent, on using their products, on the ad side, and on the publishing side, and their data analytics, because you have to use them when you use their products. And then, they control your information, about whether you're getting efficient pricing and--and fairness. So, I think we need to review all of--

BLACKBURN: Which is one of our concerns is, you know, the self-preferencing, and there is so much that we have said about this. You know, it drives me absolutely crazy, when I get in my car, at a certain time of day, and Google maps tells me how far it is to my house, and how long it's going to take me, to get there. So, my time has expired. Thank you all, very much. Thank you, Mr. Chairman, I yield back.

LEE: Thank you, Senator Blackburn. Mr. Lowe let's go back to you. And in some cases, you might end up with search results that are degraded, in terms of their value, to the searcher or in other cases, might be deceptive. So, help--help walk me through what Yelp considers deceptive or a degradation of the quality, of a search result.

LOWE: Thank you, for the question, Mr. Chairman. It's not as Senator Hawley just said, I think the devils in the details. Is this idea that the introduction of these Answer Boxes, also known as Win Boxes, did have anticompetitive effects, which--which were acknowledged.

But on balance, they found that it led to consumer benefit. And I think, you need to engage in this, sort of, vertical-specific balancing. So, I talked to economists about this topic, a lot. I think, the, you know, one way you could imagine it is sort of a spectrum of, you know, on one side is sort of a mutable fact-based information, commodity, utility-like, it's almost an analogous to the flashlight example, in the app store, that was discussed earlier.

On the other side is sort of, the most subjective information you can imagine. And, in the case of local search, the core information that is surfaced, is this amalgam of user-generated content. And so, I think that you know, asking the question, does it make sense to bypass the entire World Wide Web of candidates, for potential relevant results, in serving up an answer, and having a totally exclusionary box, with no other third-party services allowed, to even participate, in this merit-based process, you know, I think these are fair questions, to raise.

LEE: What--tell me what Yelp does, in response to, Internet search query, that's different than how Google does it.

LOWE: So, Yelp is a vertical search engine. And that's distinct from general search, in that there is a geographic coefficient. So, if I search for dentistry on Google, Google has the challenge of returning relevant content, for the person looking for dental school, or the history of dentistry or maybe their--maybe they've got a toothache, and they are looking for a dentist. If I do a search for, dentist in Provo, on Yelp, that's a very specific type of search. And, we know that that person is looking for a local business. Yelp--

LEE: You will get a ton of results; I don't know why, but we have a ton of dentists in Provo.

LOWE: Yelp, not unlike Google, serves--surfaces ads, and that's not what--I don't think that's what we're discussing today. I think people should have the right to run advertisements. But unlike Google, we--and like Google, we also, surface organic results. But unlike Google, we do not surface this distinct, third category of information, which is an Answer Box, where we're steering people to, you know, the dentist that is on Yelp's payroll or--

LEE: That's what differentiates your results, from theirs, separate from your structure, your vertical search structure.

LOWE: Right.

LEE: Yours are differentiated, in that, you have sponsored ad search results and then you have non-sponsored ones, but not the third category, of this Answer Box.

LOWE: That is correct, sir.

LEE: By the way, what--what percentage of Yelp's overall traffic, including what you get from your modal app--your mobile app, does--does Google account for?

LOWE: If you include the mobile app, I think that gets a bit bigger(ph), because there are many times, people, Google is one of the key ways, if not the keyway, that people discover services, third-party services, like Yelp and TripAdvisor and others, and then ultimately, download the app. So, to bring that in, somewhat muddies, the calculation. I don't know the exact number, in the last month or so, but I think we're still about 80 percent of web traffic, is a--that comes to Yelp, comes through Google.

And sometimes, it's navigational search. People who have already decided that they want to go to Yelp and they're almost using Google, as a--they're typing in the search, you know, dentist Provo, and the word Yelp. And, sometimes, they've never heard of Yelp before, and they're just discovering Yelp, through Google. But increasingly, that is becoming more difficult, because most people are doing these searches, on smartphones.

The majority of smartphones search these days, is local search, and the majority of those local search results, served up on smartphones, are being siphoned into this, walled garden, so to speak, this sort of Google ecosystem.

LEE: By the way, that percentage that you referred to, and I understand why that's an elusive number to identify. Has that number increased? Has it waxed or waned, over the last few years?

LOWE: It's been relatively stable, but the number, sort of, to keep your eye on, in terms of understanding the impact of this conduct, in the market, is how many, number one, how many total search result pages have been generated, since the last time we had this hearing, or 2004, when Google was a pure turnstile. And, what percentage of clicks, are going into Google secondary products, versus going to the web.

And, within the last six months or so, according to a very high-quality, third-party data, there's been a tipping point, that today, so, if you imagine, about 15 years ago, virtually 100 percent of traffic going to Google, was diffused out into the web. And, that was--unlocked all this innovation and investment.

Today, the majority of traffic going to Google, either stays on Google or either terminates on Google or goes to Google secondary pages. So, you think about the slope of growth, of Google's own products, relative to the slope of growth, of the web itself. That's where you're seeing that type of foreclosure effect.

LEE: Interesting. Thank you. Professor Hazlett, other search engines like Bing, and DuckDuck Go, tend to provide, if I understand them correctly, targeted answers to consumers searches for local information. HAZLETT: Thank you, Senator. That is the relevant consideration. And, I'm--I'm glad you mentioned the rival search engines because you want to compare, not a perfect or idealized world, or some kind of hypothetical, you want to see, actually, what's happening, in a dynamic sense, with competition, amongst real-world alternatives. And, it has been mentioned that Google comes out of, a search market in the 1990s, with stock to be solved.

There was not a new opportunity, that was apparent, but it created a much cleaner project and much better answers. And, I guess that was called the turnstile approach, is that what it was? That just passing it along, to the best, the best answer, but you know, search was being gained obviously, by websites, and you know, pornography sites, and all kinds of stuff, people, in general, didn't want, figured out that these algorithms would, you know, could be manipulated. And--and, Google solved that problem. And, has made enormous capital, out of the fact, that it has created, this credibility.

Now, that's what's, you know, that that is--is the question, now, is that continued? And, to find out, you want to compare, and to see how this evolution, has continued. I mean, in--in 2002, AOL actually offered and was paid, by the upstart, Google, to get the default search engine slot, on the AOL software. Because it was such a great application and--and, Google, was the upstart, paid for that. And, that was self-prefacing, by AOL, but by contract they--they sold and made money on that. They were the number one ISP, in the world. Internet service provider.

And so, that was a market power issue, and it didn't work, so well, for AOL, which went out with competition. But it certainly worked well, coming up, to get more customers, for Google. And, it is constantly competing, then, with Inc. to Me (SP), now with--with Bing, and other upstarts and--and--and they--they can gain, by self-preferencing, but of course, they could also lose by that, as well. And--and, you know, in a competitive context. We have to see if--if there is any--any room to think, that this is not the best, that consumers can do.

LEE: Mr. Lowe, what is your response to that?

LOWE: So, thank you, Mr. Chairman, for--for raising--being in DuckDuck Go, in nondominant general search engines, do not have the luxury of degrading the quality of their services when it comes to local search. So, if I do a search for hotels, Salt Lake City, on Bing today, as much as I, you know, don't like it, TripAdvisor powers that--that Answer Box experience, and when I click on the information there, I'm sent out to TripAdvisor.com.

Now, if you tweak the search, and do a search for restaurants, Salt Lake City, on Bing, you get Yelp content. And, you are sent off to Yelp. DuckDuck Go does the same thing. So, you know, the--the--it is very technically trivial, for a general search engine, to provide a nondiscriminatory and interoperable local search experience, but, you know, I find it telling that the non-dominant general search engines, don't engage in this activity, because I think that they have to fear that users will switch, and use alternative services. Whereas, Google is so dominant, that it doesn't have to experience, that same fear, of switching.

LEE: Mr. Reed, let's turn to you for a minute. There are members of Congress and sometimes some tech companies, who will, from time to time, raise concerns that platforms are enabling app developers--app developers, to take advantage of consumers, by collecting their data, and they'll go after them, in that direction. But then, turn around and criticize, those very same platforms, when their efforts to solve that problem, might end up harming competitors. How do your members think about this issue, and think about how policymakers, should go about finding the right balance?

REED: Well, I think you're talking about, basically, the dichotomy between how do we meet the consumer where they are, to provide them with what they're want--what they want, but also meet their privacy expectations? That is, kind of the golden goose, that everybody's looking at, right now.

I think one of the most interesting things for this hearing, is that you are, in fact, seeing major platforms that I--I deal with, the app ecosystem, really competing on privacy, as a consumer value add. That to me, is surprisingly refreshing, that companies are spending, millions of dollars, to say, here's the way that we protect it. The interesting way that flows down to us, in the developer world, is it changes our terms of service.

It changes the expectations of our behavior. Do you remember the very beginning, I said there are 3--3 factors, that we need, from a platform? We need--we need them to create a trusted place. We need them to offload our overhead and we need them to create a global market. Well, that first one, trust, is absolutely critical. So, what we're seeing in the antitrust space, right now, is we're seeing that there is real competition, to establish trust, with the end-user, so that, they will buy my app, or use my app.

I think the difference here, is that, for Ms. Hubbard and Mr. Kimmelman, there is the idea that we need additional government agencies, to move forward, or housing our net tribunal, but at the end of the day, what I think, Ms. Hubbard commented on, which was critical, was this, I think you used the word will; the will to actually, move forward, on these cases.

And so, Senator Lee, if there are examples where privacy is being abused, in an anti-competitive manner, then that's exactly where the FTC, with its current jurisdiction, can move forward. Especially, as Mr. Lowe pointed out if it's deceptive.

I guess the difference here is, what's the tool, to solve the problem? Is it, additional government agencies, or is it, will and resources, to the existing agencies? Right now, we tip our thumb on the scale of, existing agencies, with additional resources and will, more than new government forces.

LEE: Thank you. Ms. Hubbard let's--let's turn to you next, if I understand it correctly, to deal with many of these problems, that you've described today, with the--the issues involved, in self-preferencing, by tech platforms. You support proposals that have been introduced, by some of my Democratic colleagues, to break up, some of these large companies. I do worry that regardless, of what one might think about what that could achieve, it could also create some problems.

For example, let's say if Amazon, were to be forced to stop selling its Amazon basic--Amazon basics, line of products, or at least stop selling those products, on its own platform. And, it could sell them only on another platform, separate from this one. Isn't that likely to increase the cost of both the Amazon basics line of products and the remaining products, that are sold on the Amazon platform? And, if so, doesn't that harm consumers?

HUBBARD: Thank you, for the question, Senator. So, the proposals are more to divest that rule. So, it wouldn't be Amazon, still selling Amazon basic, on another platform. It would be other companies acquiring that--that functionality. So, Amazon is no longer, in the business, of selling products. It's only in the business of running a marketplace, that removes structurally, the conflicts of interest.

LEE: I--I--I get that, but doesn't, by offering its own products and those of its rivals, and its competitors, on the same platform, in close proximity, doesn't Amazon, by doing that, provide consumers with--with a benefit, by permitting and ensuring, price competition? Price competition, that would be, in many ways, diminished, if that weren't to occur.

HUBBARD: Unfortunately, the examples that I've looked at, where Amazon has kicked out other competitors, other retailer competitors, and favored its own products, we haven't always seen lower prices. In fact, there was a study that I did, looking at water filters, where it removed all other sellers of water filters, and the price actually went up. So, I don't think we should take, as a foregone conclusion, that it is prefacing its own products, is actually leading to lower prices.

But I also think we need to look at--at the issues that were talking about today. The other roles that consumers play as citizen--as entrepreneurs, that want to have a fair opportunity, to compete, by offering the best product and service. And, having that best product and service, have a shot at fair competition. And, consumers benefit, when fair competition delivers the best choice and innovation, and prices.

So, I think, you know, competition on an equal, level playing field, will be the best for consumers. Both in their role, as consumers, and as in their role, in fact, consumers are human, so, they also are, entrepreneurs, and they are also employees of companies, that are currently being, very much squeezed, by Amazon, with its extraction in anticompetitive practices.

LEE: Okay, I wanna drill down on this answer, you provided, a moment ago. So, the studies you referred to, of instances where the owner of a platform withdrew its own or did not withdrawal its own products, and prices went up, aren't you referring to instances in which, they excluded competitors, and then their prices went up?

HUBBARD: Right. So, Amazon does a few different things, for preferencing its own product. So, it has its own lines of products, like the Amazon basics, and all the brands, that it has. And it prefers those, on the platform, by giving them premium pricement--placement, in search results, premium advertising, they have access to data that their competitors don't have, and they have a superior ability, to target Amazon users, with advertising, about their products.

There also is a practice of self-preferencing, involving Amazon selling, as a first-party seller. That's when Amazon, is the retailer of a product, that it buys from someone else, at wholesale. And so, in the water filter example, what had happened was, there was a bunch of sellers, selling water filters, Amazon kicked off all those third-party sellers, from selling water filters, and became, itself, the exclusive seller of water-- of the branded water filter, that belonged to a different brand. And the prices, actually, went up, drastically.

LEE: When that happens, given that the distance between, say Amazon and something else, is just going to another website. If prices do go up. Doesn't that drive competitors--customers to a different website, where they'd find lower prices?

HUBBARD: You know, I would really love to see some data about switching, between alternatives. I think for a lot of Amazon Prime members, there's not a lot of comparison-shopping. They're kind of in a habit of just, you know, using Amazon as their everything store. So, I have not had access to data.

I'm hoping that's something that DOJ and FTC, are looking at, is switching data, between Amazon's platform and other competitors. I know from the marketplace seller side, from, you know, the vantage--the businesses that are being disadvantaged, those third-party sellers, I've spoken to them and they've told me, that selling on another platform, is not an option for them, to be viable business. They can't--they have no choice, but to sell on Amazon. If they tried to sell on eBay or Walmart, it's not going to be enough of a sales volume, for their businesses to exist. That's on the other side of the market, from the seller side.

LEE: Right.

HUBBARD: There's not switching, on that side. I haven't seen the data on not switching.

LEE: Walmart is too small of a market for them?

(LAUGHTER)

HUBBARD: Yeah. Online. For on-- e-commerce.

LEE: So, The mom-and-pop operations?

HUBBARD: For e-commerce.

LEE: Yeah.

HUBBARD: I'm talking about.

LEE: How does this differ, meaningfully, from let's say, Costco? You go to Costco, you can find a number of branded products, in some circumstances, you'll find Costco's own private label branded product, Kirkland. How does the set of scenarios, you are describing, differ meaningfully, from Costco's own pricing and physical placement of its Kirkland branded products, relative to those of--of others?

HUBBARD: The difference is that Costco is not nearly as dominant, as Amazon is. And so, you know, for Sherman Act Section 2, you need to have both monopoly power and exclusionary conduct. And, which can do--when you don't have monopoly power--you can't do legally when you do have monopoly power.

So, because Costco is not as dominant, any brand that makes a product, has alternatives, to selling on Costco. They can choose not to sell on Costco. That's not the case with Amazon. Nearly every major brand has no choice, but to sell on Amazon, and therefore they can't protect themselves, against that self-preferencing, conduct. They can't choose alternatives.

LEE: But you mentioned, a few minutes ago, that one of the reasons for that, I think, the lead reason you mentioned is, because of habit. That it is a pattern, of consumer habit. Is that something that can translate, into anticompetitive conduct, under our antitrust laws?

HUBBARD: That's just to go to, whether there was switching or not. You were asking about switching, and switching is what we use, for analyzing whether there's monopoly power. We use the hypothetical monopolist test. We say if there's a small, but significant non-transitory increase in price, do a significant number of consumers, switch to alternatives?

If they don't, for whatever reason that may be; whether it's habit, or you know, whatever the reason is if they don't, and the other, you know, then the companies are not, the alternatives are not included, in the relevant product market, for determining monopoly power. The alternatives, if they're not switching to them, are not included in the relevant product market, for determining whether monopoly power exists. That's why switching, where switching, comes into play, in antitrust analysis.

LEE: Sure. In the case of an online retailer that offers a broad array of services, that makes it somewhat unique. Does that present an interesting challenge, for figuring out, what the relevant market is?

HUBBARD: Yeah, I mean, I think there's lots of different relevant product markets. We are talking about Amazon. There's Amazon as a whole, you could go-- drill down into a particular product category, you can be looking at, like a product line, like consumer products.

So, I think, you know, unfortunately, when I stopped being an antitrust enforcer, I lost the subpoena power, I don't have that--insights to, really do that robust analysis, that's needed, to identify that switching data. But I think there's probably a lot of different markets, at play here, not just one.

LEE: Professor Hazlett what's your response, to Ms. Hubbard's answer to my questions, about the Amazon basics line of question?

HAZLETT: (OFF MIC)Well, well first of all, yeah, thank you, very much--

LEE: Yeah, push the button, thank you.

HAZLETT: Thank you, very much, Senator. The--the trend with--with--with the argument, that Amazon is mistreating third-party vendors, and using their data, and undermining them or throwing them off the platform. The fact is, that the platform started in the mid-to-late 90s, as an Amazon sales platform. And, if you go to 1997, the year of the IPO, I think it was 97 percent of all products, were Amazon products, that were sold by retailers' sales volume.

Now, it's down, the latest data I've seen, it's down to 42 percent. And, it's a third-party platform. That's what emerging. It is extremely profitable, for Amazon to make the platform lucrative for the third-party vendors. That's what it is.

That's what this enormous value creation has been about. Where we've seen Amazon become, rotating, for the prize of, most valuable company in the world. At the same time, they have completed their entire corporate existence, against a non-vertically integrated platform, in this sense, which is eBay.

And, eBay was much larger, of course, at the start. You go back to the mid-2000s. I think it was about three times, the market capitalization, of Amazon. And, eBay, specifically takes the other approach in its business model, which has some salience here and is advocated as a rule, but you don't need the rule, to see what happens, in the marketplace. You have the opportunity, for a non-integrated platform owner, to make the platform, excellent, for the third-party vendors.

And that--that works very well, too. Now, Amazon has come, come on, you know, with a lot of momentum here and actually outcompeted, in the sense of volume. So, that they have more third-party sales now, but it's not as though, eBay does not exist. It's not as if other sites, have not launched, and exist, to compete. And, in fact, the great story about one product that was thought to be suppressed, Diapers.com, on Amazon, there's a story about this.

In fact, it--it--it was bought by Amazon, prices did not go up, this interestingly enough, and in fact, the people who had this entrepreneurial venture, competing on the platform of Amazon, made a very large capital gain, from that, but they left Amazon and started their own venture, Jet.com, sold that for $3 billion, that was acquired by Walmart. And, now, the head of Walmart, previously at Amazon, is competing, running the e-commerce division.

That is an intense rivalry, where both sides, are competing to create platforms, for all kinds of branded, integrated, self-preferential, and independent products. And, that is what consumers should want. We benefit from that. We find new efficiencies. And, that's the way these competing business models, are returning social value.

LEE: In the mid-1990s, my wife and I had twins, during my first-year law school. At the time e-commerce, hadn't really become a thing, but we knew exactly which store had better prices, on diapers, which store had better prices, on formula, and so forth. And, I wish some of these services have been around then. If nothing else, it made price comparison easier.

Mr. Kimmelman let's go back to you for a second. You proposed a nondiscrimination framework, as a way to address, some of the problems, that you see, with self-preferencing by these platforms. I'm not sure how some of this would work in practice, though. For example, how would that work for a firm like Apple? What--what would iOS look like, if Apple couldn't bundle various apps and other components, into the iPhone?

So, would a consumer, end up with a phone, with no apps installed, just hardware and something that when taken out of the box, would open up to a blank screen, when it turned on, and then the customer would have a litany of choices, to be made, regarding what operating system it should run, what apps to install, and, so forth?

So, I mean, virtually any--any platform component, can be modularized, and open to competition, by third parties. It--it and so, if that's true, then where would you draw the line and why? Where would you draw it? And why would you draw, choose to draw the line, where you do?

KIMMELMAN: Senator, the first line that needs to be drawn is, who would be subject to some kind of a nondiscrimination standard. And, what I've been proposing is, we look at companies or elements of the market, where we have no entry, or we have bottlenecked power, we have gatekeeper control. So, not to--not to--to divert from your hypothetical, but I'm not sure Apple, totally fits in that framework.

But, let's assume that it does, I'm not suggesting that they have to separate everything out. There are various ways that we could have an expert agency look at, what is fair treatment of yourself versus third-party players, on your platform. In cable, it was prices, terms, and conditions. We've done similar things in telecommunications.

So here, I think, it's not about prohibiting bundling or prohibiting the offering of vertical services, except maybe in the most extreme cases, I would be much more cautious, then Sally was. But it's enabling the opportunity for others to be, for example, in the app store, offering similar choices, for consumers.

LEE: Let me tell you, what worries me about that if we are to imagine a very benevolent and efficient federal agency, something that I get to see, that exists, not that the government doesn't serve the role, it does. But when I look at different industries, I see the most dynamic, successful, areas of our economy. Areas where there's been more competition, rather than less, over the last couple of decades, and where jobs, most of our net job growth, has occurred.

It tends to be in industries, that are, what I describe as, being born into freedom, as opposed to, being born into captivity. We have the benevolent regulator model, for many decades, in place with common carriers, for example. Airlines. This kept prices quite high. So, what worries me about that model, is that when someone has to go to a regulator and do a 'mother may I', every time they want to make a change.

You don't and you can't have, the type of dynamic market environment, that you've had, with the development of the Internet, of a smartphone, where people can respond, in real-time, to changing market circumstances, without being told in advance, as if, through a sort of, technical analog to prior restraint, what they may or may not do, what may or may not be, considered fair. So, that worries me a little bit. Professor Hazlett, do you have any response, to Mr. Kimmelman's analysis, there?

HAZLETT: Well, I--I mean there's--there's obviously some reasons to think that you want, and the arguments been given here, to want more ability, to attack anti-competitive activities. But, there's a cost to that. There is a tremendous opportunity for dynamic competition to evolve, as it's evolved. I think that's what you're referring to, in some of these open markets. And so, we're impressed by that. And, when we see how common carrier control of AT&T for 40 years, really had a very stultifying effect on competitive entry, even though it was designed, and in some poetic retrospectives, is actually given credit today, for keeping the market open.

It was--it was doing exactly the opposite. And in fact, the antitrust action against AT&T, was as much an action, if not more, as some economists have stated, against the regulatory structure. Which was keeping out, what was supposed to be able to come in, by design, by open access, through common carriage. And so, obviously, that regulatory system is very suspect. We've done better to--to move past that. There's not a lot of debate about that. People of various stripes, certainly, agree with that.

But I remember the introduction of the iPhone. And it was attacked, for its vertical control, platform owners, want the platform to be successful, and they want to assert some control over that, generally speaking. And, Apple came in, with this integrated product. And, Professor Tim Wu (SP) at Columbia, is very well versed, on this. I've assigned one of his many books, to students, there's a student of mine here, who was forced to read that book.

But he--he called it, what he said, "the iPhone, is iPhony", because of the vertical structure and its exclusive agreement, originally with AT&T, to provide service, in the United States. That has become a tremendously productive platform. Whether you're talking about the app space or the consumer acceptance. And, in fact, the competition it promulgated. It eliminated Blackberry and Nokia, which were the pre-existing platforms, that were great, in their own time, and in their own way.

But it--it--it--it really was disruptive to them. And, they had a lot of complaints, but it moved on and created the opportunity for the Android, Google Play, which was the competing space, that rose up in direct competition, in its own, sort of controlled space, which is now, being criticized as well, because it's not just as open, as Google claimed it was.

There were some linkages and some self-preferencing when you use the Android operating system. Yes, the default is, Google search. And, Google benefits from that, even though they licensed the software for free, in an amazing stretch, really became the biggest software platform in the world, particularly in the mobile space, by this open mechanism, of not charging for the license.

It--it--that kind of creative disruption, really is, what you want, in these high-tech markets. And, to say that you have to go through a process, that's going to tax innovation, by running it through a "mother may I' is--is very costly. So that has to be the offset, that people are very concerned with.

KIMMELMAN: Mr. Chairman, I'm not suggesting a 'mother may I', and I'm asking for something much more limited. I agree with a lot of what Professor Hazlett says, but the main point here is, that a lot of what we're talking about, antitrust has not been effective, at getting at. And so, while there is a cost to regulations, and I'd be very careful and targeted about it, there's also a bigger cost, of doing nothing.

LEE: Mr. Reed?

REED: I just have a brief note. I think it's important that we don't mix our history. The interesting part about the release of the iPhone is, that when it first came out, you couldn't have third-party applications on it. Steve Jobs intended it to be only web apps. And, it was supposed to be a pristine environment, filled with only Apple--Apple applications. And, everything else had to be web apps.

It wasn't until Apple, kind of took a page from Microsoft, and put developers on the forefront and did those three things, of creating an environment that actually gave us space, to utilize the features that were on the device, that you saw this explosive growth. He mentioned Blackberry. Blackberry tried to have an app store, but they didn't--they didn't put the developer first. They didn't create this, equality space, that we can put our apps in.

And that's what gave birth to it. It wasn't the iPhone itself, that took some time. It was the birth of the app store, and the ability of third parties, to participate, on that. That really change the landscape and opened the door, as you said, to other platforms, to compete. So, it's really the involvement of small businesses and--and the ability of platforms, to nurture that, and make that possible, that helped Apple, become one of the biggest companies out there.

LEE: That's a good point. I hadn't thought of that, in a while. Plus, Blackberrys got annoying after a while.

(LAUGHTER)

I don't know what they did, but one day they--their new phone, just became impossible to use. And, their, but their app platform, was very unwieldy, and you couldn't access it. The iPhone platform, by contrast, I--I've gone back and forth, for years, using different mapping apps and different search engine apps, depending on who's gets better.

So, sometimes at the--Apple map app, is better. Sometimes it's Google or Waze. Anyway, I know you didn't come here to hear me opine, on my favorite map apps. This has been really helpful. I really appreciate each--the expertise, each one of you, has brought to this, as we are going to wrap up the hearing.

Before I do so, I just want to thank a member of my staff, Sean Pugh, who's been with me for a couple of years. He's done an extraordinary job. We're going to be losing him on Friday. I--I--I've threatened to wear black, in mourning all week, this week, to cover all mirrors, in the office, as a result of it.

We're losing him to the private sector, but he's been absolutely phenomenal. I'm grateful to him, for all he's done for me, for my staff, for the development of antitrust law, and in putting together this, and so many other hearings. The record is going to remain open until Tuesday, March 24, and we stand adjourned. Thank you.
