Senate Judiciary Committee Holds Hearing On Encryption And Lawful Data Access

December 10, 2019 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-S.C.), CHAIRMAN

SEN. CHARLES E. GRASSLEY (R-IOWA)

SEN. JOHN CORNYN (R-TEXAS)

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UTAH)

SEN. TED CRUZ (R-TEXAS)

SEN. BEN SASSE (R-NEB.)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

SEN. THOM TILLIS (R-N.C.)

SEN. JONI ERNST (R-IOWA)

SEN. MICHAEL D. CRAPO (R-IDAHO)

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R-LA.)

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TENN.)

SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN (D-CALIF.), RANKING MEMBER

SEN. PATRICK J. LEAHY (D-VT.)

SEN. RICHARD J. DURBIN (D-ILL.)

SEN. SHELDON WHITEHOUSE (D-R.I.)

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR (D-MINN.)

SEN. CHRIS COONS (D-DEL.)

SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL (D-CONN.)

SEN. MAZIE K. HIRONO (D-HAWAII)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-N.J.)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS (D-CALIF.)

[*]GRAHAM: The purpose of the hearing today is to talk about the problems associated with encryption of social media devices, phones, and how to strike a balance. So the point, for me, is I appreciate the fact that people cannot hack into my phone, listen to my phone calls, follow the messages, the texts I received and how I use the phone. I think all of us want devices that protect our privacy.

Having said that, no American should want a device that becomes a safe haven for criminality. The only people--we're not the only people who use these devices. Criminals use these devices. Terrorists use these devices. You've got encrypted apps out there that child molesters use. You've got encrypted apps like WhatsApp and Messenger that terrorists use. So here's the deal for me. I want the average American to be protected as much as possible, but when law enforcement believes that a crime has been committed or is in the process of being committed and they get a court order, I want the government to be able to look and find out all relevant information.

There is no place safer, more sacred in American politics and legal systems than one's home. You know, the king of your--queen of your castle. Having said that, if the government gets a search warrant to go into your home, they can. If you lock the door, they can break it down. So in American law there is no place that's immune from inquiry if criminality is involved. You have to go through a legal process to get into one's home, the warrant process. And I'm not about to create a safe haven for criminals where they can plan their misdeeds and have information stored in a fashion that law enforcement can never be allowed to access it. That is a bridge too far for me. How we do this, I don't know. I hope the tech community working with law enforcement can find a way to do it. If you all don't, we will. Senator Feinstein.

FEINSTEIN: Thanks, Mr. Chairman. I'd like to put my formal remarks in the record, and I just want to say a few things from the heart. I want to take everybody back to December 2, 2015. The place is San Bernardino, California. What happened was a mass murder. 22 people--excuse me--14 were killed, and 22 more were injured, but a cell phone was found at the scene of the crime. As part of the investigation, the FBI was unable to unlock it. And despite a lawful court order, the phone's manufacturer refused to assist the FBI in unlocking the phone.

I was called and asked to help, and I learned the detail of this. And I learned the cost of what it took to eventually unlock that phone. Gentlemen, remember, 14 people lost their lives, were killed, and 22 more were injured. I am determined to see that there is a way that phones can be unlocked when major crimes are committed. It is a vital piece of evidence, whether that's liked by you or not, at the scene of a crime.

This time, on the state I rep--at the state I represent a lot of people killed and a lot of people injured, and what was there? A cell phone. I know what it costs to unlock it. I've been asked not to say it. I'll respect that. But it should not have happened, and I've learned, my colleagues, even when a United States senator calls and asks for help for law enforcement, that help is denied. So we need to take action.

GRAHAM: Well, I could not have said it better. I didn't say it better. I associate myself with everything Senator Feinstein just said in terms of my view of the problem and what we need to do to fix it. The panel today is Cyrus Vance, Jr., district attorney for New York County; Matt Tait, independent cyber security expert and consultant, Austin, Texas; Erik Neuenschwander--that's pretty good--director of user privacy, Apple; Jay Sullivan, project--product management director for privacy integrity, Facebook. Mr. Vance.

VANCE: Good morning, Chairman Graham, Ranking Member Feinstein and members of the Senate Judiciary Committee. On behalf of my office and law enforcement around the country, particularly local law enforcement, I thank the committee for its attention and for its invitation to me to address the issues of local, state and national public safety around encryption.

The single most important law enforcement challenge in the last 10 years, in my personal opinion, is the expanded use of mobile devices by bad actors to plan, to execute and to communicate about crimes. Just as we ordinary citizens rely on digital communication, so do people involved in terrorism, cyber fraud, murder, rape, robbery and child sexual assault. Until the fall of 2014, Apple and Google routinely provided law enforcement access to their mobile phones when they received a court ordered search warrant, just as you suggested, Senator Feinstein, but that changed when they rolled out their first mobile operating systems that, by design, often make the contents of smart phones completely inaccessible. And in doing so, Apple and Google, in my opinion, effectively upended centuries of American jurisprudence, as you suggest, Chairman Graham, holding that nobody's property is beyond the reach of a court ordered search warrant.

So how has this affected law enforcement and crime victims? Let me answer these questions with two brief examples from my office. The first involves child sexual abuse. A babysitter at a local church in Manhattan was identified as having shared images of child sexual assault online. Pursuant to a warrant that was issued by a judge, his encrypted mobile devices and other devices were seized. Over time we opened the devices using technology from a paid consultant, which we'll discuss in a bit. We then discovered that the suspect was not only sharing images of child sexual assault, but himself videotaping his own child sexual assault activities and recording that abuse as well. Based on this evidence, which we finally accessed, we convicted him of predatory sexual assault.

In a second example we weren't so lucky. My office was investigating a case of sex trafficking and obtained an encrypted phone from a suspect who at the time was incarcerated on a different case. In a recorded telephone call from prison that suspect, speaking to an accomplice outside prison, told the accomplice that he hoped his phone had the newest encrypted operating system from Apple, and this inmate said to his friend, and I'm quoting, Apple and Google came out with these softwares that can no longer be unencrypted by the police. If our phones are running on iOS 8 software, they can't open my phone. That may be a gift from God.

In fact, we were never able to view the contents of that phone, and as a result, our investigation of sex trafficking was blocked by encryption. And to be clear, we are in some able--in some cases able to gain entry to these phones by using hacking tools we've paid private companies to obtain. I want to be clear about this, though. Such third-party workarounds are cost prohibitive for all but a handful of local law enforcement agencies. They are simply out of reach for many of the smaller and rural communities that you represent. And in addition, these workarounds in many cases do not succeed due to security mechanisms put in place by Apple and Google.

I think it's also important to note that in a number of cases our ability to open and access phones has led to exonerations of people wrongly suspected or arrested for crimes. So our ability to access devices enables us to protect our twofold obligations, to hold the guilty responsible and to protect the innocent from injustice.

Finally, I anticipate that Apple today will tell you that it is impossible for them to open their devices without creating a hole for crypto criminals themselves to gain access. I have two brief responses to this. First, in 2016 at House hearings in which I participated, Apple's then general counsel acknowledged in written testimony that the company's process for unlocking phones in response to warrants prior to the introduction of iOS 8 in 2014 had never led to a security breach of that process. Second, this new tech--this new criminal justice problem is, in my view, a direct result of these private companies' decisions to reengineer their projects. Now I'm not a technologist, but I'm confident that the problem can be solved by a company redesign, as well.

[*]VANCE: As President John F. Kennedy once said our problems are man-made; therefore, they can be solved by man. The right balance between privacy and public safety can be achieved I believe by one requiring a court-ordered search warrant and two, limiting the information sought to data at risk, what Senator Feinstein was talking about the photos in the messages and the data that is on the phone. I am not talking about surveillance of discussions or other communications while they are in progress because I believe this is a middle ground on encryption and the position most likely to result in fruitful compromise and a position endorsed by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. But this middle ground will only be achieved through federal legislative action which is why I am here today. In our view allowing private companies in Silicon Valley to continue to insert themselves as the unregulated gatekeepers of critical evidence is dangerous, it is bad public sub policy and in our view warrants legislative intervention. Thank you.

TAIT: Chairman Graham, Ranking Member Feinstein, members of the committee thank you for inviting me to this important hearing today. For as long as this country has existed society has always struggled to maintain a balance between individuals rights to privacy versus the rights of victims of crime to obtain justice through law enforcement's ability to collect evidence and prosecute the crimes committed against them. Time and again the inevitable progress of technology shifts this balance in one direction or another and we are here again today because technology has once again shifted this balance. Encryption makes us undoubtedly safer online from hackers and foreign government surveillance. Without it the internet would not be the thriving hub of commerce that it is today. Encryption has made it possible to communicate securely with one another, to build business is online and enables us to access global communities and shared interests that were previously very hard to access.

The internet and the technology market today is as it is precisely because encryption enables us to operate securely online. As with all technologies encryption comes with the inevitable collaterals in this case to law enforcement. It is right that we ask hard questions about what we can do to mitigate these collaterals without undermining the huge benefits to society that encryption gives us all. We should not be coy here. Encryption does affect law enforcement in practically all domains from counterterrorism, financial crimes countering child abuse as well as ordinary device searches for local law enforcement and given the sheer scale and complexity of these domains it is hardly surprising that the conversation around encryption need some work itself to decipher.

As I understand it encryption meaningfully hinders law enforcement in three key areas that need to be taken separately device searches, wiretaps and so-called cyber tips whereby distribution of child abuse material can be detected and investigated. Perhaps surprisingly the way encryption relates to these domains is not similar to one another and the approaches for technology companies, law enforcement and regulators to address these collaterals have surprisingly little overlap.

The first of these three domains says ordinary device searches which is impacted by device encryption. Device encryption in tangles the user's files with the passcode of the user in order to prevent unauthorized extraction of those files. This has the collateral effect of presenting law enforcement from searching devices that have been physically seized during an arrest or property search. If the owner cannot enter their passcode perhaps because they are dead at the scene of a crime either as a victim or as a perpetrator the device provides no alternative mechanism to access the content of that device.

The second of these domains is traditional wiretaps between two individuals known to law enforcement to be planning or committing a major crime. This is impacted by end to end communications encryption which hides all content but not necessarily all meta-data of the conversation taking place so that even the communications provider cannot see it. The third domain is what law enforcement calls cyber tips in the context of detecting when child abuse imagery is shared over a communications platform.

At the moment many technology companies voluntarily scan shared images against a huge database of known child abuse material and alert law enforcement if a match is discovered. Although this domain is very different to traditional wiretaps it is also affected by end to end communications encryption because without access to the content being transmitted technology companies are more limited in their ability to scan that content for abuse material.

Each of these three domains impacts law enforcement in very different ways and the ability of technology companies, law enforcement and regulators to counteract these are surprisingly different. For example the use of zero day vulnerabilities has in effect becomes the excepted default mechanism for law enforcement and intelligence agencies to conduct wiretaps on end to end encrypted platforms. A few months ago for example a recent hacking campaign attributed to China made the use of iPhone zero day vulnerabilities to access some amongst other things the contents of WhatsApp and I message encrypted communications from targeted devices. These vulnerabilities are not cheap but at least for now wiretaps via hacking remain an attractive practical and proportionate method for federal law enforcement to conduct wiretaps without the need for proactive regulation or to help from technology vendors.

Cyber tips have a harder challenge to bridge. Here the use of zero day vulnerabilities to break into devices would clearly not be safe or proportionate but other approaches do exist that do not require the alteration or removal of end to end encryption. For example technology vendors can scan abuse images as they are sent and received on the device itself rather than as it traverses the communications platform. In short, options do exist for conducting wiretaps and retaining cyber tips without the need for substantiatively alter during or regulating into end encryption.

These options are not easy to be sure but they do exist. Uniquely amongst the problem domains only device encryption which thwarts device searches would be amenable to what law enforcement calls a front door access mechanism. This is because device searches uniquely can be predicated on the knowledge if not the consent of the owner and the technology to do so can be built around law enforcement's physical access to the device which doesn't exist in the case of wiretaps. Because these factors are not available in the context of other searches there will always be dangers to extrapolate options for one of these domains to other domains.

In summary encryption remains an important tool for enabling the internet to operate as the hub of commerce and communication that is increasingly the center of all of our lives. There are externalities to law enforcement investigations but many of these externalities can be mitigated entirely or substantially without reference to the encryption itself.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I appreciate the opportunity to be here today and I look forward to answering the committee's questions.

NEUENSCHWANDER: Good morning, Chairman Graham, Ranking Member Feinstein and members of the committee. Thank you for inviting me to speak with you today about how encryption works and the important role it plays keeping electronic data and records secure.

My name is Erik Neuenschwander and I have been a software engineer at Apple for 12 years. I worked as the first data analysis engineer on the first iPhone, manage the software performance team for the first iPad and founded Apple's privacy engineering team. Today I manage the team responsible for the technical aspects of designing Apple's privacy features. I am proud to work at a company that builds great products that improve people's lives.

Today iPhone is used for much more than phone calls. Around the world people use them every day to store and send sensitive and important data, personal financial information, or health data, communications with our colleagues and even information about the location of our family members. And as the internet is making the world even more interconnected people use their iPhones to remotely control things like home security systems, vehicles and appliances. Your iPhone needs to be protected from hackers and criminals and that is what strong encryption helps to do.

Encryption is the underlying technology providing information security in all modern systems. We do not know of a way to deploy encryption that provides access only for the good guys without making it easier for the bad guys to break in. Encryption not only protects a person sensitive data it is also one of the most important mechanisms we have as a nation to safeguard an increasingly interconnected future. Every day over 1 trillion transactions from financial transactions to the exchange of healthcare records occurs safely over the internet because of encrypted communications. Utilizing 5G networks connected devices will play an even larger role in the operation and maintenance of our critical infrastructure running our electric grids, transportation networks and healthcare and financial systems.

Encryption is needed to protect from malicious actors whose and tax are growing exponentially in scope, frequency and sophistication. And encryption will become even more important as more devices are added to the internet and attack surfaces expand. Encryption is woven through our software, hardware and services for maximum security. We also challenge ourselves to collect as little customer data as possible including through the use of tools that process data only on a person's device rather than on Apple servers. If we don't have your information then nefarious insiders or malicious actors who gain access to apples networks won't either. And our use of secure enclave a hardware-based key manager that is isolated from the main processor provides an extra layer of security overall our approach to design improve security reducing points of vulnerability and risk.

We understand that rapidly evolving technologies by their very nature can create challenges for investigators. At Apple we share law enforcement's goal of creating a safer world and we work closely with law enforcement every day. We have a staff of professionals including former law enforcement personnel on call 24 hours a day seven days a week to assist law enforcement with lawful request.

This work is significant. Over the past seven years the company has responded to over 127,000 request from U.S. law enforcement agencies for information that we have been told is critical to helping prevent or solve crimes. In addition our teams have fielded and supported thousands of emergency request from U.S. law enforcement typically taking action within 20 minutes of receipt. And the number of U.S. government request has increased over 100 percent indicating that the information we are providing is valuable to investigations.

Given the pace of innovation and the growth of data in recent years we understand that one of the biggest challenges facing law enforcement is a lack of clear information about what data are available, where they are stored and how they can be obtained. That is why we publish a comprehensive law enforcement guide that provides this information and our team has trained law enforcement officers in the United States and around the world to these processes. We will continue to increase our training offerings in the future including by deploying online training to reach smaller law enforcement departments.

We think it is critical that American companies lead in the area of secure encrypted messaging. If the United States rolls back its support for privacy and encryption foreign application providers will fill the vacuum. Technology eve(ph) falls and the tools we use to keep people safe can and must as well but our resolve remains unchanged.

Facebook invest immense resources on safety and there is a lot that we can and will do to keep people safe while providing secure private communications. First, working to prevent harm. We're also working to better understand how bad actors connect with their victims so we can prevent that initial contact and give people more control over who can contact them online.

Second, we'll continue to use all unencrypted information available to us, including group names, profile pictures, and other information from the--the--the Facebook app and the Instagram feed detect abuse. We're also using what we learn from those apps, which remain unencrypted, and we can stop a lot of bad behavior in our messaging apps from those public spaces.

Third, we're working on encouraging and making it easier for people to report messages that concern them. When they do so, they do share that unencrypted information back to Facebook so that we can act on them as we always have done.

Facebook has in his immense respect for the work that law enforcement does to--to keep America safe. Our commitment to partner closely remains unchanged. We will continue to respond to all lawful requests with metadata, content that users to share with us through reports, and the unencrypted content from the Facebook family of apps, including the spaces of Instagram and Facebook.

Law enforcement's ability to retrieve direct messages stored on a device continues. Some have called for the building of backdoors and otherwise secured systems. We oppose intentionally weakening the security of encrypted systems because doing so would undermine the privacy and security of people everywhere and leave them vulnerable to hackers, criminals, and repressive regimes. Instead, we're working to develop ways to use information that we can access to support law enforcement when it is lawful and appropriate.

Ensuring that encryption is implemented across our services is an--an effective and responsible manner will require continued dialogue. We're not flipping a switch tomorrow. In Messenger itself, one of the ways that we receive the--the unencrypted message content is when people report messages that violate our community's standards and we have been working very hard to increase that user-generated reporting. We are seeing some promising early results so I believe that we will be able to help prevent people from making these contacts in the first place, detect them and then have reporting and continued action thing proactively with law enforcement and with child safety groups going forward but it is going to take a lot of work.

That is what it sounds like because right now you are able to get into the content, but with encryption you are not going to be able to and since most of the reports that are made are based on content I don't know how you are not going to see a pretty significant decrease I would say in the number of reports that you are able to make. So are you pretty much committed to encrypting your Messenger service, or will you review the impact on reporting of the encryption and if it--if--if the reports drop by 50 percent or 75 percent or some other large number would you reconsider encrypting?

SULLIVAN: The current plan is you know we provide messaging systems for billions of people, and we want all of them to have the privacy, safety and security that we all enjoy when we send messages to each other so that--the plan is to cooperate over the next couple of years to keep working through this problem until we get to a point where we feel like we have new mechanisms that are going to help keep people safe. That is why we announced this so early and didn't just drop it on the world so that we could work through this issue with all of the relevant stakeholders and you know I just want to zoom out a little bit like the--the reason those reports are in those numbers and the one report is terrible obviously, the reason they are at that level is because of the commitment and the effort that we put into that. Now we are shifting that effort and saying, hey, what are the methods that we can use as the whole world has moved to encrypted messaging so that we can continue to be the leader in keeping people safe there?

HIRONO: I am out of time. I--I will submit some other questions for the record but obviously, the--the time that it is going to take for you to be able to identify these--make these terrible images and get rid of them it is going to--it seems very daunting considering the billions of messages that are being put out there. Thank you.

BLACKBURN: Senator Tillis, five minutes.

TILLIS: Thank you, Madam Chair. Mr. Neuenschwander--might I pronounce that right?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Yes, Senator.

TILLIS: Can you tell me a little bit about the steps that Apple has taken to be compliant with Australia's encryption laws?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Senator, I am not--from these software engineering standpoint where my focus is I am not aware of any steps that we have had to take under that law.

TILLIS: I mean it's a law that is basically focused on your platform, so I was just curious your--your--I don't know how you deal--or--well, let me put it a different way. Let's assume that that is model legislation we implemented here in the United States, would it be problematic and why?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Senator, so we--we oppose that legislation as it was being drafted and I do think it could be problematic.

TILLIS: For what reasons?

NEUENSCHWANDER: I think that it attempts to have language to avoid what they call a systemic vulnerability or requiring that to be put into a device, but that's a difficult and ill-defined concept in that legislation and my overall fear would be that if some of the capabilities of that legislation were imposed on any provider that that provider would have to weaken encryption just by the nature of the technology for all users and it (INAUDIBLE)--I wouldn't say necessarily it was focused on our platform. Encryption is wide-ranging across a large number of platforms and I don't see anything in that act which would leave any provider potentially out of weakening their systems and services.

TILLIS: Just a--just for the record I know that Mr. Cook has stated publicly that there has been no accommodation, in the foreign jurisdiction including China in terms of providing access to information for say Chinese consumers is that correct?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Correct, Senator. We have never built a back door for anyone.

TILLIS: And I think maybe for Mr. Tait or--or for the entire panel to what extent can we really rely on industry? I think Mr. Vance mentioned 2015 is when we took this up for the first time, and quite honestly this sounds a whole lot like that hearing in terms of working on things but what can we do to provide a solution to this that does not require a congressional or a legislative solution? What can you tell these members that you are working on as an industry, Mr. Tait as an observer to where we are going to see progress fairly quickly and not have another hearing in 2024 that sounds a lot like this one with child exploitation and a number of horrible things that we hear (INAUDIBLE) now continuing to occur?

TAIT: Well, I think for device encryption, that is a very difficult thing; that is, there really isn't incentives for technology companies to be proactive on this topic. There is--

TILLIS: Mr. Tait do you agree though if--if we don't get this right if every device looked like it was wide open or potentially gaining access to it or having a back door that it would undermine a lot of the valid commerce and uses of these devices?

TAIT: Sir, I don't think anyone is suggesting that we roll back to a state where these devices are unencrypted and where common criminals on the streets can gain access to these devices.

[*]TAIT: In the event that Congress required, of course, that--with a court order that these devices had to be accessed, you know, it's possible that Apple might say well we're going to have an unencrypted device, but then Google could say well we have a better solution; we're going to encrypt it with a key that we control, and then Apple would lose out in sort of the marketplace of ideas there that, you know, they wouldn't be able to sell that product as easily.

So I think that when we're looking at device encryption, there really isn't a good solution at the moment absent a regulatory solution. When it comes to end to end encryption, I think that regulated solutions are much less, much less useful. The app companies in question are very much smaller. They're very often overseas.

TILLIS: Well, that was going to be my next question. We can--we have to look at this as a global threat in jurisdictions that are not necessarily subject to U.S. law, which is why we've got to figure out how to fix this and have platforms here that are reliable and not just see this move offshore and the criminal enterprise continue.

TAIT: Sure. So when we look at device encryption, the three main companies that are providing device encryption are Microsoft, and Apple, and Google. All of them have operating incomes of like $35 billion or so, or in Apple's case much more. They're all big U.S. companies. If Congress chose to regulate them, they could. When we look at app end to end encryption apps, WhatsApp at the point where it was acquired by Facebook had 200 million users and 50 employees. When we look at Telegram, it has 300 million employees--or 300 million users. It has about 15 core members. It's based overseas. When we look at Wire is an end to end encrypted Messenger. It's got roughly 50 employees as of 2016. It's based in Switzerland. So the opportunities to regulate there I think are much harder.

TILLIS: Thank you.

BLACKBURN: Senator Hawley, five minutes.

HAWLEY: Thank you, Madam Chair. Mr. Sullivan, I've seen the news reports this morning about your boss' letter to the attorney general, which he says that Facebook is very committed to end to end encryption, is very committed to its users' privacy. I have to save a question or two about that, however. You said earlier in response to Senator Durbin that Facebook doesn't share data outside Facebook, but yet the FTC has reported, and indeed Facebook has been fined--not enough in my view, but fined--for doing precisely that. Let me just remind you the FTC has reported that Facebook in 2014 told developers on their platform that they could continue to collect personal data for a year. After that period elapsed, Facebook continued to provide developers with access to data for years to come. FTC says it took Facebook at least until June of last year to stop providing access to data to--this personal data--certain third-party apps. So maybe you could clarify.

SULLIVAN: I'd like to clarify. I'm sorry, what I thought the question was was do we sell messages from Messenger Kids is what I was trying to answer earlier. So I'm--I'm--I didn't mean to conflate that we don't have a developer program where third-party developers--and I understand the, you know, what you are referring to with the FTC. So I was referring to the Messenger Kids message content only.

HAWLEY: But just to be clear, Facebook has collected and shared personal data outside of Facebook, correct?

SULLIVAN: I wouldn't want to rehash the whole FTC thing you're talking about, but what I can tell you is that over the last several years, but especially recently, the way that we collect and manage metadata is really changing, and I appreciate--I just want to refer to a letter--

HAWLEY: Actually, that's all--I'd rather you not. And I would just note for the record that at this late stage, after all that we have been through with the FTC, after the fine, which I say again I think was not nearly enough that was levied, you still won't answer that question yes. It just amazes me. I mean, do they send you to school to evade our questioning? Why can't you just say yes, Facebook has collected data, you have shared it with third-party developers? You were fined for it and probably should have been fined more based on your answers today.

Let me ask a few other questions. Will you commit to me today that Facebook will not use any metadata from your supposedly encrypted messages for purposes of targeting advertisements or building profiles on users? Yes or no?

SULLIVAN: Senator, the question of metadata is what we're actively working on. I read your letter of--of May 14, I believe, and our response to that letter, and I think--

HAWLEY: Your response was equivocal. You wouldn't commit one way or the other, so I'm giving you a chance now.

SULLIVAN: It's still--yeah, it's still--it's still early, so when we announced that Messenger was going to be encrypted, the reason we did it around two years ahead of--

HAWLEY: So it's still early, meaning you haven't decided?

SULLIVAN: It means--so let me lay out what I think kind of the core, the core trade-offs and issue--

HAWLEY: No, that's okay. I don't want to hear the trade-offs. I just want to hear where you are. So have you--have you decided? It sounds like to me you're keeping open the possibility of collecting metadata and using it even on supposedly encrypted messages.

SULLIVAN: Metadata--part of what is the metadata is what's going to help us keep children and other people safe. So when we have encrypted communications, part of the metadata is what we will use to prevent bad actors from contacting children in the first place, from detecting, say someone's tried to contact multiple minors in a short period of time. We can immediately ban them from our platinum to keep children safe. So there is a balance we have to--

HAWLEY: Okay, I'm going to take that as a--sounds to me like that's leaning to yes. How about this? Will Facebook swear off any other future or present efforts to find workarounds to get information about the nature of users' encrypted communications for ad targeting purposes?

SULLIVAN: So Senator, take Messenger, which is what I focus on. We don't use the content of people's messages today to target ads, even though Messenger is unencrypted.

HAWLEY: And you won't try and--and figure out what links they're sending in order to target ads? You won't try to gather other information?

SULLIVAN: No, I mean, we won't even have--sorry to interrupt you.

HAWLEY: No, that's okay.

SULLIVAN: Once it's encrypted--so today we have the ability and we don't use it for targeting. In the future when it's encrypted we won't even be able to see people's content, which is part of the goal of encryption is people don't want Facebook looking at their messages either.

HAWLEY: And you won't attempt to--to, for instance, reverse engineer what links people are sharing over encrypted messages?

SULLIVAN: They'll be--we won't be able to. We won't be able to see the message content.

HAWLEY: Will you promise not to target ads based on information you can retrieve from shifting AI to the device from the cloud onto devices?

SULLIVAN: So within Messenger we won't be seeing the content in the cloud or in transit, as we call it. Nor will we be scanning the content on the device. So we won't--we won't be able to--we won't have access to it to run any algorithm on it because we believe that we're trying to create an end to end system of trust, not just on the server. So we don't plan to look at content on the client either. So--and that would include, you know, any uses.

HAWLEY: I see my time is expired. I'll submit as a question for the record the question for Professor Tait and maybe for all of you, which is that when it comes to building backdoors onto the devices as you've talked about, Professor Tait, as one possible solution, I think my big question is, how does one do that without making it easier for entities like Beijing, or Russia to gain access to that device? I think that's a big concern. Thank you, Madam Chair.

BLACKBURN: Senator Kennedy, five minutes.

KENNEDY: Thank you, Madam Chairman. Thank you, gentlemen, for being here. Mr. Sullivan, Facebook isn't scared of Congress, is it?

SULLIVAN: I guess what I would say is, you know, let me explain where we're at. We take our responsibility to the American people and--very seriously.

KENNEDY: I understand, but that was a simple question. Let me--let me preface it by saying we've been talking for three years about the fact that our large social media companies, most of which originated in America, about which I am very proud, we've been talking about the fact that our large social media companies are no longer companies; their countries. They've got more power than most countries. And we've been talking about ways to protect people's privacy and when there should be exceptions, and we've been threatening to do something. We haven't done anything. When it comes to social media and privacy, we couldn't pass gas. So Facebook isn't scared of Congress, is it?

SULLIVAN: Senator, first of all, let me give you a very direct answer to your question. We have the utmost respect for what we're trying to do here today to make our services more private, but I would be happy to tell you what we're doing in the area of privacy.

KENNEDY: You can tell me. We'll talk afterwards.

SULLIVAN: Okay.

KENNEDY: Apple's not scared of Congress, is it, sir?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Senator, I think that we're respectable of Congress, and it's part of why I'm pleased to be here to answer your questions.

KENNEDY: All right. Let me ask you, Mr.--is it Neuenschwander?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Certainly, sir.

KENNEDY: Apple has been--has been an advocate of encryption for a while. Is that correct?

NEUENSCHWANDER: That's correct.

KENNEDY: Okay, and Facebook is sort of--just got religion (PH), right?

SULLIVAN: The WhatsApp messaging app has been encrypted since--

KENNEDY: You just started to embrace encryption?

SULLIVAN: The WhatsApp messaging app that we provide--

KENNEDY: Have you just started to embrace encryption?

SULLIVAN: If I may just finish the one answer, WhatsApp has been encrypted since 2016, and we preannounced Messenger's plans about two years in advance.

KENNEDY: Didn't your--didn't--isn't the reason that Facebook decided to embrace encryption because of your competition with Apple and the criticism from Apple?

SULLIVAN: No, Senator.

KENNEDY: You just did that on--out of the goodness of your heart?

SULLIVAN: Our users want to be able to share messages and communicate with their family, loved ones, without anyone, not even Facebook, getting access to their messages. So it's driven by our customers.

KENNEDY: And I understand that. I mean, what role for--to the both of you--what role do you think that people's distrust of not only bad guys hacking into their--their information, but what role do you think people's distrust of government plays?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Senator, I don't know really what's in the mind of our customers, but I think--

KENNEDY: You haven't done market studies?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Not to my knowledge, sir. But if I just--

KENNEDY: So you haven't done any market studies about, about the impact on your business of going to encryption and throwing away the key as you've just talked about?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Not to my knowledge, sir, and certainly not with respect to anything around fear of government. If I think about most customers, I think that they shouldn't have a fear of government. They should have a fear of those criminals and the increasing threats. And that's why as we put more--

KENNEDY: You haven't seen it from the inside?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Pardon, sir?

KENNEDY: You haven't seen government from the inside, have you?

NEUENSCHWANDER: No, sir, I have not seen government from the inside. But I would just say, sir, that I think with the increasing sensitive data and the reliance and the move into areas of national security and national infrastructure, that we remain committed to encryption because we think it will keep us all safer.

KENNEDY: Do you sell Apple phones in China?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Yes, sir, we do.

KENNEDY: Okay, and--and are they encrypted?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Sir, the phone is the same across the world. The encryption is the same across the world.

KENNEDY: And--and you're--look me in the eye now. You're telling me that China allows you to sell your devices in China without you allowing them to breach the encryption and gain information about their users?

NEUENSCHWANDER: That's 100 percent correct, Senator.

KENNEDY: Do you believe Jimmy Hoffa died a natural death?

(LAUGHTER)

NEUENSCHWANDER: I--I wouldn't speculate, sir.

KENNEDY: I don't.

Let me ask one last question. Am I last, Madam Chair?

BLACKBURN: Well, we've had a request for a second round--

KENNEDY: --Okay--

BLACKBURN: --But I think Senator Lee is the only one that would want--

KENNEDY: --Can I have 30 seconds--

BLACKBURN: --To question in a second round. Yes, sir. I yield you 30 seconds.

KENNEDY: Let me--let me ask my friend from--Mr. Sullivan. Isn't it a fact, Mr. Sullivan, that there are people at Facebook that could go to my Facebook page and actually put a name to all my data if they wanted to and find out the--all the information that you have about me and put name to face?

SULLIVAN: You're talking about employees?

KENNEDY: Yeah.

SULLIVAN: Senator, we have very strict what we call access controls.

KENNEDY: Are there people at Facebook--don't--don't dodge and weave. I've only got 30 seconds, man. Just tell me. Are there people at Facebook that can go in and--and match my data to my name?

SULLIVAN: We really restrict when and how any employee whatever look at a customer's data--

KENNEDY: --But you can, can't you--

SULLIVAN: --To lawful--well--

KENNEDY: --You can, can't you?

SULLIVAN: --To be able to respond--

KENNEDY: --You can, can't you--

SULLIVAN: --To lawful requests we would.

KENNEDY: Can you do it?

SULLIVAN: Yes, sir, to respond to lawful requests.

KENNEDY: Thank you, Madam Chairman.

BLACKBURN: The gentleman yields back. And there is a request for a second round, Senator Feinstein. If there is no objection, I think Senator Lee is--

FEINSTEIN: --No objection--

BLACKBURN: Senator Lee is the only one who wanted a second round. Senator Lee, you're recognized for five minutes.

LEE: Thank you very much, Madam Chair. Mr. Neuenschwander, I wanted to give you a chance to respond to Mr. Vance's point a few minutes ago.

NEUENSCHWANDER: Thank you--pardon me. Thank you, Senator. I think that what I hear is an incorrect inference that if Apple's process, by which we used to extract data for law enforcement had not been breached, that customers had not been breached. And what we were aware of it and has now is that customers are breached and their data is taken by common criminals.

LEE: Okay.

NEUENSCHWANDER: And so, the step that we took was to actually shore up the device security for all people and stop the threats that we were seeing in the attacks against our customers.

LEE: Okay. So, in fact those breaches do occur.

NEUENSCHWANDER: To customers--

LEE: --Yeah--

NEUENSCHWANDER: --Without--without making a comment about Apple, absolutely.

LEE: To customers and--and people, including children, can be harmed when those breaches occur.

NEUENSCHWANDER: I agree, Senator.

LEE: One can be very concerned about children and about children--protecting children from things including child sex--sexual exploitation by being concerned about their data privacy, is that not right?

NEUENSCHWANDER: Certainly, Senator. I mean, we are very concerned about that. We find the material and the people who traffic in it abhorrent, and we want no place for them on our platform.

LEE: Mr. Tait, you acknowledged a moment ago briefly that, if we were to start mandating this for devices, people would quickly move to apps. You mentioned Facebook is one app they might migrate to. Let's suppose that Facebook changed its practices. Would they not migrate to other apps using end to end data encryption within the same phone?

TAIT: So, sir, I think it's very important to distinguish device encryption, which is related to device searches, which is software that manufactured by--

LEE: --I get that--

TAIT: --The phones.

LEE: I get that. But people would still have a way of using encryption on a phone.

TAIT: For--for app--for end to end communications, certainly there's a possibility that people might choose other apps. There are several different communications apps. There's very few device encryption apps, because they are essentially the--of the operating system of the device itself. And when we look at those device manufacturers are, they are overwhelmingly multibillion-dollar U.S. phones. They're--there's--there's not many overseas providers that have device encryption software.

LEE: Thank you. Mr. Vance, you're a prosecutor, and a--and a good one. You're also an iPhone user, from what I could tell a minute ago when you held up your device. Do you prosecute drug cartels or people affiliated with drug cartels?

VANCE: Our office has a special narcotics prosecutor that sits next to our office and particularly prosecute those cases.

LEE: In--including some of the big cartels like the Sinaloa drug cartel--

VANCE: --Yes--

LEE: --Gulf cartel and so forth.

VANCE: Yes.

LEE: The other entities that, based on my understanding, have a--have annual revenues that are staggering, that any U.S. company, any large blue-chip U.S. corporation, would envy. As entities with a lot of money, these enterprises could invest a lot of money in reverse engineering a backdoor. They could, if given the time and the resources, break into a backdoor system created through an Apple device. Would you be comfortable with your phone or that of your colleagues being hacked into by the Sinaloa drug cartel?

VANCE: Well, of course I wouldn't, Senator. But I still haven't heard the answer, I think, to the question or a factor that are raised. Yes, I understand that Apple is telling us that consumers' data was taken. It happens every day. I mean, that happens when people's--click on the--an attachment or go up to a--a website and malware is loaded. Of course devices and individuals have been compromised.

The question is, in the process of unlocking the device when we sent it to Apple historically, did that process create a vulnerability while it was at Apple and before they extracted material and send it back to us? General counsel for Apple in 2016 said no.

LEE: Mr. Neuenschwander, What's your response to that?

NEUENSCHWANDER: I would certainly agree with my former general counsel that we are aware of no breach of that process. But again, that process relied on a state of the device for which we are absolutely aware that there were breaches of customer data and harm to our customers around the world.

LEE: Okay. And--and that device is--is now operating on a different platform, one that doesn't permit that. What would happen if you were to take your current platform and engineer it in such a way that it could work like the previous system did?

NEUENSCHWANDER: I--I think, Senator, there are two major options for that one, and Professor Tait alluded to both of them. One of them is that we can roll back to that prior state of 2014 and begin to leave customers around the world again evolved--or, sorry, exposed, even though the threats would have evolved and grown stronger over the five years, six years. And I think that would leave everyone the worst.

The second possibility is that we could do something which we never did, which is try to hold in our possession a key that would read the passcode protect the data on customers' devices. And as a technologist, I am extremely fearful of the security properties of such a system.

LEE: I've appreciated the thoughtful exchange we've had from our witnesses today. I want to be clear about the fact that I--I don't regard this as an easy set of problems to solve. I think we do ourselves, and the Senate as an institution and those we serve, a grave disservice when we allow this conversation to send into a contest over who loves children and--and--and who acts with reckless disregard for them.

You can always tell when a conversation is descending into a bad area when people start invoking extreme examples like that. One of the reasons people use them is that, in some circumstances, they work. You can demonize someone if you can make someone look calloused, recklessly indifferent toward the needs of children. Then you can make them an enemy and you can disqualify them from everything they say.

This is the opposite of this sort of stability that we need in our society. And I--I worry a lot about some of the discussion we had today because much of it has focused on this sort of ad Hitlerum strategy that attempts to demonize certain individuals, when in fact we--we are not dealing with something--with a circumstance where we can easily identify one way that protects children and one way that disregards them. If we open these things up, there are consequences. There are consequences to children. There are consequences that will result in more children being abused and exploited and the--and having other horrible things done to them.

So, I hope, Madam Chair, that in future conversations we can have more respect for each other and for our witnesses in approaching difficult concepts like this one. Thank you.

BLACKBURN: The gentleman yields back. That is the end of the member questioning. We thank each of you for being here with us today.

Members are reminded that we are going to keep the record open until the stated time, and we will have the opportunity to submit questions. We ask you all, for the questions that have been submitted for on the record answers, that you would reply quickly.

I do want to ask unanimous consent to submit for the record the two articles I referenced, one from TechCrunch on Facebook paying the children, the other from The Hill on looking at Messenger Kids and the bug there that I hope you all have fixed, that allowed unauthorized adults on to that.

We thank you so much for being here to participate and work with us on this issue. We look forward to continuing the conversation and finding a resolution that is going to allow us to keep the Internet safe, to keep it open and free and innovative, but to make certain that protections are there for our children, and that needed data is there for law enforcement. The hearing is adjourned.

Senate Judiciary Committee Holds Hearing On Law Enforcement Response To Fraud During The New Coronavirus

June 09, 2020 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-S.C.), CHAIRMAN

SEN. CHARLES E. GRASSLEY (R-IOWA)

SEN. JOHN CORNYN (R-TEXAS)

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UTAH)

SEN. TED CRUZ (R-TEXAS)

SEN. BEN SASSE (R-NEB.)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

SEN. THOM TILLIS (R-N.C.)

SEN. JONI ERNST (R-IOWA)

SEN. MICHAEL D. CRAPO (R-IDAHO)

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R-LA.)

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TENN.)

SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN (D-CALIF.), RANKING MEMBER

SEN. PATRICK J. LEAHY (D-VT.)

SEN. RICHARD J. DURBIN (D-ILL.)

SEN. SHELDON WHITEHOUSE (D-R.I.)

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR (D-MINN.)

SEN. CHRIS COONS (D-DEL.)

SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL (D-CONN.)

SEN. MAZIE K. HIRONO (D-HAWAII)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-N.J.)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS (D-CALIF.)

[*]GRAHAM: Good morning, everybody. Thank you very much for attending the hearing. And I'm sure we'll have more come in, throughout the morning.

We've got four witnesses: Mr. Craig Carpenito, is that right? Okay good, U.S. Attorney for the District of New Jersey; Bill Hughes, Associate Deputy Attorney General; Calvin Shivers, Assistant Director of the Criminal Investigative Division, FBI; Michael D'Ambrosio, Assistant Director of the Office of Investigations, United States Secret Service.

So, we talked about this before, fraud related to the CARES Act, scams out there against seniors, selling masks that don't work, trying to play on peoples' fears. Unfortunately, when you try to do some good in the country, people take advantage of it.

And we're going to hear from our folks, today, about what's going on out there and some ideas about how to make sure it stops, if we can.

Phase IV will be coming. There's a need, in my view, for Phase IV. So, I'd like to learn as much as we can about the Paycheck Protection Program, the economic impact for individuals and supplemental unemployment benefits, how those programs are, sometimes, being abused. And generally, about what people are doing out there to scam Americans, particularly, our seniors. And that's the purpose of the hearing.

With that, I'll turn it over to Senator Feinstein.

FEINSTEIN: Thanks, Mr. Chairman. I'll put my statement in the record, so you can proceed. Thank you.

GRAHAM: Thank you. Anything from anybody? Okay. Let's start with Mr. Hughes.

HUGHES: Good morning, Mr. Chairman, Ranking Member Feinstein and members of the committee. Thank you for inviting me to appear before you, today, with several of my colleagues, to discuss the federal law enforcement efforts to deter, detect and prosecute those who violate federal law, by exploiting the COVID 19 pandemic and the economic dislocation it has caused.

Before I focus on the topic of the day, I want to take a moment to address the tragic killing of George Floyd. As Attorney General Barr and Deputy Attorney General Rosen have previously said, the video images of the police conduct in this instance are incredibly disturbing.

As the Attorney General previously announced, the Department is conducting a parallel and independent investigation into this incident, in collaboration with the FBI, to determine whether federal civil rights laws were violated.

We intend to conduct that investigation, as swiftly as possible, and are not sparing any resources. We know that George Floyd's death was not the first of its kind and it exposes concerns that reach far beyond this specific incident.

The outrage that Mr. Floyd's death has triggered is real, legitimate and deeply rooted. While the vast majority of police officers do their job honorably and in accordance with the law, we see instances like this one that erode confidence in the American criminal justice system.

America takes great pride in the rule of law being a bedrock principle and, as the nation's leading federal law enforcement agency, the Department of Justice is committed to doing its part to seek justice for Mr. Floyd and his loved ones and to secure the confidence of all Americans in law enforcement.

I know these issues are important to you. They are important to us. We welcome the opportunity to have discussions on the subject, in the days ahead. But for today, for this hearing, our subject is the pandemic, the related economic disruption and those that wish to exploit others for their own gain, during tremendously challenging times.

The Attorney General has made clear that, notwithstanding, the operational challenges the pandemic presents, it is critical that the Department is vigilant in detecting, investigating and prosecuting wrong doing, relating to the crisis.

This has become a high priority for us. Since the early days of the pandemic, we have been receiving reports of individuals and businesses using the crisis as an opportunity to exploit, both Americans and government programs, designed to assist Americans that have been hard hit.

Leveraging the public's concern about the pandemic, fraudsters utilized many schemes to separate Americans from the money in their bank accounts, from their government benefits and from there personally identifiable information.

Other fraudsters and unscrupulous opportunists have gotten into the personal protective equipment trade, looking to defraud and price gouge health providers, first responders and other essential workers, who have no choice but to pay astronomical prices for protective equipment that their health depends on.

We're also seeing schemes that target taxpayer backed relief programs that provide Americans and American businesses financial help, as they weather a disrupted economy.

In particular, fraudsters are targeting the Payroll Protection Program, the Economic Impact Payment Program and its state unemployment benefit programs.

The pandemic has also changed the cyber threat landscape. Child predators on the Internet see widespread closing of schools, stay-at-home orders and the reliance on Internet platforms, as the primary means of communication, as an opportunity to prey on children.

Cyber criminals also see the widespread work from home posture of many American businesses, as an opportunity to attack and infiltrate business computer networks, to disable systems, or steal or hold hostage, valuable data.

As I'm sure you will agree, it is reprehensible that anyone would use this crisis as an opportunity to profit, at another person's expense or, otherwise, prey on the public.

The Department of Justice will not tolerate it. And our resolve is demonstrated by our efforts to coordinate a cross Department offices and components to collaborate with other government agencies and to engage with industry and the public.

We are already bringing cases to hold fraudsters accountable and to disrupt their schemes. And we will be doing so, for the foreseeable future.

I thank you, again, for the invitation and I look forward to your questions.

CARPENITO: Good morning, Chairman Graham, Ranking Member Feinstein and members of the committee. I am Craig Carpenito, the United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey. I was appointed by Attorney General Barr to lead the Department's Hoarding and Price Gouging Task Force.

We are grateful for the privilege of appearing before you, today, to discuss the Department's efforts to detect and prosecute those who, for their personal financial gain, seek to exploit the COVID 19 pandemic and the economic dislocation it has caused.

The Attorney General and the Deputy Attorney General our leading those efforts and we are honored to help them in that vital task.

We want to thank the committee for its attention to these issues and to the good work at the Department of Justice to protect the safety and security of our nation, during this unprecedented crisis.

Before I answer your questions, today, about price gouging, hoarding and COVID 19 fraud, however, I would like to take a moment to acknowledge the senseless and tragic death of George Floyd, at the hands of the Minneapolis police.

I am proud of the people of New Jersey, who have raised their voices in peaceful protest, seeking justice and reform in the name of Mr. Floyd and the other victims, like him.

I hear and appreciate their call for change. In New Jersey, we have witnessed productive community and law enforcement partnerships in cities like Newark and Camden.

These partnerships have lowered crime and restored trust. While we in New Jersey are proud of these efforts, we recognize that we must and we will do more.

Now, let me turn to the reason I'm here, today.

We've seen a broad range of illegal conduct, throughout the country, in these past few months. Our strategies and responses have evolved to meet new challenges, as they arise. But our core philosophy has not. The Department will investigate and prosecute those who treat--seek to treat COVID 19, as an opportunity to defraud the public and the government.

The Department has received many reports of individuals and businesses, using the crisis to seek windfall profits, at the expense of public safety and the health and welfare of the American people. These reports range from the sale of fake cures of COVID 19, online, to hoarding and price gouging of critical medical supplies, to defrauding the CARES Act economic programs.

The Department is, aggressively, investigating those reports and has already commenced prosecutions.

The Department's attorneys work side by side with our partners at the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Secret Service, as well as other federal, state and local agency partners.

Make no mistake, the fight against COVID 19 is a fight to save precious lives, every day. Our medical professionals and first responders put their own lives at risk to stand between the virus and each of us. The personal protective equipment that they wear is the only shield they have to protect themselves, as they bravely go face to face with the virus, each day.

It helps ensure our heroes do not fall victim to the disease. It also helps ensure that they do not bring it home to their families and their broader communities.

Hoarding and price gouging, in particular, have inhibited front line healthcare professionals, essential workers and the public from acquiring the supplies the need to protect themselves from contracting the virus. Hospitals, first responders and retail consumers have been targeted by individuals who view the scarcity of critical medical materials, as a path to get rich quick.

This conduct has disrupted our supply chains and markets and jeopardized the safety of our communities. In response, Attorney General Barr and Deputy Attorney General Rosen, assembled the Departments hoarding and Price Gouging Task Force to combat and prevent hoarding and price gouging.

The task force is comprised of over 100 experienced federal prosecutors, throughout the nation's 93 U.S. Attorneys offices and Department components, here in Washington.

The task force's primary mission is to identify, investigate and prosecute illegal hoarding and price gouging of crucial medical supplies, including personal protective equipment, such as face masks, that are essential to preventing the spread of the virus.

We do so in the larger context of the current public health crisis. The decision the Department makes to open investigations, or to bring charges, are intended to help the public health response. Accordingly, the task force is focusing on profiteering, especially, by market participants, who sell scarce materials for excessive prices that far exceed their reasonable cost.

The task force also is investigating counterfeit, misbranded and defective medical supplies, imported into the U.S., from abroad. These flawed products are entering our stream of commerce and creating safety hazards. We will use all of our tools at our disposal to identify these products and those who transaction them here and abroad and hold them accountable.

The Department's efforts are ongoing but they have already yielded substantial results. We've brought several federal criminal cases, across the country, alleging price gouging, fraud, misbranding and other charges.

Just last week, the task force commenced the Department's first criminal prosecution against a foreign manufacturer for sending defective and misbranded N95 respirator masks into the United States, during the pandemic. Instead of protecting our medical professionals, these materials would have, silently, put them in harm's way.

We've also seized hoarded materials and worked with agents and partners to distribute them to those on the front lines to fight COVID 19.

Thank you, again, for inviting us to address these important topics and I look forward to answering your questions.

GRAHAM: Mr. Shivers.

SHIVERS: Good morning, Chairman Graham, Ranking Member Feinstein and members of the committee.

My name is Calvin Shivers and I'm the Assistant Director of the FBI's Criminal Investigative Division.

Thank you for the opportunity to appear before you, today, to discuss the FBI's response to COVID 19 related fraud.

As head of the FBI's Criminal Investigative Division, I oversee the FBI's financial crimes and fraud against the government programs. In my role as the Assistant Director of the Criminal Division, I also oversee civil rights, color of law and hate crime investigations.

I believe it's important that I take a moment to address the recent events, which have grabbed our nation's attention, before I focus on the issues, surrounding today's hearing.

I, along with my colleagues at the FBI, offer our sincerest condolences to the family and friends of George Floyd. The FBI civil rights program has a long and proud history of protecting the rights of the American people.

As the primary federal agency responsible for civil rights investigations, we at the FBI are committed to utilizing our full set of investigative and intelligence capabilities to address violations of federal civil rights laws.

In pursuit of justice, we are conducting a thorough investigation into the actions that led to George Floyd's death. The FBI recognizes the rights of citizens to exercise their first amendment rights and we will continue to work to protect our citizens and their ability to exercise those rights, free of violence.

Now, I will shift back to the topic at hand.

These are unprecedented times for most Americans. Due to COVID 19, people are, understandably, worried about their health and their livelihood. Although we are coming together in various communities and throughout the country, unfortunately, there are individuals who seek to exploit our anxieties and fears, by selling fake COVID 19 cures, or vaccines.

They are also peddling fraudulent investment opportunities in companies, purportedly, working to develop cures and vaccines for COVID 19. These were some of the earliest COVID 19 fraud schemes the FBI identified.

When the attorney general issued a memorandum on March 16 of this year, directing U.S. attorneys to prioritize COVID 19 related fraud investigations and prosecutions, the FBI was ready.

Within days, all 56 FBI field offices began working a wide range of investigations, related to COVID 19 fraud schemes.

As we began our investigations, we saw a number of different criminal schemes. We saw subjects hoarding personal protective equipment, or PPE, and attempting to sell it at exorbitant prices. We also saw people selling counterfeit, or substandard PPE.

The FBI worked closely with the Department of Justice and other law enforcement partners to conduct price gouging investigations, or seize counterfeit PPE.

The CARES Act was designed to provide fast and direct economic assistance to families, American workers and small businesses. However, there are individuals who seek to steal money from the people the CARES Act was designed to help.

With the passage of the CARES Act, we began to see fraudsters shift their efforts towards exploiting the various programs created to relieve the severe economic effects of COVID 19.

To effectively target this growing threat, the FBI formed a Payroll Protection Program Fraud Working Group, in coordination with the Department of Justice's fraud section and the Small Business Administration's Office of Inspector General. Through this effort, 116 investigations have been initiated and over $126 million in potential fraud has been identified.

We're also beginning to see healthcare fraud. We are seeing fraudulent billing for services not received, charges for unnecessary procedures and fraud related to telemedicine.

In addition to fraud schemes, we are seeing crimes targeting our children. School closures have increased the presence of children, online. In addition, social distancing restrictions and the isolation of children at home may afford terminal actors with an opportunity to sexually exploit vulnerable children.

We are, proactively, countering this threat, through active investigations. We're also working to educate the public, regarding the warning signs and the danger of online sexual exploitation.

Although these threats are numerous and evolving rapidly, the FBI has and will continue to be vigilant in addressing these crimes and holding the individuals who commit these crimes, accountable.

We rely, heavily, on public education and awareness. When the general public is made aware of fraudulent schemes and criminal activity, they are better situated to report them. For that reason, I am incredibly appreciative of the opportunity to speak with you, today.

I thank you, Chairman Graham, and Ranking Member Feinstein, for bring attention to these issues and I'm happy to answer any questions you might have. Thank you.

D'AMBROSIO: Thank you, Chairman Graham, Ranking Member Feinstein and distinguished members of this committee.

Before I begin, like my colleagues, I'd like to express my deep sadness and frustration with the tragic events of recent weeks.

Having served in government for nearly 29 years, nothing troubles me more than police misconduct. It severely erodes the essential trust necessary for law enforcement to, effectively, protect and serve our communities.

Law enforcement must be held to the highest standard. Racism and discrimination in any form is totally unacceptable.

The Secret Service is committed and, indeed, oath bound, to ensuring that all Americans are afforded their constitutional rights to equal treatment, under the law, and to freedom of speech and assembly.

Those rights are unalienable and no duty is higher for a law enforcement officer then to protect them.

Returning to the subject of this hearing. Thank you all for inviting me to speak about the current wave of COVID 19 related crime and the work of the United States Secret Service to counter it.

As early as February of this year, the Secret Service identified individuals and groups, seeking to exploit the pandemic for illicit profit.

We quickly took action to build the capacity and strategy necessary to combat what we anticipated would be a surge of criminal activity.

Major disasters have long invited fraud. From the terrorist attacks on 9/11, to hurricanes Katrina and Maria and, indeed, well before, criminals throughout history have used public emergencies, as opportunities to defraud the public.

However, the fraud associated with the current COVID 19 pandemic presents a scale and scope of risk we have not seen, before. Enabled by the Internet, criminals all over the world are defrauding anxious citizens, distressed businesses and government stimulus programs, alike.

Since we released our first alert on March 4, we observed the significant proliferation of criminal schemes. In particular, we have seen a surge in crimes targeting various economic relief programs, such as those provided by the CARES Act. Countering this fraud has become a core focus of investigative work and I expect our investigative efforts will continue, for years.

The Secret Service, in addition to our protective mission, is responsible for the investigation of criminal violations of U.S. law, pertaining to the U.S. financial system.

As the Assistant Director of the Office of Investigations, I lead the, over 160 field officers of the Secret Service, which includes our network of electronic and financial crimes task forces, which conduct specialized investigations of cyber and financial crimes.

The immediate investigative focus of the Secret Service is to disrupt and deter criminal activity that could hinder an effective response to the pandemic, by assisting organizations at risk of fraud and working to recover any funds stolen from Americans.

Longer term, we will ensure that those who have criminally exploited this crisis are arrested and, successfully, prosecuted.

I am pleased to report that the Secret Service has already seen tremendous success emerge from our investigative efforts, to date. We have initiated over 100 criminal investigations and prevented, approximately, $1 billion in fraud losses.

Among other law enforcement actions, the Secret Service has, successfully, disrupted hundreds of online COVID 19 related scams, halted the illicit sale of stolen COVID 19 test kits online and is leading a nationwide effort to counter a vast, international scheme to defraud U.S. state unemployment systems.

We have also released regular threat intelligence and alerts to provide industry, consumers and our law enforcement partners with the best practices to defend themselves from the latest criminal threats. However, we are not achieving these results by ourselves. We can credit much of our success to the close partnerships we have built, with a range of government and industry partners.

In particular, we are working closely with the various agencies of the Department of Treasury, with the Cyber Security and Infrastructure Security Agency and Homeland Security investigations, as well as various offices of the inspector general, particularly, from the Department of Labor and Small Business Administration. And of course, my colleagues to the right, within the Department of Justice, their COVID 19 Task Force and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, have all been essential partners.

I am committed to ensuring the Secret Service is doing our part, on behalf of the American people, to counter criminal activity exploiting this pandemic. I look forward to answering your questions on how we can work together to address this threat.

Thank you.

GRAHAM: Well, thank you all. I'll start with the Secret Service. Can you give me some examples of how people are taking advantage of the Paycheck Protection Program?

D'AMBROSIO: We primarily, right now, our focus on the unemployment--

GRAHAM: --Okay, I'm sorry. Let's, tell me about unemployment.

D'AMBROSIO: So, right now, it's mainly stolen identity, theft investigation in which criminals are utilizing stolen PII, things that they have acquired on, whether it be the dark web, whether it be network intrusions. And they are using that stolen information to apply for Social Security benefits and probably across, right now, about 29 states, across the country that we have seen.

It's not a very complex fraud. It's the availability of PII out in public that allows for this to occur.

GRAHAM: Got you. Is there anything this committee can do to help you in this endeavor? Do you have all the tools you need in current law?

D'AMBROSIO: We have the tools, right now, that we need for this particular--

GRAHAM: --Do you have the resources?

D'AMBROSIO: We have the resources with the partnerships that we created, whether it be the Department of Labor, as well as--

GRAHAM: Okay, the answer is yes, right? Okay.

D'AMBROSIO: The answer is yes.

GRAHAM: Mr. Shivers, I appreciate what you all are doing at the FBI. When it comes to consumer fraud, what are you seeing most of?

SHIVERS: (OFF MIC)

GRAHAM: Your mic, please. Thank you.

SHIVERS: So, as I mentioned in my opening, on the consumer fraud, initially, private citizens were targeted through a number of schemes. Many of those schemes included offers to sell counterfeit COVID-19 cures, or vaccines. And as I mentioned in the opening, also, investment opportunities.

And so, what we see is a wide range of citizens being targeted, through a number of means--

GRAHAM: --Is that problem getting better, or worse, or is it about the same?

SHIVERS: It's continuing--I think, COVID-19, obviously, has shined a light on an opportunity for criminals to take advantage of a specific type of scheme.

And so, what we see is a number of ways that they're reaching individuals, through unsolicited phone calls, or through unsolicited emails. So, there's a wide range.

And what we ask the public to do is to make reports to IC3.gov. and that gives us greater visibility on the nature of threats and the number of threats.

GRAHAM: Is there anything the committee can do? Do you have the tools you need to deal with the problem?

SHIVERS: We do, sir.

GRAHAM: Okay, thank you. Mr. Carpenito, is that right?

CARPENITO: Carpenito, sir.

GRAHAM: Carpenito, I'm sorry. Tell us about the fraudulent sales going on out there. What's going on, in terms of overseas activity?

CARPENITO: So, what we're seeing, sir, with regards to hoarding and price gouging is the trends have indicated to us that, initially, what we had was fraud relating to a spike in the prices of the materials.

What happened was, just like any scenario we've seen in our country's history where we have a national crisis, there's always going to be that dark underbelly that rises to the top and tries to profit, illicitly, from the fears of folks that are most impacted by the pandemic.

The challenges that we have are the same challenges that you have in any sort of a disaster relief related fraud situation. We faced it in New Jersey, after Hurricane Sandy. As Senator Graham correctly stated, when you put this kind of money out into the ether because you have to take care of society and, you know, take care of those who are desperately in need of it, the cockroaches are going to come out of the dark and into the light.
