Senate Judiciary Subcommittee On Antitrust, Competition Policy And Consumer Rights Holds Hearing On Antitrust Laws

September 17, 2019 02:30 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UTAH), CHAIRMAN

SEN. CHARLES E. GRASSLEY (R-IOWA)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

SEN. MICHAEL D. CRAPO (R-IDAHO)

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TENN.)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-S.C.), EX-OFFICIO

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR (D-MINN.), RANKING MEMBER

SEN. PATRICK J. LEAHY (D-VT.)

SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL (D-CONN.)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-N.J.)

SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN (D-CALIF.), EX-OFFICIO

[*]LEE: Welcome to this hearing on the Subcommittee on Antitrust Competition, Policy and Consumer Rights. Today, we're pleased to have with us the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission Joseph Simons and the Assistant Attorney General for the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice Makan Delrahim. Welcome to both of you.

As an initial matter, as a matter of housekeeping, we've been informed that we may have a block of four votes starting about an hour from now as a practical matter. We may well be able to push to an hour and 15, hour and a half from now before we have to recess at some point. We likely will have to go recess to cast a few votes. We will have to play some of that by ear. I apologize in advance for that.

No way to predict these things in advance--it does seem, however, to be an uncanny event with antitrust subcommittee hearings--seems to be a good predictor, albeit an unintentional predictor of when votes are going to occur.

As both of you know, I've been critical of the fact that we have two federal agencies responsible for civil antitrust enforcement. And this, of course, is not your choice. This is a choice made by congress in years past, and so the fact that the law is the way it is has a lot to do with this branch of government and not to do with your respective offices.

And I have to say, your two agencies have done a remarkable job in recent points--in recent months of making the point that I have with regard to my concerns about having two agencies with overlapping civil antitrust enforcement authority. It--it's true that, for many decades, the FTC and the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice have jointly handled civil antitrust enforcement, but in the past, the agencies have avoided too much mischief because they've generally played well together. And recently, this appears quite regrettably to have changed.

From what I hear, from what I can tell, clearance disputes have become more frequently, more pronounced and more prolonged. It's bad enough that your agencies sometimes determine who will investigate a matter according to position arrows and coin tosses, but these clearance disputes impose real cost by wasting resources, creating delays and creating a certain amount of institutional pettiness.

Having two federal agencies handling civil antitrust enforcement is also creating confusion, both here and abroad, when the FTC and the DOJ are not on the same page. This is clearly on display in the recent Qualcomm matter where your agencies are literally opposing each other in federal court. None of this makes for effective or efficient antitrust enforcement, and not one of us would design a system from the outset if we were writing on a blank slate this way.

Earlier this summer, we learned that your agencies have begun investigating the large tech firms, some large tech firms to see if they violated antitrust laws. And I've said before, I'm encouraged that the FTC and the DOJ are bringing much-needed antitrust scrutiny to these tech companies. But I'm also concerned about the way you but divvied up these investigations.

Now, I understand, when it comes to specific investigations, your clearance process designates a single agency to investigate a specific matter. But based on news reports, it sounds like your agencies may be pursuing monopolization investigations of the same companies, at the same time, through two different agencies.

Now, let me be clear. I don't think your agencies should be divvying up parts of a monopolization investigation of the same company, tech company or otherwise. Former FTC Chairman, Bill Kovacic, has called this nuts. And I agree.

There's no analytical basis for splitting a monopolization investigation between the FTC and the department of justice. Doing so, simply looks like both agencies simply want to have, not just a slice of the same pie, but the same slice of the same pie, at the same time.

This will have the agencies stumbling over each other and will inevitably, undermine, rather than further the enforcement efforts of both agencies.

Consumers, of course, deserve better than that. Consumers are harmed when you are tripping over each other and you are unable to do your job, effectively.

On the topic of big tech, I'd like to hear your views, today, on whether viewpoint bias should be the subject of antitrust enforcement. I share many of my colleagues concerns with what appears to be bias against certain political viewpoints, particularly conservative political viewpoints by companies like Google and like Facebook.

What I don't necessarily share is the suggestion, by some, that antitrust is necessarily the proper tool to address this issue. But I welcome your thoughts on this topic, as I certainly have more to learn.

We often hear talk that antitrust policy needs to evolve to address competitive issues in these tech markets. Advocates of the so-called hipster antitrust theory argue that antitrust is too focused on price effects. They claim that this causes antitrust enforcers to ignore anti-competitive conduct in markets where consumers receive services for free. I'd love to know your thoughts on that topic.

Finally, I hope we'll have time to discuss what the antitrust division is doing, when it comes to music. This includes what the division is considering in its review of the music licensing consent decrees.

Also, and I know this is something that my democratic colleagues have raised with you, I'd like to hear more about what the Department of Justice is doing to police anti-competitive conduct in the ticketing market.

Senator Klobuchar will now give her opening statement.

KLOBUCHAR: Thank you, very much, Mr. Chairman. Good afternoon to Chairman Simons, as well as to Assistant Attorney General Delrahim. We're pleased to have you both here to discuss this very important issue.

These times are far from typical for antitrust and competition policy. Many new antitrust issues have arisen, since our last oversight hearing.

The American people, increasingly, understand that competition is critical for their well-being. They know how important it is for consumers, the health of our markets and the future of our economy. And that is one thing that I have noticed is a change, over the last year, as there's just more and more discussion about the need to do something about enforcement in this area.

Yet, despite this widespread recognition of how important competition is to our nation's future, we still, as a country, have a major monopoly problem.

Given the grave competition problems we are facing while, as much as I appreciate my colleague's focus on the two agencies and what he referred to as mischief, I am much more concerned about the bigger picture, which is how we're going to take on the monopoly issues of our time and how we're going to take on the competition issues, whether they are in tech or whether they are in the pharmaceutical area or so many others.

And I was thinking about the analogy of splitting the pie. I am more concerned that our consumers are going to get a big pie in their face, if we don't do something about this.

We are seeing higher levels of market concentration, across our economy, partially driven by waves of corporate consolidation. Since 2008, American firms have engaged in more than ten trillion in acquisitions and between 2012 and 2017, annual merger filings at the antitrust agencies have increased, by more than 50 percent.

And those waiting for this trend to slow down will need to wait longer, because the latest agency report shows that merger filing increased, yet again, in 2018, the sixth consecutive annual increase.

These more concentrated markets have led to decreased competition in many industries, including pharmaceutical, social media, digital technology, telecom, ag, online ticket sales, transportation and more.

Today, I sent a letter to the FTC with a number of my colleagues, raising concerns about two proposed pharmaceutical mega mergers, that would be AbbVie's acquisition of Allergan and Bristol-Myers acquisition of Celgene and their potential effects on prices.

There's one additional matter I will be raising at this hearing. Since the beginning of this administration, I have repeatedly had cause to raise concerns about reported White House attempts to interfere in antitrust enforcement efforts for political purposes.

I've sent numerous letters to the department and the White House, concerning potential interference in antitrust law, based on statements that the president and administration officials reportedly made, regarding matters, such as the Bayer, Monsanto merger, the AT&T, Time Warner merger and the still pending T Mobile, Sprint merger.

Not all of my letters were answered but the responses that I did get received contained carefully worded assurances that the department had followed its procedures and that it was quote, "Not aware of any influence by the White House," on any of the antitrust matters in question.

The actual extent of any contact between the White House officials and the department enforcers concerning pending antitrust matters is still a mystery. And now, we have reports of the antitrust division investigating four auto makers for negotiating with California regulators to lower California fuel emission standards to a level that would be more stringent than the standard that the Trump administration intends to impose.

The automakers reported conduct seems to be little more than an effort by regulated companies to petition a state regulator from our favorable rule, something that happens all the time between state and federal regulators.

Quite frankly, the antitrust investigation into these automakers, appears to have less to do with protecting competition than with intimidating parties that don't fall into line with the Trump administration's plan to relax emission standards.

A letter from the EPA and the Department of Transportation to the California Air Resources Board only bolsters the perception that this antitrust investigation is part of a broader effort to, by the administration, to promote its preferred emissions standard and bully those who get in the way.

For years, both antitrust agencies have talked about applying the consumer welfare standard. This investigation looks more like enforcement, guided by a corporate welfare standard for oil companies and light truck manufacturers.

I have questions about how this investigation, regarding the gas mileage standards, was initiated and why the division decided to use its limited resources to pursue it.

As a matter of prosecutorial discretion, I find it hard to believe that an investigation into four automakers trying to navigating a shifting regulatory landscape is the best way to protect competition and consumers, when we're seeing consolidation in so many industries. Sometimes, why you do something is as important as what you do.

Also, the antitrust issues that have been received the most attention, of course, are those raised by the major tech companies. We're living in the time of rapid technological change. These changes have led to the rise of powerful technology companies that have come to dominate markets and gather massive amounts of information from consumers, raising serious concerns about competition and privacy.

At our last oversight hearing, I questioned why European enforcements have been investigating big tech, for years, while our agencies were doing nothing.

Since then, not only have we heard reports about tech antitrust investigations by the FTC and antitrust division but also by many state attorneys general.

But these new enforcement efforts, of course, occur against a backdrop of a federal judiciary that has become increasingly skeptical of antitrust enforcement, raising the procedural and evidentiary bar for government and private enforcement. And some have questioned whether the antitrust laws are up to task. I question that very much and that is why I have these bills that I think would be so helpful.

One, I appreciate the work Senator Grassley did with me on the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act that we introduced that would help with funding for both of your agencies.

And then, also, I've introduced the Consolidation Prevention and Competition Promotion Act with my colleagues to upgrade the antitrust standards to get at some of these issues that we are going to be hearing about, today. And then also, of course, the Civil Fine for Monopolization Mill, as well as the prescription drug pricing bills, one of which I have with Senator Grassley.

In closing, as a former prosecutor, I know how important it is to have enforcers that are ready and able to enforce the law without fear or favor. You both have the responsibility to ensure that your agencies act as vigorous yet, impartial, law enforcers.

Millions of Americans and the health of our free market depend on your efforts and your judgment to ensure that the economy remains fair and competitive.

Thank you and I look forward to your testimony.

LEE: Thank you, Senator Klobuchar. We will now be pleased to hear from both of our witnesses, each in turn for their opening statements, before we proceed to questions.

Joseph Simons was sworn in as the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission on May 1, 2018. Earlier in his career, he had served as the Director of the FTC's Bureau of Competition.

Makan Delrahim was confirmed on September 17, 2017, as the Assistant Attorney General for the Antitrust Division in the Department of Justice. Mr. Delrahim also worked at the antitrust division, earlier in his career, having previously served as Deputy Assistant Attorney Journal.

No stranger to the Senate, Mr. Delrahim knows his way around this institution, having previously served as Chief Counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Mr. Simons, we'll hear, first from you.

SIMONS: Thank you, so much Chairman Lee, Ranking Member Klobuchar and members of the subcommittee.

Thank you for the opportunity to appear before you, today. I am pleased to testify on behalf of the FTC regarding our current competition enforcement activities and policy priorities and, of course, also, to be alongside my esteemed colleague, Makan Delrahim.

The FTC's mission works to ensure that our nation's markets are competitive and working for American consumers. We do this through targeted, yet vigorous enforcement of the antitrust and consumer protection laws and also by using our unique research and policy tools.

Today, I will focus my remarks on the antitrust side of our mission. We promote competition through a rigorous fact intensive approach to law enforcement. We have jurisdiction over a wide swath of the economy and focus our enforcement efforts on sectors that most directly affect consumers and their wallets, such as healthcare, pharmaceuticals, consumer products and services, technology, manufacturing and energy.

In fiscal year 2019, the agency has challenged 20 mergers, so far. In June, the eighth circuit upheld our request for an injunction blocking an anti-competitive merger among healthcare providers in North Dakota.

This case is our fifth straight appellate victory in hospital, involving healthcare consolidations, following successful appeals of hospital mergers in the third, sixth, seventh, and ninth circuits.

This string of appellate victories, across multiple circuits, has solidified our analytical approach to these mergers.

The current state of the law relating to hospital mergers is no accident. It reflects the culmination of efforts to use the agency's enforcement, research and policy tools to protect healthcare consumers.

In the 1990s, the antitrust agencies lost a significant number of consecutive court challenges to hospital mergers. In response, the FTC launched a merger retrospective study that questioned the prevailing economic methodology that courts had relied on, in ruling against the agencies in these cases.

Those results, in turn, influence our subsequent enforcement work. Through our unique research capabilities, we successfully moved courts from embracing modern economic approach to analyzing competitive effects in these transactions.

On the conduct side, in 2019, we filed a complaint against Surescripts, for using vertical restraints to monopolize two markets associated with electronically transmitted prescription information and we have two other monopolization cases on appeal.

The agency has been consistently active in this area, bringing 24 monopolization cases, since the year 2000, including several, while I was the Bureau Director.

In 2013, the commission won a critical victory in FTC versus Actavis, when the Supreme Court clarified that pay for delay arrangements can violate the antitrust laws. This long-running case finally concluded this year on the eve of trial, when the defendants agreed to settle.

In March, the commission held in an administrative proceeding that impacts laboratories and Endo Pharmaceuticals and entered into a reverse payment arrangement that delay generic entry of an extended release opioid used for pain relief, Opana ER. The agency continues to monitor the use of any competitive reverse payment settlements.

I would also like to highlight our work in the technology sector. Our Bureau of Competition recently shifted resources to establish a dedicated technology task force. This task force is up and running and is actively investigating competitive activity in the U.S. technology markets.

For example, we are currently pursuing an antitrust investigation of Facebook. In addition to target law enforcement, we also have a robust research and policy function. We are in the process of concluding our hearings on competition and consumer protection in the 21st century.

We convened 14 sessions over 23 days, with thousands of people attending in person or watching via live webcast. We are distilling a large volume of stakeholder information and generating output, which likely will include reports, statements, guidance and speeches.

The FTC remains committed to marshaling its resources efficiently, in order to protect consumers and to promote competition, to anticipate and respond to changes in the marketplace and to meet the current and future challenges.

We look forward to continuing to work with this subcommittee and Congress and I look forward to your questions.

Thank you.

LEE: Thank you, Chairman Simons. Mr. Delrahim.

DELRAHIM: Thank you, Chairman Lee. Thank you, Ranking Member Klobuchar, former chairman of the committee, Grassley, and I see former Chairman Leahy, to his left, and distinguished members of this committee. Thank you for having me before you, today. And I also appreciate being next to my colleague, Chairman Simons.

Chairman Simons and I go back over 20 years. We were both on the same side, I think, on the consumers in the past investigations of Microsoft from representing different parties. But our work has continued and I'm pleased to work with him now, across the street.

The importance of antitrust enforcement continues to occupy the front pages, these days, in large part, to the efforts of many on this subcommittee.

I want to thank this subcommittee for continuing the bipartisan support of the antitrust division's work to protect competition, on behalf of American consumers, workers and entrepreneurs.

When corporations or individuals fix prices, rig bids or allocate the markets, they are robbing Americans of honest competition. The antitrust division has steadfastly held culpable--the culpable actors accountable.

Numbers can only tell part of the story but I'm proud that at the close of fiscal year 2018, our criminal program had the highest number of pending grand jury investigations, 91, over the past decade.

I'm particularly proud of the guilty pleas we obtained from five South Korean fuel companies that rigged bids on Department of Defense fuel supply contracts, at the expense of the American taxpayer.

The crimes in these cases directly targeted taxpayer dollars, which fund the critical work of the U.S. military and the Korean Peninsula. We obtained criminal and civil penalties in these cases, amounting to over $350 million.

In civil enforcement, the antitrust division continues to confront multi billion-dollar mergers that involve industries, important to every consumer, ranging from media to healthcare, to transportation and telephony.

Even with our constrained resources, the antitrust division has not hesitated to litigate, when we have needed to, after we have found the merger to be anti-competitive.

Separate from and as a complement to our enforcement mission, the antitrust division has engaged in robust competition advocacy, implementing a wide range of initiatives, designed to advance competition.

For example, the division has used its amicus initiative to address developments in case law earlier and more frequently, providing the opportunity to have an outsized impact, given our resources.

For instance, the division recently filed a statement of interest and argued at a hearing in a private antitrust case. The suit alleged that two major universities entered into an unlawful agreement not to poach each other's medical school faculty.

We were able to advance important arguments before the court about the application of the Per Se, Rule of anti-trust law and also push back on overly broad assertions of antitrust immunities, in that case.

Subsequently, and I think in an innovative manner, we successfully intervened in the settlement of the parties, after we had successfully argued in that case, the parties decided to settle.

We intervened, the court accepted our motion and doing so enabled the antitrust division to obtain the same relief and protections for the American worker that we would have achieved, had we conducted our own lengthy investigation.

It also provided some transparency to the markets about our enforcement priorities, with respect to no poach arrangements.

The division has also held workshops and roundtables, including a discussion of the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act, which is up for reauthorization, in less than a year.

I'm pleased that the administration has a position to seek reauthorization of that legislation.

In addition, we held a workshop on media advertising to inform our efforts to apply long held antitrust principles to the continuing evolving digital advertising market.

As I testified before the subcommittee last fall, will the division has recently established the Jackson-Nash address. This lecture series is designed to inspire and educate division staff and the public about cutting edge issues and developments in the field of economics.

Thus far, we've been honored to hear addresses from Nobel prize-winning economists, professors Alvin Roth, George Akerlof, Roger Myerson and last year's Nobel prize winner, Professor Paul Romer.

Each have provided valuable insights into innovation, competition and possible threats facing the modern economy.

Internationally, the United States, it's businesses and consumers benefit when other nations enforce the competition laws, according to sound economic principles and in accordance with appropriate procedures and protection.

You may recall that, at my confirmation hearing before this committee, over two years ago, I identified this issue as a top priority for me at the division. I'm proud to report that our initiative for multilateral agreement and our efforts over the last year, led to the international competition networks framework on competition agency procedures.

This is an historic achievement for procedural fairness and antitrust enforcement, across the globe, with now over 70 signatories.

Many doubted that this administration would be able to achieve this. I'm also proud to share that the United States sought and is granted the privilege of hosting, for the first time, the ICN's annual conference, in 2020. We will jointly be hosting that with the Federal Trade Commission in Los Angeles.

This is the most important conference for global competition enforcing agencies. Our host status will allow the division, along with the FTC, to showcase our ideals by promoting fundamental due process, through the gap. We also, will be able to engage with the world on a range of other important policy issues, including digital platform competition, cartel enforcement and cross border merger cooperation.

It's been nearly two years, since the Senate confirmed me to this post. Each day presents new challenges but there are two constants. First is the pride and responsibility that I feel, as I work with the talented attorneys, economists and staff of the antitrust division.

And second, it's my unwavering belief that the work we do at the antitrust division continues to provide for a competitive American workplace that benefits all Americans.

Thank you.

LEE: Thank you very much, to both of you. We will now begin five-minute questioning rounds.

In response to my first three questions, I'd like a simple yes or no answer from both of you. We'll start with Mr. Simons and then go to Mr. Delrahim for each of these three questions.

Mr. Simons, do you believe that your agency could benefit from more resources to enforce the antitrust laws.

SIMONS: Yes.

LEE: Mr. Delrahim.

DELRAHIM: Yes.

LEE: Would it be a waste of resources that you have within your agency for your agency to be investigating the same conduct in the same company at the same time, as something that's already being investigated by the Department of Justice?

SIMONS: Yes.

LEE: Mr. Delrahim, likewise with respect to the FTC.

DELRAHIM: Yes.

LEE: Mr. Simons, are you aware of any instance, any matter, prior to 2018, in which your two agencies were investigating the same company for the same conduct, at the same time.

SIMONS: No, Senator.

LEE: Mr. Delrahim.

DELRAHIM: I don't recall.

LEE: Okay, thank you. Let' move on to clearance. Back in June, news reports suggested that your agencies had divvied up review of the dominant tech firms. But in July, The Justice Department announced that it is conducting a broad review of the leading online platforms.

It sounds to me, in context, like your two agencies are covering the same ground, at least, in very significant part. In fact, the Wall Street Journal reported, yesterday, that the Justice Department may conduct its own antitrust monopolization related investigation of Facebook, despite the fact that the FTC is already investigating Facebook under a monopolization theory.

Chairman Simons, are the FTC and the Department of Justice still operating under the clearance-under a clearance system to avoid duplicative efforts or have things broken down on this front?

SIMONS: For the vast majority of matters, we continue to operate under the existing clearance agreement.

LEE: I'll take that as a yes, things have broken down, at least, in part. I'm not suggesting--

SIMONS: --Yeah, I would agree with that.

LEE: Mr. Delrahim, what can you tell us about that? Have they broken down? Are you still using it? Do you agree with Mr. Simon's suggestion?

DELRAHIM: Well, the clearance process and the agreement is a process we are continuing to use.

LEE: But you'd acknowledge that it's broken down in, at least, some cases.

DELRAHIM: I would acknowledge that there is, over the last 20 years and you might recall that Chairman Muris and Assistant Attorney General James, when they faced this back in 2002, I believe, entered into an arrangement that could have solved a lot of the problems because this has been going on, not recently, but in the past. Chairman Simons, a little while ago, when we talked before we had to leave to go vote, I asked you if you were advising another country on how to set up its civil antitrust enforcement, would you ever set up a system where you had two agencies enforcing the same substantive law? You said no.

I want to get back to that point briefly if we can. In light of that, why would you ever advise against combining the two agencies? Why would you advise against getting rid of the division that we have here?

SIMONS: I haven't thought about that.

LEE: Mr. Delrahim?

DELRAHIM: Again, as an administration official, I don't have an administration position but I don't see that we would object as far as looking at that and possibly that'd be a good solution going forward.

SIMONS: Well one thing--one thing I do have to say is we have some characteristics of the Federal Trade Commission that are kind of unique and I think are very helpful.

LEE: Sure. and you have authority that extends outside of antitrust law.

SIMONS: Yeah, and so that might not say that you should only have one but if you were only going to have one you might want to have one with those qualities. In other words, if you're just going to have one agency, you might want to have one that looked more like the FTC than the Justice Department.

LEE: Right, that is probably a conversation reserved--

SIMONS: I reserve the right to object, senator, right.

LEE: Well said, I mean, each has some characteristics that the other one doesn't have. The Department of Justice has other tools that you don't have. You have a few tools that they don't have. So I get your point but thank you both for your candor on that point. Mr. Delrahim, the--the ASCAP and BMI consent decrees have been around for many decades and there is a lot of course that's changed in the music industry since then in terms of the way people experience music. But that doesn't answer the question of what--what has changed in the music industry on the licensing site itself that suggests that the consent decrees may no longer be needed.

DELRAHIM: Senator, it's a great question and it is not lost on us as far as the established reliance and the models that have been created around that. So there have been a couple of recent changes we've had some new Performing Rights organizations that have occurred in the last couple of year, that's a few years. We also have had a recent Second Circuit opinion dealing with fractional ownership and fractional licensing that has created some changes in that whole industry.

We have made no decisions. We have recently as you well know and we informed you before we took any of these steps is that we put it out for notice and comment. From the public, we've received over 800 comments, we've made those public on our website, I think a week or so ago and now, we're in the process of taking a look to see, do those consent decrees. Are they actually serving as an--as an anti--in an anti-competitive matter to prevent new innovation or new licensing? One, two, does it make sense for the Antitrust Division to continue to be the regulator in this market again. The free market has not has not ruled as far as those. There's been a thumb on the scale with respect to the licensing and licensing rates.

No question, it has provided some certainty within the marketplace given how many licensees there are. The number of radio stations, funeral homes, bowling alleys, hotel owners and--and such. And we are considering all of those. We will be in touch with the committee with this subcommittee and particularly knowing your interest in this and the direction and the music modernization act to communicate any direction we go in this area whether or not it needs to be modified, it needs to be sunset or to do absolutely nothing and I think we owe it to the public to examine that.

LEE: Is there anything you can tell us about the timing of your review?

DELRAHIM: We have not. So as I mentioned, we received the public comments, our staff who are the experts in our media and entertainment section are--are looking at it. They have not made any recommendations, they're tabulating the different comments that we have. As you can imagine, where you're drawing lines in the sand different interest within the industry have different points of view, so there's not one cohesive point of view but we have not.

So no my guess is that within the next three to six months, we will have formulated some viewpoints. At least, we have analyzed the comments and at that time be delighted to share that with you.

LEE: Thank you. Thank you, that's helpful.

DELRAHIM: Sure.

LEE: I know you're both recuse from the Qualcomm matter. So I'm not going to ask you to--one of you to comment on the core merits or the theories behind those case but I--I think this case some of what has happened here illustrates the confusion and the wasted resources that can result when your two agencies don't see eye to eye.

Now, I want to make one thing very, very clear here. I'm not--I'm not expressing frustration over the fact that you don't always see eye to eye; government agencies are not omniscient, they're not omnipotent, they're run by mortal human beings.

Mortal human beings, sometimes, we'll look at the same close issue of law and reach different conclusions. I'm not saying that it's wrong that you've reached different conclusions. I'm saying that it's weird that we have a system set up that pits you against each other because stuff like this is inevitable. Frankly, I--as long as we're talking about things that are--are--are either mortal or immortal or fallible or not, it's nothing short of miraculous that you haven't had more of these instances in the past but I think it is--it would be an act of denial to suggest this is going to be an aberration.

SIMONS: I think these stem from the same thing that you're--you're thinking about. So one is Qualcomm and one is the friend issue and I think it's the same view about intellectual property that causes the division with respect to both. So it's really those two are manifold and maybe pay-for-delay as well. Those--those things are manifestations of the--the same difference of opinion.

LEE: No, I get that, I get that. But getting back to what I was saying earlier, one of my colleagues during--during questions suggested that, you know, somehow I was talking about the dual sovereign property. That's not my issue. My issue is not that there are two sovereigns involved in the issue the federal government and the state at issue. My concern is that within the federal sovereign we have two kings, two Caesars, two czars, whatever you want to call your agency.

We have two enforcement agencies that are not always going to see eye-to-eye for this or that reason, for perhaps very legitimate reasons. So Mr. Delrahim, before Qualcomm, can you tell me when was the last time that the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice joined the litigation to oppose the position being advanced by the Federal Trade Commission?

DELRAHIM: I am--I don't know if there was. However, I can't tell you in my last tour of duty at the department where I was the deputy for appellant international. We did file separately from another independent agency the Securities Exchange Commission. In the Second Circuit, we had two different views where we did not believe that unless there's a repugnant conflict between the two regimes, there should be an implied immunity from the antitrust laws.

The Securities Exchange Commission at the time took a different view, the Solicitor General agreed with our point of view and we filed two separate briefs in the Second Circuit. I also--

LEE: Yeah, that's messed up but--

DELRAHIM: It is. I also know that again, back then, when there was the viewpoint also from the Federal Trade Commission that came to the division in the--I believe the Schering-Plough case where I belief it was the Sixth Circuit or the Eighth Circuit where they had--the Federal Trade Commission had lost on a theory that the department did not agree with and they have certain authority to independent litigate in the Supreme Court came to the division, the Solicitor General and the Antitrust Division did not agree with that theory of per se law, you know, the illegality of certain paper delays when it was within the term of the patent and the FTC went up, then the of course the Chief Justice was not unfamiliar with the solicitor's office asked for the cert worthiness view of the Solicitor General and they took an opposite position with the Supreme Court in that same case.

So it has happened, it's unfortunate. I think we--we do our best to avoid that whenever we can but those are--those are important politics. I should also note, it's not just FTC and DOJ, you know, perhaps in the Qualcomm case with the--and the FTC there's there appeared to be at least publicly different viewpoints amongst the commissioners. So, you know, there is dissent but it's not just necessarily just the two agencies.

LEE: Sure, sure. And within the FTC they do have rules that determine when the Commission is taking a position and when it isn't in the absence of unanimity. You want to identify in other instances like that?

SIMONS: No, the only--the only one I was thinking of was the Schering-Plough one. That's the only one I'm aware of.

LEE: So I--I again I want to emphasize the problem is not that these things happen the problem is that they can happen and the fact that they do sometimes happen with other agencies between other agencies other than your two doesn't make it any more acceptable here and that is and ought to be a concern especially in something like antitrust, whereas the civil enforcement agencies for antitrust laws, you have to investigate, you have to reach a conclusion and where you have even the possibility of multiple investigations involving the same conduct, the same actor or actors, the same substantive law, you've got this almost unavoidable opportunity for conflict. It really undermines either agency's ability to do what it needs to do. Senator Blumenthal.

DELRAHIM: Mr. Chairman, can I just make two quick points for the record so the records can reflect this? First is Senator Whitehouse had asked any instances where there's been collusive activity, where there's been a state actor in North Pennington and there's the case of ally tube (SP) at the Supreme Court is an important one where there was collusive activity this was about standards for, you know, different types of tube to be used. There was state--

LEE: Tell me about one that was--with you--it's okay if you don't remember.

DELRAHIM: I do not remember. I want to say in the late 70s--

LEE: Like 1980.

DELRAHIM: When was that?

LEE: It was like 1980.

DELRAHIM: Yeah, so it was 80 when it was decided by the Supreme Court where the defense of North Pennington because there was a state actor there was advanced and Supreme Court rejected that. So that's one. The other is that you had asked a question about, you know, kind of the tech agencies and the--and the expertise and I agree with the Chairman why it's important to have that in each agency and--and commend them for creating the technology task force and I just wanted to let the record reflect and for you to know that the division has had what used to be called Network and Technology section.

Senator Blumenthal will know because that's the section that brought the Microsoft case almost 20 years ago and that--they--they were the ones that have continued their activity in this industry and they're the ones who are engaged in--in our current inquiry in the tech industry and it continues to be an important element because they continue to build expertise in that.

Thank you, that's helpful. Senator Blumenthal.

BLUMENTHAL: Let me ask you about that group within your division. Does it actively and regularly consult with the tech task force that operates within the FTC?

DELRAHIM: That's a good question. I think the instructions have been in the areas. So I do know that in one of the matters that were involved with that is public and Google, we have been in touch with the FTC as, you know, the FTC in 2000 belief 11 and then 15 had had investigations in Google, they had certain not only documents but expertise that we could benefit from and there has been communication to coordinate on that and I believe that we intend to do that as we do with all the state AG's. Wouldn't it make sense doesn't it make sense for there to be an active and regular protocol of consultation if you're both investigating the same company.

I mean, it's fine for the two of you to express your intent to cooperate but as a practical matter, as we all know, as law enforcers, what really matters is the staff and the investigators and the economists and the people on the ground, getting evidence in your FTC investigation as we discussed earlier, you have evidence that is highly relevant to Facebook's potential use of user information that stifles competition or consolidates and increases its monopolistic power which could be relevant to what your investigation may concern.

DELRAHIM: Absolutely, I think it makes perfect sense. We do a lot of that. There's a number of matters where we do, you know, as I mentioned before, the safe landings, there's a lot that we do jointly to try to increase each other's capacity to be better enforcers.

LEE: Now, that happens a lot different areas as well. not just tech.

BLUMENTHAL: Thank you, Mr. Chair, yeah, that's good to hear. Let me ask you coming back to the health care issue, we talked earlier about GPOs. I'm very concerned that mergers in the pharmaceutical industry and the potential impacts of those mergers on competition, innovation prices, I apologize if you covered this ground already.

Participants in the pharmaceutical supply chain including manufacturers and PBMs are known to engage in behaviors essentially designed for close competition. One form of competitive behavior is called a rebate wall or a rebate trap which allows manufacturers to leverage patient volume to block a competitor's access to formulary.

I know this areas somewhat complicated I'm not going to try to go into the details because we're late in the day. But it's detrimental to low-cost brand drug biosimilar access and it can have detrimental impacts on patients who could be benefiting from life-saving drugs and treatments, In fact, biosimilars which are extremely expensive to develop compared to other types of drug has struggled to take off in the U.S. market because of those rebate traps and other exclusionary predatory practices by large pharmaceutical companies.

Those practices are designed to maintain their market share. I'm not going to repeat the exhortation that I did earlier today. But Americans are looking for you to do everything possible--both of you in reducing health care costs at every level; employers, businesses, patients. What is the FTC doing to address the practice of rebate traps and similar behaviors?

SIMONS: Yes, in our health care shop is focused on health care and this is one of the things that they're--they're thinking about. So if this is--this is the type of thing that you're talking about market foreclosure particularly with firms that might have significant market power. This is, you know, this is the--this is the type of thing that we--that we should be looking at and are looking at.

BLUMENTHAL: I know you're not going to tell me whether you have specific companies under investigation but do you have an active investigation concerning rebate traps or rebate walls?

SIMONS: I'd have to check on that.

BLUMENTHAL: Could you get back to me about that?

SIMONS: Yes.

BLUMENTHAL: Thank you. And on September 12th as you may know, a number of consumer groups wrote a letter expressing concern about the Allergan (SP) have you--merger. One of their concerns if this acquisition is consummated is that the merge firm will have an increased ability to bundle rebates. Are you familiar with the letter and, you know, this pract--possibility concern you?

SIMONS: I haven't seen the letter and sorry, I'm in the dark a little bit about exactly what it says. But it certainly we'll--we'll take a--take a good look at it.

BLUMENTHAL: And would you perhaps get back to me in writing about your response to the letter as well?

SIMONS: Sure, I mean but you just keep in mind that again it's a non-public investigation so we couldn't provide you details about what we're doing right in the context of that.

BLUMENTHAL: Okay, thank you both.

DELRAHIM: Just to--related to that senator, and--and your state should be commended for its leadership in the generic pharmaceutical criminal matter that we have and that's an area where, you know, the Federal Trade Commission has great expertise in the pharmaceutical area. There's been price-fixing, we've had three guilty pleas, we had a deferred prosecution agreement that we entered into due to some complications at HHS where had we indicted the company, they would have had to be necessarily excluded from a number of federal programs. So instead of eliminating competition, we chose to do that and stay tuned, there's going to be several others coming up.

BLUMENTHAL: That is--I'm delighted to hear it. Maybe you can also tell me and I--I join you in commending our present Attorney General for his aggressive pursuit of those criminal and civil potential antitrust violations in the generic market and it makes me miss my old days as attorney general. But can you tell me whether the Department of Justice has an active investigation concerning opioid manufacturers?

DELRAHIM: It's not--I can't say anything about the with respect to the Antitrust Division or outside of the Antitrust Division. I can say there have been a number of actions on the both of the civil side as well as others but I'll--I can get back to you broadly from the department's activities in that area.

BLUMENTHAL: I'd appreciate that, thank you both for being here today and for your testimony. Thank you.

DELRAHIM: Thank you.

LEE: Next Tuesday, the subcommittee will be holding another hearing which we'll look at the acquisition--the--look at acquisitions are of nascent or potential competitors by digital platforms. As you both know, many platform markets are somewhat subject to tipping, meaning that the that the firm ends up gaining power, gaining the upper hand, early on often has very significant durable market power.

Mr. Delrahim, in your opinion, is--is legislation needed to address this issue or can the agencies already manage this issue through their enforcement of the Clayton or Sherman Act?

DELRAHIM: Senator, I believe that the guidelines the horizontal merger guidelines could address some of these issues where a company has significant market share and is trying to acquire that. We have recently filed a case in Delaware against Sabre who is a crime--acquiring Farelogix with exactly that theory or some variations of that, we'll let you know how that pairs out.

I think the current laws, you know, in a I--I think with the right theory and the right set of facts a current laws should be able to address that if there is in fact a pattern of acquisition in order to kill what could be the competitor as a violation of the section two.

LEE: You agree with that Mr. Simons?

SIMONS: Yes. And another thing--another thing--

LEE: Hit the button.

SIMONS: Sorry, and yes and another thing that we're looking at is the use of section two, monopoly maintenance claims to go after acquisition programs of nascent competitors because we think in that sense, the--the burden on the plaintiff to show harm is less and so we think that might be a very advantageous Avenue.

LEE: I want to thank both of you for coming here today and for your patience well we had to go and vote. I especially want to thank you for your service to our country and within your respective agencies and the thoroughness with which you undertake your job, the seriousness with which you take them. Our record for today will remain open for two weeks. We stand adjourned.

Senate Judiciary Subcommittee On Antitrust, Competition Policy And Consumer Rights Holds Hearing On Competition In Digital Technology Markets

September 24, 2019 02:30 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UTAH), CHAIRMAN

SEN. CHARLES E. GRASSLEY (R-IOWA)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

SEN. MICHAEL D. CRAPO (R-IDAHO)

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TENN.)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-S.C.), EX-OFFICIO

SEN. AMY KLOBUCHAR (D-MINN.), RANKING MEMBER

SEN. PATRICK J. LEAHY (D-VT.)

SEN. RICHARD BLUMENTHAL (D-CONN.)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-N.J.)

SEN. DIANNE FEINSTEIN (D-CALIF.), EX-OFFICIO

[*]LEE: Welcome to this hearing of the subcommittee of the Antitrust Consumer Policy--Competition Policy and Consumer Rights. Today, we're pleased to have with us four distinguished witnesses to testify about digital platform acquisitions of nascent competitors. Well, we appreciate your taking the tie today and to come and share your wisdom with us. There's a bit of feeding frenzy these days, when it comes to antitrust in the world of big tech. And while I'm encouraged that the FTC and the DoJ are investigating in whether the tech giants have violated antitrust laws, I'm also concerned that we might overshoot the mark in our efforts to reign in those firms. One area where it's critical that we get the balance right is in the context of tech mergers, especially in acquisitions of nascent, or potential competitors by digital platforms.

Clearly, we wanna ensure that the competition is not harmed in tech markets to that we can all enjoy the benefits of innovation and consumer choice, two things that have come to distinguish this sector of our economy. Platform markets are prone to tipping, which can lead to durable market power and to barriers on entry. So, acquisitions by dominant platforms that gobble up would-be rivals to eliminate them before they can pose a competitive threat should be prevented and should be something that we're concerned about. At the same time, we also need to recognize that sorting out the problematic acquisitions from the beneficial ones may not always be an easy task.

If we restrict tech mergers too much and prevent pro-competitive acquisitions, then we run the risk of potentially harming the startup ecosystem that fuels many of the consumer innovations that we enjoy today that have occurred in this industry. I look forward to discussing how to balance those two competing interests, today. Before we get started, let me say a few words about the Oversight Hearing we held last week, with the Heads of the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice's Antitrust Division. They both confirmed what I've long believed, which is that it makes no sense, no sense at all to split civil antitrust enforcement between two federal agencies.

Once more, they've both confirmed that it would be wasteful for each agency to investigate the same conduct, by the same firm, under the same subset standard of law. Nevertheless, our federal antitrust agencies seem intent on dividing monopolization investigations, on the same tech companies and between themselves. When he was here last week. Mr. Delrahim, who of course heads the Department of Justice's Antitrust Division suggested that the DOJ and FTC can split up a monopolization investigation of the same company, so long as each agency looks at different conduct.

But as I said at the time, there's no analytical basis for splitting up a monopolization investigation. Despite Mr. Delrahim suggestion to the contrary, you just cannot run a monopolization investigation piecemeal, it doesn't work. It wouldn't make sense to have the FTC looking into whether a platform used a series of acquisitions to maintain market power, while the DoJ was simultaneously looking into whether that same firm had exploited data in some way, to exclude rivals. It's all the same offense.

You have to look at the totality of the company's efforts in attaining or maintain market power. So, you don't split up this exercise between two agencies and yet, that's exactly what existing law does. I know the antitrust agencies are working with limited resources. I also know that they have a lot on their plates and that they're working hard and in good faith. So, I--I expect that they'll use their resources to ensure that we have the most effective and efficient civil antitrust enforcement possible. This means we should not see both agencies wasting taxpayer money by carrying on with the same investigation of the same company at the same time, under the same substantive standards of federal law. Senator Klobuchar will now give her opening statement.

KLOBUCHAR: Thank you very much Mr. Chairman. Good afternoon to our witnesses and welcome, thank you for coming to this very timely hearing. As I mentioned at the hearing last week, America truly has a monopoly problem. We know the statistics, we know that--the effect that it's having, I actually started my day today with Senator Scott, we formed this entrepreneurship caucus and we had 20 women entrepreneur startups and we are now experiencing what we call the "startup slump" in that we are at a--a record low number of startups in decades. And as I said to them, today, there are many reasons for that but one of them I believe is that we have too much monopolization, and it's too hard to get into these markets.

One study the non-partisan Brookings Institution observed a broad base decline in startup rates going back to 1979. Another study found a 26 percent decrease in new business formation from 2006 to 2015. The American people know that competition is key to the health of our markets, and if we want to build the next great new American company, we have to allow those ideas to take seed. And what I'm really concerned about is that it's getting harder and harder to do that. It's clear that much of the recent interest in competition issues comes from legitimate concerns about the major online platforms. This is no surprise because of the technical world we are living in, and it makes sense that these digital platforms are receiving so much attention.

They are with us from the moment that we wake up in the morning to when we fall asleep at night. And all of us are hearing stories about some--of how some of the companies are treating users, business partners and the handful of competitors that are still independent. For instance, just yesterday the Wall Street Journal published an article about Snap's 'Project Voldemort' dossier on aggressive tactics that Facebook has used against its rivals, and that's just one of the many signs of the ever-increasing dominance of these digital platforms is threatening competition. I am encouraged that this investigation is starting with the FTC and the Justice Department, I am not nearly as concerned as my colleague as I pointed out last week, about how the pie is separated. As I said last week, I'm more concerned the consumers are gonna end up with a pie in their face if we don't start taking action soon.

So, much of our discussion is focused on of course, big mergers in this committee, and given the limited resources compared to these sophisticated companies a lot of the Justice Department and FTC research and resources are going into these big deals: T-Mobile-Sprint, AB InBev Comcast-NBC Universal we just--I just commented on some pharmaceutical mergers and that's understandable because when a big deal is anti-competitive, it has big consequences. But as we're gonna talk about today, maybe these acquisitions that we're talking about aren't the most valuable in terms of dollars, because the acquisition targets are usually smaller companies or startups.

Some are small enough to avoid federal merger filling requirements all together, so the agencies aren't even notified that it happens. But make moment--no mistake, if digital giants use strategic acquisitions to snuff out emerging or potential future competitor, the harm may not be as immediately obvious, but those harms are no less damaging or enduring in the long run. A recent white paper issued by Dr. Moss indicated that the five most valuable tech firms: Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Facebook have completed more than 700 acquisitions since 1987, and looking back, some of these deals raise significant concerns. It's easy to say that these deals are only troubling in hindsight and that the agencies could not have predicated what would happen when they looked at these mergers.

But for many of these acquisitions industry observers raised concerns right away. That was true for Facebook, Instagram and Google Waze and Google AdMob and others. When Google bought DoubleClick, former Commissioner Harbour dissented from the FTC's decision to close its investigation without taking action, laying out alternative predications about how the acquisition would harm competition. Looking back, we know she was right. And digital platforms continue to buy startups. Just yesterday news broke that Facebook is looking to buy CTRL-labs, a startup that is developing an arm-worn device to read brain signals.

This will likely be merged with the ongoing work of Facebook's Reality Labs division on brain input devices. We expect the agencies would look at this kind of deal and others like it, and I think they should be looking backwards and retroactivity at some of the deals that have already been made. As a former prosecutor, I appreciate the difficulty in weighing the evidence, and building a case that can win, under the circumstances that we are in, with a conservative court and with limited resources. But as a lawmaker with oversight responsibility for antitrust enforcement, I have questions about the enforcement agency's ability to assess the likely competitive impact of these types of acquisitions, the adequacy of the legal tools available and how agencies can, as I mentioned, look back at prior deals.

In an area of antitrust where there will always be uncertainty, I strongly urge the agencies to err on the side of protecting competition, especially when dealing with dominant digital platforms. I have some bills on this, I'm not gonna go through them again, but they involve more resource, they involve changing some of the standards when we look at some of these deals and also deterring monopolies, a bill that I recently introduced with Senator Blumenthal which would grant the antitrust agencies the power to seek serious civil fines from monopolization offenses, including those involving acquisitions that would create or maintain a monopoly.

Finally, we need to discuss whether additional legal presumptions might be effective in preventing harmful acquisitions by digital platforms. We should also of course, talk about these retrospective merger reviews, taking a look back in time may reveal merger effects that were not apparent before closing. Although concerns with big tech go beyond competition into privacy election security bills that I have near and dear to my heart, effective antitrust enforcement has a crucial role to play. Competition lowers prices, improves quality and spurs innovation. That is why the competition enforcement is so critical to the future of the digital sector. Open competitive markets are what allowed these digital platforms to grow and to thrive. We must ensure that the next generation of American technology firms have the same opportunities. I look forward to your testimony and Mr. Chair, the subcommittee has received letters on the topic of today's hearing from consumer reports of Spiegel Center at the University of Chicago, (INAUDIBLE) and the Electronic Privacy Information Center, and I would like to submit them into the record.

LEE: Without objection. Thank you, Senator, Klobuchar.

KLOBUCHAR: Thank you.

LEE: I'm now pleased to introduce our witnesses. Bruce Hoffman is the Director of the Bureau of Competition of the Federal Trade Commission. Before joining the FTC, Mr. Hoffman held leadership positions in the antitrust practices of two well-known global law firms in--earlier in his career, he served as Deputy Director and Associate Director of The FTC's Bureau of Competition. Diana Moss serves as the president of the American Antitrust institute. Before joining the AAI, Moss was the--was at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, where she coordinated the agency's competition analysis for electricity mergers. She's also consulted in private practice in the areas of regulation and antitrust. John M. Yun is an Associate Professor of Law, and Director of Economic Education at the Global Antitrust Institute, at George Mason University Antonin Scalia Law school. Prior to joining the Global Antitrust institute, Mr. Yun served as Acting Deputy Director in the FTC's Bureau of Economics.

Patricia Nakache is the General Partner at Trinity Ventures in Silicon Valley. Her work focuses on consumer and business technology startups. She serves on the Board of The Natural (SP)--National Venture Capital Association and also as a lecturer in management at the Stanford Graduate School of Business, where she teaches Startup Garage. Prior to joining Trinity Ventures, Miss Nakache worked for McKinsey & Company. We'll start with you Mr. Hoffman and go down the list in the order we introduced you.

HOFFMAN: Chairman Lee, Ranking Member Klobuchar, members of the subcommittee, thank you for the opportunity to be here before you today. I'm pleased to testify on behalf of the commission about our enforcement approach to acquisitions of nascent and potential competitors by digital platforms. Let me start by nothing that the written statements submitted for this hearing represents the views of the Federal Trade Commission, but my oral statement and answers to questions today represent only my own views and not necessity the views of the Federal Trade Commission or any commissioner.

As everyone I think is well aware, we in terms of both the United Stets economy and the world economy are in a period of huge innovation, huge change and huge--huge disruption. But I think it's also clear that that does not prevent anti-competitive conduct and mere change, mere innovation are not enough. And in fact, the Microsoft case showed us 20 years ago in a period of similar change and similar ferment in the economy that dominant firms can identify, target and attempt to extinguish developing threats, even very early in the development of those threats. We are alert to that as for example our recent monopolization case against Surescripts shows. Surescripts we allege is a digital platform in the e-prescription space, which engaged in similar conduct aimed at stifling nascent competition and we have brought a suit against them.

The hearing today focuses on one potential form of anti-competitive conduct, which is acquisitions of nascent or potential competitors by dominant firms. Let me start by saying that this is a completely viable theory of anti-competitive harm. Buying a rival is one way of killing a rival, potentially. We share the concern that has been expressed, that is embodied in the statement of--that's articulated in this hearing and we had taken action. We actually have several pending investigations in different markets looking at nascent or potential competition issues. We recently won a trial in a case called Ottobock and Freedom Innovations involving an acquisition by a dominant firm of a competitor that was largely nascent, existing competitor, but very small where the competitive concern was more about the future than the present or the past.

Last year, in the digital platform space, we blocked the dominant platform CDK's acquisition of its rival Auto/Mate, this was in dominant platforms for applications for car dealerships. We brought a litigation challenge against that merger, which was abandoned, as a result of our action. As laid out in our prepared testimony, the commission is committed to promote--devoting our resources to this area. This year, we formed the Technology Task Force, which is designed to marshal resources and expertise from across the commission to deal with this issue and others that are related to it, and that group is actively conducting investigations as we speak.

Let me close by identifying I think three important issues to consider as discuss these topics. Number one, as I think was identified in both statements, every acquisition of a startup by an incumbent is not necessarily bad, nor is it good. Both things are possible acquisitions of startups can involve the acquisition of compliments, of services that are brought more quickly or better to market than would otherwise be the case, or it could involve eliminating competitive threats. The key is, what are the specific facts in the specific transaction?

Second, even for past acquisitions, it's not also easy to tell if they were pro or anti-competitive. We have been told that acquisitions that resulted in the product that was acquired not coming to market were anti-competitive because it didn't come to market. We're also told that acquisitions that resulted in the product that was bought coming to market faster or better than it otherwise would have were anti-competitive because they had that result. Both of those things could be true, or neither could be true. It depends again on the particular facts, merger review is a very fact-specific exercise. Third, and in some respects maybe more importantly, it's important to note that our ability to review these kinds of transactions often depends on help form the public.

The HSR Act allows us to review certain kinds of transactions before they're consummated. It covers a lot, but it does not cover every (INAUDIBLE). We scrutinize markets carefully to look for transactions that are otherwise not reportable, but we don't find everything, and we ask for the public's help in finding them, and we get it. The Ottobock case that I mentioned before was brought to us by the public. People identified and we sued and as I said, we recently won that case in trial. We take this very seriously, but we do need help. Thank you again for this opportunity to share our reviews of these important issues. We look forward to continue to work with the subcommittee and Congress, and I'd be happy to answer questions.

LEE: Thank you. Dr. Moss?

MOSS: Thank you Chairman Lee, Ranking Member Klobuchar, and members of the subcommittee, it's an honor to be here today. The large digital market players maintain broad ecosystem of business to consumer and business to business markets. Many of these comprised platforms, or sets of technologies upon which other technologies and applications interoperate. The growth of these firms is a function of several factors, including winner take all, organic growth, and expansion through acquisition. AAI recently analyzed merger enforcement data for the digital sector and concluded that the agency's record has been extraordinarily weak.

Big tech made over 700 transactions over the last 20--32 years, the history of which involves large swaths of serial acquisition in advertising, business analytics, big data, artificial intelligence, Cloud computing e-commerce enterprise software and IT. Between 2001 and 20--2018, about 240 deals in a major category of big tech were reportable to the agencies, less than 20 percent of which were cleared to either the FTC or the DoJ. This mean that while the rate of second requests is on average higher than across all sectors, the challenge rate for big tech deals is far lower than across all sectors.

This record may indicate that the agencies are either not finding that transactions raise concerns, or they are not comfortable challenging them. Several factors probably explain this weak enforcement record. Digital players may be strategically pursuing deals that fly under the antitrust radar. History tells us that the agencies are hesitant to challenge deals where they weigh the cost of blocking benign deals, more heavily that the costs of allowing harmful deals. It's also possible that enforcers perceive that they have inadequate tools to assess complex mergers. But we know that the consumer welfare standard can address the myriad issue such as zero price, multisided markets and non-price dimensions of competition.

This is evident from investigations into Google DoubleClick, Google AdMeld and Google ITA. In other words, enforcers appear to have the tools they need, they just need to use them. More troubling is the idea that weak enforcement in the digital sector results from the fact that many competitive concerns are cognizable under antitrust law, but they may not be reachable in practice because evidentiary standards are too high to address unique features of the platforms.

This includes the interconnected ecosystems of markets and the durable competitive advantage of the platforms. This is compounded, this problem is compounded by antitrust focus on narrow markets, one acquisition at a time which collectively miss the longer-term effects of serial acquisitions on raising market concentration. I wanna emphasize that antitrust is the lead tool for addressing competition concerns but it is not well-suited to address broader social policy concerns that have originated--that have arisen in the digital sector. Moreover, antitrust is not designed to be used as a vehicle for implementing industrial policy, such as comprehensive breakups that are not well-founded or based on identified competitive harms.

Using antitrust in these ways can stymie enforcement at a time when we need to strengthen it, clarify it and invigorate it. That means that antitrust should serve as--as the tip of the spearhead, in a--in a policy portfolio approach for the digital sector that includes other complementary policy tools, such as social regulation for addressing systemic privacy breeches, access and interoperability standards to promote switching and consumer choice.

So, what can we do to strengthen merger enforcement in the--in the digital sector? First, we need stronger presumptions. This includes new presumptions for acquisitions and potential competitors that lower evidentiary standards and shift burdens to acquiring firms. We need new vertical presumption that focus on high concentration and vertical foreclosure. And we need the rigorous application of the existing structural presumption in highly concentrative mergers. Second, we need to ramp up retrospective analysis of mergers. If there is evidence of post-merger harm, the agencies should use their authority to challenge consummated deals.

Third, improved agency transparency is vital through press releases and closing statements. Finally, I would suggest a blue-ribbon committee should be formed and tasked with evaluating the need for possible new digital markets legislation. The committee would consider goals and parameters and proposals, including an independent regulatory oversight authority and how that authority would collaborate with antitrust enforcers to advise on technical matters that affect the agency's competition mandate. In sum, it is time to address the weak record of merger enforcement in the digital sector, with tractable and sensible policy proposals that will gain bipartisan support from our competition, protect consumers and stimulate innovation. Thank you and I look forward to your questions.

LEE: Thank you. Professor Yun?

YUN: Chairman Lee, Ranking Member Klobuchar, and members of the subcommittee, thank you very much for offering me the opportunity and privilege to appear before you here, today. I just wanna spend the first few moments just clarifying the concepts of nascent and potential competitors, simply because these are often used conjunctively but they are--they mean two separate things. Generally speaking, potential competition is a product that does not yet exist but is predicted to exist or could exist very quickly. Thus, it's really a forecast about entry or the potential for entry.

Whereas nascent competition is about a product or technology that exists gut has not fully matured into a significant competitor, whether within or outside the same relevant product market. Like potential competition, nascent competition can be a forecast of entry reposition or expansion, but it also involves a forecast of future differentiation or development of a product or technology and its level of market success. In order to understand both concepts, we must understand the proper counterfactual. For instance, what if Google did not purchase YouTube, what would these products look like today? Would consumers be better off?

Given the nature of the exercise, they'll always be some degree of uncertainly and we can never actually observe the counterfactual. For example, let's--let's look at Facebook's acquisition of Instagram in 2012. At the time of the purchase, Instagram had zero revenues and a handful of employees. Since that time, Instagram has grown from 30 million users to well over 1 billion. During the same period Facebook group formed approximately 900 million to over 2 billion users. This substantial expansion in output in users in a relatively short period of time is the complete opposite of what we would normally consider a anticompetitive outcome.

Importantly, the success of big tech platforms is not guaranteed. We don't have to look any further than Google Plus, which launched in 2011, with the support of 1,000 Google engineers. In 2019, Google Plus was perhaps mercifully shut down. Consumers clearly voted with their feet or eyeballs and directed their attention to other products and platforms. The Google Plus example illustrates the difficult in making predictions about market success and projecting future competitive effects. As the great Yogi Berra once allegedly said, "Predications are hard, especially about the future." Clearly, the acquisition of a potential or nascent competitor can result in an outcome that is harmful to consumers and innovation, yet it can also unlock a great deal of value as well.

Based on the current evidence and scholarship, I believe the U.S. Federal Antitrust Laws and the enforcement of those laws are sufficient and effective. The doctrines of potential and nascent competition are well-developed and were actually first developed by the US Antitrust authorities. The agency should and must continue to vigorously enforce the antitrust laws. As a society, we want technology companies both large and small to behave properly and to innovate within the bounds of conducts that's based on the merit, rather than on the ability to control the market, keep competitors out and lower consumer welfare.

Are there things we can and should do right now? I believe there are three potential options that are worthy of your consideration. First, in our increasingly data-driven world, I believe that more economists should be hired at the agencies, in expertise such as machine learning, econometrics, labor and finance. Second, I believe the FTC should seriously consider exercising their 6(b) authority and looking at past acquisitions and examining whether there were good or bad for consumers.

Finally, I would advocate for greater transparency to the public and to policy makers, for all major policy decisions from the agency, including decisions to close without action or with consent, just to give greater transparency to the public. Thank you for your time, and I look forward to today's discussion.

LEE: Thank you. Professor Nakache.

NAKACHE: Chairman Lee, Ranking Member Klobuchar, members of the subcommittee, thank you for the opportunity to testify today. My name is Patricia Nakache, and I serve as a general partner at Trinity Ventures, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, California. As an investor, I partner with world class technology entrepreneurs who are building innovative products and services for the American public. I also serve on the Board of The National Venture Capital Association and am testifying in that behalf. VC backed companies have had an outside positive impact on the economy. One academic study found that 42 percent of all US company IPOs from 1974 to 2015 were venture-backed and those companies accounted for 85 percent of all R&D spending and 63 percent of the total market capitalization of public companies formed since 1974.

When VCs like myself are evaluating whether to invest in a startup looking to compete directly against a large incumbent, we consider a number of factors. These include whether the founder has a unique and important insight into the market and is developing a differentiated product or service, whether she has crafted a marketing and sales strategy that will enable her to grow--grow with the company quickly and whether the leadership team of the startup can execute nimbly against larger competitors. Startups building products that serve customers only marginally better than large incumbents will likely find it challenging to secure a VC investment. Similarity, startups building superior products but competing in markets for incumbents are nimble and deep pocketed may also find it difficult to secure VC investment.

I have been asked to speak to the views of the venture capital industry, as policy makers consider whether and how to apply our antitrust laws to large digital platforms. There are diverse views about this topic in the VC industry. It should come as no surprise, given that venture capital firms are partnership composed of individuals with varying professional experience and perspectives. Certainly, on the one hand, there have been some venture capitals that have grown frustrated by practices of large tech companies that can have an outsized negative impact on startups. For example, through periodic changes to their algorithms, large technology companies that have significant consumer reach can dramatically affect, overnight the traffic flowing to startup websites and mobile apps.

And this is a--related to the article that Ranking Member Klobuchar was--was referring to regarding Snap today. At the same time, other venture capitalists believe the startup ecosystem benefits in many ways from large technology incumbents. For example, these VCs point out startups often view larger companies as potential customers and distribution channels and that talented employees at these incumbents often go off to start their own companies and pursue their entrepreneurial dream. And of course, M&A activity has always been an important avenue for liquidity, for risk-taking entrepreneurs and investors and has become even more so in recent years, with technology incumbents the most active acquirers of tech startups.

Venture capitalists are not necessarily one or the other of the two camps I have described. In my experience, the vast majority of venture capitalists see both sides of this argument. We are passionate about the startups we invest in and want them to get a fair shake in the marketplaces they take on incredible challenges. At the same time, we recognize the large incumbents are adjacent to startups in the tech ecosystem and that action taken against these companies could have adverse and unforeseen consequences for young companies. In examining this area, it's important to understand that many young companies cannot realistically achieve the scale necessary to become standalone public companies.
