Furthermore, the public markets are not nearly as welcoming of small companies as they once were, and the result, there are now roughly half the number, of the total number of public companies than they were just 20 years ago. This means that often M&A is the most viable pathway for a startup. If the government makes it more challenging for incumbents to acquire these companies, this will have a devastating effect on making it less attractive to launch a new enterprise. The end result will be harm to the American innovation economy. In the majority of acquisitions, the larger competitor is seeking to acquire a startup to complement existing business or offer new services to their customer base.

It is likely a ministry of cases where an incumbent is engaging in the acquisition to directly stifle a future competitor. Furthermore, at times small competitors will merge in an effort to take on a larger competitor, and it's important not to stifle that activity either, as these smaller market participants do not have the resources to participate in exhaustive government proceedings. I encourage these policy makers to act deliberately in making changes. I'm very supportive of efforts to improve the IPO market but the reality is, even the best efforts will not open up the IPO markets for smaller companies in the short-term. That means that M&A will remain critical to the startup ecosystem for the foreseeable future. If this option is hampered, investment into startups will suffer and cause a massive drag on innovation and mew company formation. I thank the committee for its attention and will be pleased to answer any questions.

LEE: Thank you very much, we're each gonna begin a series of seven-minute question rounds, with taking turns between Republicans and Democrats. It seems to happen every time we have an Antitrust Subcommittee hearing, the scheduled votes for 3:30 are a series of four votes, which means at some point we will have to recess for a while. I'm not sure exactly when we will have to do it, probably won't have to recess until about 3:40-3:50 or something like that. And that--that could last 45 minutes or an hour, depending on how the procedure unfolds. So, we'll do our best to move forward as quickly as we can. If we're fortunate, maybe there will be some delay in the vote, and we can wrap up the hearing before that happens, it seems unlikely.

Miss Nakache, I'd like to begin with you. You note in your testimony that it's important for law makers, policy makers and antitrust enforcers to strike a proper balance between on the one-hand underenforcement, which has an obvious set of problems, with--with on the other hand overenforcement, each one can create its own set of difficulties when it comes to dealing with acquisition by tech startups. Distinguishing between those acquisitions that are likely to be anti-competitive and those that are likely to be pro-competitive is of course, a difficult task, and it requires one to proceed with--with a certain amount of neutrality and--and neutral objectives in trying to predict the future. But in your line of work, you also make predictions about the likely--the likelihood of success about a particular business, is that right?

NAKACHE: Yes.

LEE: And would you agree that it's an efficient line of business, that is that people don't go into venture capital unless they're reasonably good at predicting outcomes, is that right?

NAKACHE: That would be the hope.

LEE: Even in that circumstance, even in that very efficient industry, where someone's got skin in the game, so-to-speak, money on the line, their own money, and that of a lot of other people behind them, it can be very difficult to predict which companies are likely to succeed, over the long-term and which companies are less likely to succeed.

And you note that--that failure is a fairly common reality within venture capital, and the startup ecosystem as a whole. On average, what can you tell us about the sort of success or fail rate, where they either end up a success making lots of money or on the other hand, eventually having little or no economic value.

NAKACHE: Thank you for your question, Chairman Lee. There is a study by Harvard Business School that indicated that 75 percent of venture baked startups fail. So, the failure rate is quite high. And so, putting incentives in place that maintain the possibility of success with regards to both M&A and IPO are important in order to maintain that balance the incredible risk entrepreneurs are taking on, and the potential failure rate.

LEE: So, when you're--in light of that concern in your written testimony you note if the government is too heavy handed in preventing incumbent firms from acquiring startups, that could harm the innovation economy. Tell us how this works and how that might impact your investors including university endowments, public foundations, and public funds.

NAKACHE: Sure. Our--our investors as you rightly pointed out are a variety of institutions that can range from foundations to endowments funds. And they make asset allocations all the time, and they decide how much of their capital they want to allocate towards venture capital and fostering this innovation economy. They're looking at the returns of venture capital industry relative to those other asset classes, to the extent that action is taken that depresses potential returns in the world of venture capital that would likely drive those investors to seek other asset classes, over time.

LEE: So that--that's a very real--real world consequence of over enforcement. Under enforcement also has its own problems as we're aware of. But, over enforcement is certainly cost-free proposition. I think we can all agree that some acquisitions of nascent rivals might be done for anti-competitive reasons. I think we also should all agree that's difficult, in some cases, to identify which deals should be challenged versus which deals can't. In part, because we can't see the future, and this is what marketplaces are built on. They're built on a certain degree of uncertainty and some people can ascertain that certain better than others. It's very difficult to predict in advance, especially from the vantage point of government enforcement agency, which ones are going to succeed, and which are going to fail. That doesn't excuse the task from the outset, but it does entail some risk.

Dr. Moss has suggested that antitrust enforcers have, perhaps been reluctant to challenge mergers in the digital tech space, perhaps because some of them might be more concerned about wrongfully blocking a good merger, and not sufficiently concerned about the failing to challenge bad mergers. Professor Yun, is this--what's your reaction to this? Do you think the antitrust enforcement agencies have failed to challenge systematically or otherwise what are in fact, anti-competitive acquisitions among tech startups?

YUN: So, my read on the scholarship is that there's no conclusion that there's systematic basis for either, as you mentioned, a false positive or a false negative. In fact, in the merger guidelines it's already built in that weigh the anti-competitive harms more so than the pro-competitive benefits. It's not a one for one. So, there's actually a greater concern for the false negative versus the false positive. The false negative being allowing blocking a pro-competitive merger. False negative is just, or I might have it opposite way around. But, that's the way, there are a cost to these decisions. And so, yeah, my read-on scholarship is that there has been, I've seen no scholarships showing a systemic finding of agency bias either way.

LEE: Mr. Hoffman, have antitrust enforcers been too timid to bring these kinds of cases?

HOFFMAN: Thank you. I think the answer is, I'm not aware of any data that suggests that. Dr. Moss and I talked a little bit about the AAI study. And I want to commend AAI for doing that study. I think it's the kind of work that needs to be done to help us understand the overall landscape. But, as we discussed previously, the concern that we had about the specific study was that the--this is a little technical, but the data set that they looked at actually, for the most part doesn't include filings by the firms that they identify as the big tech firms. So, it's sort of like if you want to study agriculture merger enforcement and you accidentally study airlines.

That said, I think it's the case that we are looking very hard to determine whether or not, for example, in the past missed transactions that may have been anti-competitive. We need to ascertain whether or not there's any kind of systematic error that we're making. I don't of evidence that supports that second proposition right now. As far as specific past transactions, that's something we are always wanting to take a further look at.

LEE: Dr. Moss, I want to give you a chance to respond. We may have to get back to you in a subsequent round for that because I'm over time and I want to stick as closely as we can to our seven-minute rounds. So, I'd encourage my colleagues to do that, as we're approaching the vote.

KLOBUCHAR: Oh. I get the message. But, in a nice segue, I'll ask you to respond, Dr. Moss. And if you could just--you know this hearing was prompted of course by concerns about lack of enforcement action when it comes to these start up purchases. What should the agency be doing and how do you respond to Mr. Hoffman's comment?

MOSS: Thank you for the question. So, to respond to Mr. Hoffman's comment, the AAI study was based on publicly available data through the HSR reports to Congress. We're a non-profit organization, we base all of our analysis on publicly available data.

We looked at NAAI CS code that corresponds directly to the digital technology industry. That code is a primary identifier for Amazon, Facebook, and Google. So, I guess I'm reluctant to accept lock stock and barrel, the criticism of the study, that it's looking at a very small subset or the wrong subset of transactions that are actually related to big tech firms. But the conclusions don't change. There have been over 700 transactions by the big five tech firms. And one of them has been challenged in federal district court.

KLOBUCHAR: Right. And you're talking about things like Facebook, Instagram, Google AdMob, Facebook, WhatsApp, Google Waze, Amazon, Diapers.com. So, what do you think the agency should be doing now to address these skills?

MOSS: I think the agencies have, as I suggested, have--have--there are a number of factors that have contributed to this problem. I think the agencies have the tools. I think they need to think creatively about using their tools. Under the Consumer Welfare Standard, which--which--which seems capable and reachable to the concerns, I do think that the agencies do apply error cost analysis. And I would respectfully disagree with my colleagues that--and there's been empirical research done in error cost analysis, finding that the agencies are reluctant to challenge deals because they fear they are going to stifle or chill competition. So, I think the agencies need a little bit of help--

KLOBUCHAR: --right--

MOSS: --with some strong presumptions.

KLOBUCHAR: Ok. So, part of this is my suggestion on legal change resources. Mr. Hoffman, I was listening to your three things here about good and bad, and acquisitions good and bad. But the last one was help from the public. Would that also include help from our resources, give that this sophistication of these companies, and that your resources have not greatly improved?

HOFFMAN: Thank you, Senator. Yes, it would. I think the fact of the matter is that we are highly resource constrained. We are in a situation at the Federal Trade Commission where, for example, in the last two years, we challenged 42 mergers, we tried, not investigated, tried nine cases comprising over 132 days of trial time in the last two years. That's one out of every five businesses we are in trial. And we have a staff of about 280 people. So, they do all the merger review, all the conduct review, all the policy work. Everything that we do is done by those people. So, you know, we work--

KLOBUCHAR: --have you figured out how many lawyers are in these companies?

HOFFMAN: So, I'll just give you one example. So, last year over the government shutdown, we tried the Qualcomm Case. Now, our trial team going out and tried that case in California, well over 2,000 miles from home while not being paid, faced an adversary with effectively unlimited resources who deployed against us six, I believe, of the best law firms in the world. Who I think collectively outnumbered our team by a ratio of roughly 10 to one. And yet, we won that trial. So, we work really hard.

KLOBUCHAR: Ok.

HOFFMAN: We do the best we can, but we have limits on what we can do.

KLOBUCHAR: So, let me just ask quick, some little rapid fire, here. Should acquire intent be a factor when you look at evidence in assessing the likely impact of acquiring an emerging or potential future competitor?

HOFFMAN: It is absolutely a factor. We ultimately look at capability and likely effect as opposed to intent itself. We look at intent because we think it sheds light on what the actual capabilities and likely effects would be post-merger.

KLOBUCHAR: Ok. Ms. Yun, we've talked about the challenges of predicting possible outcomes when looking at acquisitions. Do you think retrospectives for these types of acquisitions make sense?

YUN: I do. Senator, thank you for your question. For me, that's the only way you can really look back. And I think a number of studies have done in hospitals. That's what really was the genesis for all the success that led up to the FT's win, FTC's wins in the hospital mergers. They were losing eight in a row until, my understanding, is a group of economists did a retroactive study and they were on different hospital mergers. And they developed new tools to assess those mergers, looking at new data. And they were able to come up with new methodologies that has really been, sort of, the drive for all the wins that the FTC has had, in a good way of stopping anti-competitive hospital mergers. And so, I think the same kind done--

KLOBUCHAR: --you have some top picks of the ones that you think they should look at?

YUN: Yeah. I mean, you know, we all have sort of casual observations of things such as Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp. And I'm open to the view that these could go either way. And I'd like to see a detailed study, not only of prior documents, but of the data of what we would expect to happen. Part of the problem is what Mr. Hoffman mentioned, is we don't have a good sense of what we're looking for. If an acquisition by a nascent competitor, a nascent competitor acquisition results in it being quickly snuffed out, you know, do we chalk that up as killer acquisition or is that just a poor product where they just took the engineering talent and it was really going nowhere, so it's largely pro-competitive. Or do we look at Facebook, Instagram where it really took off exponential growth for both companies after the acquisition and say oh those are synergies that we would expect? Or does that mean, oh wow, they could have been a really independent strong competitor and we let that one go through?

KLOBUCHAR: Ok. Dr. Moss, you want to respond?

MOSS: I just want to make one comment based on the research that we did. You know, the big swathes of big serial acquisitions are not in social media, they're not in content and news. They're in areas like--in areas like data analytics, AI, business intelligence, cloud computing. Those are generally b to b types of transactions. All the b to c stuff gets all the media attention and all the public interest. But, all these b to b transactions seem to be flying under the radar screen. But those are the ones--those are the sectors within big tech where we've seen, you know, huge aggression and acquisitions of companies. Those are the ones, in my view, that need to be looked at.

KLOBUCHAR: Mr. Hoffman, think that's right?

HOFFMAN: So, what I would say is two things. One is, I think merger retrospectives are really important. I think it's important to remember though that they're not law enforcement. There's a difference between a retrospective, which looks at an industry across the board and gives us useful information--

KLOBUCHAR: --yes--

HOFFMAN: --going forward and actually look at a--

KLOBUCHAR: --at a transaction.

HOFFMAN: We can do both. And I think one of the things that we have been doing is looking very hard for both. Places where we should do retrospect but also, particular transactions where we have gotten it wrong. And I can't talk about specific investigations, but that is something that we're very cognizant of.

KLOBUCHAR: Alright. Thank you. Thank you to all of you.

LEE: Senator Hawley.

HAWLEY: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

Mr. Hoffman, your boss Chairman Simons was here last week and I think it's safe to say, I express my frustration of what I'm concerned is a pattern of enforcement or lack thereof at the FTC. And I said then, I'll reiterate now, that I'm increasingly concerned about your agency's ability to do its job. I'm concerned about some of the structural issues that the chairman has eluded to. I'm concerned about the pattern that I see. I'm concerned about the agency's ability to protect the public interest, to protect consumers interests, and to protect competition and make sure that we're getting good, healthy competition that actually spurs innovation. And again, protects consumers.

And to that end, I'm going--I'm sending a letter the FTC asking for the full report, the 2012 FTC report on Google's anti-competitive business practices. As you remember, I'm sure, the FTC launched an investigation into the anti-competitive practice by Google that culminated in a 160-page staff report in 2012. Half of that report was then inadvertently released during an open records request. But the FTC has never released the other half. And I think that the remaining pages are quite pertinent to the public interest for determining whether Google has been deceiving consumers for years and years. Google tells us that it simply returns the most relevant, useful results. But, of course, two years ago, the European Union fined Google $2.7 billion for doing just the opposite. And the pages that we have from the report, reveal that Google may have been involved, that the FTC was aware that Google was involved in the same sort of activity in the U.S. market. So, I look forward to your agency's attention to that.

Let me ask you about the recent report in the Wall Street Journal that several of my colleagues have already mentioned. The Project Voldemort Report, I'm calling it, about the--detailing Facebook's aggressive tactics. The report says the--the newspaper story says that Snap was worried that Facebook executives were using Instagram to prevent Snap consent from trending on that app. They were also worried that Facebook was encouraging popular accountholders or influencers to not reference Snap on their own accounts on Instagram. Is this the kind of thing that the FTC is concerned about?

HOFFMAN: So, Senator, I can't comment on a particular pending investigation, but let me make a couple of broad points. One is, information sources like the Project Voldemort, which is by the way a name that I greatly like especially with kids who are huge fans of Harry Potter, as am I. But, leaving that aside, that kind of information is the kind of information that we are constantly looking for and that helps us to good investigations. And that's one of the things that we have been doing in our technology task force is going out to the market to try to build that kind of knowledge and expertise.

Second, speaking broadly about types of practices, as opposed to the practices of any particular company that we might or might not be investigating, I can say that we would look for systematic conduct by somebody with a large share, a dominant firm that was aimed at disadvantaging rivals and potential rivals. Particularly in ways in that don't advance competition on their merits, and again, a great example of this what have alleged and the Surescripts case, which is currently pending in litigation. Or if you go back to the Microsoft case. The Microsoft case was a monopolization case that was compromised, and Chairman Lee talked about this in his opening statement, it is comprised of series of forms of conduct which altogether, created the monopolistic outcome. And that is the sort of thing, among others, that we would certainly look for.

HAWLEY: Let me just ask you at that level of generality, are you concerned about companies like Facebook acquiring competitors or would be competitors, and then using those competitor's platforms to strangle other competitors? So, deliberately expanding into markets, as we're talking about here, I mean potentially nascent competition, but expanding into markets where the--Facebook for instance, does not have a foothold, expanding into these markets, gaining a foothold, and then using those new platforms to kill other platforms. I mean, that's the kind of thing you're concerned about. Is that fair to say?

HOFFMAN: That would be fair. Just to elaborate very briefly, I think you could think of two forms of conduct but a platform in that regard that could be anti-competitive. One is, where the platform is doing something, any kind of conduct of which that would be a type, that would be aimed at for sawing a threat to the platform, the existing platform monopoly. And that was really what the Microsoft case about, a threat, ultimately to what Microsoft viewed as its platform that posed by the downstream disintermediation that platform and moving into a different direction.

The second possibility is where the existing dominant firm in market A sees a potential to monopolize market B and moves into that market engaging in anti-competitive conduct to acquire a monopoly power there. I think that's a harder case to bring, because there you're getting to speculator territory about, as you said, a situation where the firm doesn't actually already compete in the market. But, it's by no means impossible and it's not theoretically unattainable.

HAWLEY: Thank you for that.

Ms. Nakache let me just ask you in the time that I have remaining. In your written testimony you note that the percentage of IPO's for tech companies has decreased. And I just wanted to ask you to elaborate on that. Are you concerned that newer companies feel that they may lack realistic ways to achieve the same size or success of earlier entrants like Facebook and Google, that are now these very large incumbents?

NAKACHE: It has become--thank you for your question. It has become more challenging for young companies to become public companies. And there's a number of reasons for that. I mean, partly, there's increased regulations, Sarbanes-Oxley for one, Frank Dodd's the other, that makes it very expensive to be a public company. And that disproportionately burdens smaller companies. And at the same time, there's been reduced research coverage for smaller companies. And so, it's very important to encouraging trading and of public company stock. So, with those factors combined, there are few--it's much less attractive and there are fewer small companies going public, ergo, M&A has become an even more important path to liquidity for risk taking entrepreneurs.

HAWLEY: Thank you very much. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

LEE: Senator Blumenthal.

BLUMENTHAL: Thanks, Mr. Chairman.

Mr. Hoffman, I was involved in the Microsoft case. And I, in fact, helped to lead it and obviously there are parallels between what we saw then and what we see now, correct?

HOFFMAN: Again, without talking about an specific investigation that we might have, you can certainly say that the kinds of allegations that you might read about, for example, in the Wall Street Journal article or elsewhere, sound, in many respects similar to the kind of conduct and the kind of basic fact pattern that existed in the Microsoft case.

BLUMENTHAL: Well, it only sounds similar, but it looks similar, correct?

HOFFMAN: Again, without commenting specific investigation, I would agree with that.

BLUMENTHAL: And I made the point to Mr. Simons when he was here last week that the failure and I don't mean a personal failure on your part, but the agency's failure to be more specific, direct, and aggressive in discussing these issues, in a way creates lack of trust, lack of reliance on the part of the public in enforcement. Because what they see is your disclaiming knowledge or at the ability to talk about any specific investigation, when they know that these anti-competitive practices are ongoing. And they have no way to be sure that are in fact investigating anti-competitive practices. And I realize that you're not hear to speak for the agency about changing the ways that it talks publicly. But that's a message I hope you will take back, the message that the FTC really owes to the public to be more direct and aggressive in the way that it talks about these issues. If only that's the way the public will come forward with information that you need. As any prosecutor knows, if the public can't trust the prosecutors to be aggressive and--and forthright, it won't--it won't come forward. So, I think that is a real message here that a number of us feel is important.

In that Microsoft investigation, one of the remedies related to interoperability, the European regulators for example, required Microsoft to publish information that would allow competitors to be interoperable with its products, not just with internet browsers but across the wide range of prominent Microsoft services. Of course, Microsoft's attempts to use its control over Windows to stifle other internet browsers and promote Internet Explorer was the gist of what we were trying to stop. Since we see those anti-competitive practices in big tech today, let me ask you and Ms. Moss, should the FTC and the DoJ be pursuing interoperability mandates when it comes to anti-competitive practices?

HOFFMAN: So, again, Senator, first of all thank you for your points about public disclosure. I do think that we try as best we can to say what we can. And as you understand, there are limits on what we can say, but I take your point and will definitely take it back.

And so far as interoperability, I think the short answer is, yes. I mean, we look at a wide range of remedies. And as you know from your experience, the remedies available to us in monopolization cases or for that matter, in any kinds of conduct cases or retrospective merger cases that we might bring under Clayton 7 are very broad. We have a wide range of equitable tools available to fix anti-competitive conduct. And our mandate, when we find any anti-competitive conduct, is to fix it, to restore the competition that would have existed but for the conduct, whatever that conduct might be. And so we look at divestiture, splitting up companies. We have in the past, made companies who had fully integrate acquisitions for example, actually recreate the firm that they had bought, and we would look at things like interoperability and other issues like that, as the facts would warrant.

BLUMENTHAL: But there were structural changes that you required as part of the Facebook settlement, most recently. Even though, it wasn't, obviously wasn't an antitrust settlement. Mr. Simons said to us when he came here last week that he thought the litigation would have been time consuming, that the $5 billion fine vindicated a lot of the goals of the action and pursuit of the violation of consent. But there were structural changes, you committed to structural changes in antitrust enforcement.

HOFFMAN: Senator, so structural changes as I've actually spoke about on some prior occasions are our general preferred remedies. And it's particularly so where the vehicle, the form of anti-competitive conduct is a transaction. But, it's not the case. You would look at structural remedies as a viable option in any case if that was the best way to remedy the anti-competitive harm. And we also err on the side of caution, we tend to take a little more remedy than maybe would be the minimal necessary. Because we engage in what's called fencing in. We try to make sure that a firm that's engaged in anti-competitive conduct doesn't have an easy vehicle to get the same result by some slight change in approach. That said, again, any case as you know, really terms on what actually happened, what are the specific facts, what's going on in the market. And so that is certainly--it would absolutely be on the table. What we would do in a particular case, obviously I can't comment on right now.

BLUMENTHAL: Ms. Moss?

MOSS: Thank you for the question. I think in interoperability technically falls into the conduct remedy bucket. It's a remedy that as a former federal regulator, we were--was very near and dear to our hearts as part of an open access, nondiscrimination regime. It allows or promotes consumer switching; it allows rivals to operate on platforms without fear of being discriminated against. But, those types of remedies, because they are conduct oriented, are a little bit harder for antitrust authorities, I think, to effectively implement. Where a structural remedy could be taken and eliminate the incentive or the ability to exercise market power, then that would preferable.

But, I think, as you alluded to earlier, Senator Blumenthal, the platforms are really leveraging theory on steroids. These are interconnected systems of markets. There are scale economies, there are network effects, there are ecosystems of related markets, and to superimpose conduct remedies on those types of very complex business organisms, I think it's going to take--it's going to take sort of a team effort between antitrust regulators should they choose to go in that direction. But, also really facilitated by this concept of a possible digital market sector oversight authority who could advise on these technical matters.

BLUMENTHAL: So, the answer in a lot of these cases to monopoly or monopolistic and predatory conduct is structural remedies.

MOSS: That would be--that would be my preference.

BLUMENTHAL: Because they are easier to police and implement.

MOSS: And they are the most effective remedies.

BLUMENTHAL: Thank you.

LEE: Thank you. Ms. Nakache let's get back to you for a minute. You touched on this briefly in your opening statement. But what factors do venture capitalists consider when they're trying to assess the likelihood that a tech startup will be able to compete against incumbent platform?

NAKACHE: Thank you for your question. Venture capitalists consider a number of factors. And in fact, the bar is really quite high when they're considering investment in a company that competes directly against an incumbent their core market. They will look, in particular, at whether the product risk they're developing is truly differentiated relative to what's in the market today. Something that's only marginally better, is--is difficult to fund. At the same time, they'd look at the management team. And--and the capabilities of the management team to basically execute nimbly relative to deep pocketed incumbents. So, the bar's quite high, it does happen. And the bar is high in considering investment in any company competing against large incumbents. But it does happen.

LEE: Mr. Hoffman, what factors do enforcers look at in answering essentially this question in figuring whether the acquisition of a start up by a larger platform is a so-called killer acquisition, or whether it's on the other hand something more pro-competitive?

HOFFMAN: So, I think there's two broad rubrics that we consider, and then there's details within them. And just really quickly, the first broad rubric is, is the particular transaction anti-competitive? And there, with nascent competitors what we look at primarily is what we can discern from facts that are not econometric, by which I mean, what do the parties think? What do their documents show? What do the witnesses say? What do industry participants say about the likelihood that this competitor that's being acquired would have developed into a serious threat? A threat that is larger than the current market shares, which might be very tiny, would suggest. And that' the kind of fact pattern that saw in CDK automate and the kind of fact pattern that we say in the Ottobock case. The second broad rubric that we would look at, and this is more of a monopolization theory, would be if there is a pattern of acquisitions by a firm where some kind of methodology or system where it was like defining what it deemed to be potential competitors, and systematically targeting them for acquisition. There we might take an approach that would focus primarily on the analysis done by that firm and then look at the acquisitions as a group as opposed to in a single, you know, one off kind of way.

LEE: Dr. Moss, you've suggested that enforcement is weak in this area, weaker than it should be. And you tie to the evidentiary standards that are applicable. Do you have in mind any examples of tech mergers that you think the agencies should have challenged in court and perhaps would have, had the standard been different?

MOSS: Thank you for the question. I--I do think the FacebookInstagram merger is something that should be looked retrospectively to determine if there have been adverse effects. And then the agency can go back with well-crafted theories of harm, well-armed with evidence of adverse effects and then possibly unpack that. So, that was more a simple horizontal merger. I think some of the mergers in the advertising space, the DoubleClick, AdMeld, AdMob, the advertising platforms and serial acquisitions have been rather dramatic. I think that has created a tremendous amount of market power in various advertising spaces. And some of those should be unpacked in terms of their effects not only on advertisers, but on eyeballs and consumer attention.

I think the question is, and it's a good question that you raise is, do the agencies, what criteria do they use for going back and using scarce resources, to do 6 B studies or to do--or to support retrospective analysis? Should it be done within the agencies or outside the agencies? And I think one challenge we face in the big tech sector is how do you actually measure harm? Because you're not always dealing with prices here, you're dealing with zero price markets where people pay with their attention and their clicks, and their eyeballs. And markets can be more complex. And so, I think the agencies should give significant thought to this. And we're heartened by the taskforce at the FTC, and we're heartened by what the DoJ is doing as well. But we're not seeing any cases come out of those investigations.

LEE: If you were--If you could run the world for a day what would you do with the evidentiary standard? What would you change it to?

MOSS: I think for the evidentiary standard for acquisitions of potential competitors should be lowered. So, I think--and there should be a burden shift, much like what Senator Klobuchar has proposed in her more general merger legislation. Which is for the--the acquiring firm to come in with a really good story as to how this merger will actually be pro-competitive. And--and justify the cost savings, justify the alleged or the claimed consumer benefits. On the nascent and potential competitors' side, it is very, very difficult for the government to prove that a small startup firm would have grown into, but for the acquisition, would have grown into a viable rival. The reason why that's difficult is because that's a very--that's a very high wall to scale when you're dealing a--an enormous platform with all these ecosystem and network effects. And you're dealing with very small startups that can barely get their foot into the door. So, it's a hard standard to show. Lowering those evidentiary--to meet, lowering those evidentiary to meet, I think would--would serve to strengthen enforcement by making the government's case a little bit easier to make.

LEE: Mr. Hoffman, are the evidentiary standards, in your opinion, too high? Are they too high so as to stop the FTC from trying to block mergers that should be blocked?

HOFFMAN: I'm not aware of any case that we've failed to pursue because we were concerned about the evidentiary standard, where we thought that the transaction was likely to be harmful. We are willing to take risks in court and to bring hard cases where necessary. I think it's important to remember the evidentiary standard we're talking about here is the standard civil preponderance of the evidence, which plaintiff's lawyers that I've known describe as the feather lands on the scale, you know, all you need is a feather on the scale. So, it's not a very high standard.

I think it's also important to note that when you're talking about a horizontal merger, and I recognized Professor Moss' point that sometimes we're not talking about horizontal mergers here. But, in a horizontal merger you already have that presumption. Any kind of situation where you a firm that you would describe as dominant, suppose a firm with a 50 percent share, almost any acquisition it makes, even of a firm with a 1 percent share would comfortably trigger the presumption thresholds under the merger guidelines, which courts typically use. And shift the burden of at least coming forth with evidence to show that the transaction is not anti-competitive to the merging firms. So, a lot of that is already there.

In so far as lowering the standard broadly, like for example, presuming that all acquisitions of nascent competitors were anti-competitive, I think that raises serious questions. I wouldn't rule it out. I think it needs careful review, because there are potential negative consequences. For example, would this be a general standard that would apply to all acquisitions of any start up by anybody or would it only be by tech companies? But as a Diana--Professor Moss' paper points out, we don't know what the tech companies are in the sense that there's not a single industry into which they fall. So, even writing a definition that would cover them to establish he presumption would be challenging. And then if you establish a presumption that all such acquisitions are potentially anti-competitive, it's unclear to me what effects that would have on for example, the venture capital markets, and those could be significant. So, wouldn't rule it out, but I think it's something that ought to be considered very carefully to determine if its net effects would be positive or negative given where we are.

LEE: Thank you. Senator Klobuchar.

KLOBUCHAR: Thank you very much.

Ms. Nakache, excuse me, you note in your testimony that the digital platforms are now involved in venture capital, investing themselves. Of course, the big tech companies have access to vast amounts of data about potential acquisition targets by virtue of operating their platforms. Data, that I would guess, typical venture capitalist may lack. Do the big tech platforms have an advantage over other venture capital investors in searching for and valuing investments related to their existing business operations?

NAKACHE: Thank you for your question. The large incumbents--several of the large incumbents do have venture capital investing arms. But they're not along among corporations. There are--in the National Venture Capital Association alone, for example, there are over 50 corporate venture capital members. And across the board, the motivation is always staying close to innovation. There's also the objective of financial returns, but it's largely staying close--

KLOBUCHAR: --do you think they have unique information just because of their able to collect information?

NAKACHE: I think it's--so that would be irrespective of their venture capital arm--

KLOBUCHAR: --yeah--

NACKACHE: --I think that's--I think that's entirely possible that they have--that they have information based on--from them in particular, their search assets.

KLOBUCHAR: And how do you--different kind of question, how do you assess investing in a company that is competing directly against big tech? Does that make it seem harder when they have so much market power? Do you think it hurts companies that are trying to get in?

NACKACHE: The bar is definitely high to make an investment in a company that competes directly against one of the large incumbents. There--we have to see that the entrepreneur has a very unique insight, is building a very different product, is able to execute and out execute the larger deep pocketed incumbents. So, the bar is high, but it's not--but I wouldn't say that it never happens. I--

KLOBUCHAR: --how about if they sold one--they do one company and they sell it to big tech, does that improve the chances then, because they've shown that they produce something that was sold to big tech?

NACKACHE: If an entrepreneur, is that your question?

Absolutely. An entrepreneur has a track record of building a company successfully and having a successful outcome given the 75 percent failure rate in startups, absolutely improves his or her ability to raise capital in the future. For sure.

KLOBUCHAR: There was one of these things raised, not with regard to big tech, but the women entrepreneurs today. We're talking about how it's so hard for them to credibility. And one of the ways they do it is if they can sell to anyone. So, they're pretty desperate to do it. And I'm trying to see how this meshes with everything. So, then they have credibility to do their next big thing but keep it. So, it's pretty interesting.

NACKACHE: Exactly. In fact--

KLOBUCHAR: --it can lead to some weird competitive decisions, I think. Anyway. Alright.

Professor Yun and Dr. Moss, I have question for you. It seems like predicting the future competitiveness of a nascent competitor or potential future competitor could be extremely difficult, especially in the tech sector. My concern is that whenever there is uncertainty and there always is, the enforcers will default to doing nothing. In your opinion, are there developed analytical tools that can help enforcers determine which startups are likely to be strong competitors? And are you concerned that this kind of uncertainty will lead to underenforcement?

Rapid round answer.

YUN: And I'll say, in honesty, I'm not aware of tools that would be at forecasting that.

KLOBUCHAR: Yeah. So, that's why you're into the--in part into the post review?

YUN: And the post review is where we could gain--

KLOBUCHAR: --but it can't be the only thing you do.

YUN: It can't be the only thing. But, it's a good start.

KLOBUCHAR: Ok. Dr. Moss?

MOSS: So--so the only help we have here in potential competition is sort of the--the theories of actual potential competition and perceived potential competition. Which really, are--are not particularly good fits for the big tech space, for all the reasons we've discussed at the table here. So, I think this is a really fertile area for economists and lawyers and institutional experts and technical experts, to put their heads together and think about how the enforcement agencies can go about thinking about what--whether a potential competitor--today or at some point in the--in the--in the merger framework future will pose a significant threat to the market. And if it was eliminated would harm competition and consumers.

KLOBUCHAR: Ok. And you've alluded to this--that this occurs in other industries as well, the so-called killer acquisition in the pharma sector are good example. And Director Hoffman outlined a number of these prior cases in his written testimony. In your opinion, I know you've said we should be concerned about these industries; do you want to use a few examples?

MOSS: Sure. So, I do a lot of work in agriculture, biotechnology. And I think there are almost equivalent concerns about the acquisition of startups in digital farming. So, a lot of the big ag bio techs, the vertically integrated platforms of seeds, tracing chemicals are buying up digital farming startups like they're going out of style. And this all seems to be flying under the radar screen. I do think the DoJ did a good job by challenging the merger of Precision Planting, that sort of fit squarely into that category. That is--that--you know--the farming sector is going digital. And a lot of the issues--

KLOBUCHAR: --yeah--

MOSS: --have been talking about in big tech apply over there as well.

KLOBUCHAR: And how about pharma area?

MOSS: And in pharma, I talk a lot, get a lot of calls from small businesspeople that are trying to enter with smaller, unique business models. For example, secondary drug distribution, they have tremendous difficulty getting access to markets when they have to enter at more than one level. For example, not a single, you know, at drug level or at distribution level, but because they're dealing with vertically integrated behemoths much like the platforms, the barriers to entry are significantly high. And those businesses are withering on the vine.

KLOBUCHAR: And that's why I have promised this change and continuing to work on this, to try to get some basically, a better standard to look at these cases. And I'm glad that Chairman Lee is interested, maybe he wants to do the bill with me or get on our bill. Because the idea here is that what we have in place right now, either because of resources, which I think we should--I'm glad that Senator Grassley is helping with this, on trying to get more resources to the agencies. But, also the standards and then the courts, it's like just one big obstacle that we can't seem to overcome. And the other thing is we have to be as sophisticated as these companies. And when you look at the past, decade by decade, changes were made to the antitrust laws to adapt to the circumstances of their time. And we just have not been doing that in major way for a very, very long time, while an entire new marketplace has developed around us.

Would you agree?

MOSS: I would agree. I--I think--I think what--I think we should be going solidly in the direction of coming up with strengthening, improvements, clarifications to the antitrust laws. So, that they can apply broadly--

KLOBUCHAR: --and not just one sector--

MOSS: --to any sector.

KLOBUCHAR: Thank you, Dr. Moss. Thank you.

LEE: Senator Blumenthal.

BLUMENTHAL: Thanks. I'm going to try to be brief because we have a vote ongoing. But, in the interest of both simplicity and brevity, let me just put it in a nutshell. We're here today because antitrust enforcement isn't working. We see it in the pharmaceutical drug industry, we see in the airline industry, we see it in big tech. And without meaning any disrespect to you, Mr. Hoffman, personally, the danger really is that antitrust enforcement is becoming an empty suit. Whether its lack of where with all in resources, or lack of authority, I happen to think its as much lack of will.

And let me just cite to your predictions that have proved to be incorrect. I grant you, as I think Yogi Berra said, predictions are very difficult to make especially about the future. But these predictions prove to be notoriously wrong. In the Google AdMob merger of 2010, the FTC issued a closing statement basing on its approval on two stunningly incorrect predictions. First, that Apple would quickly become, "A strong mobile advertising competitor.". And second, that another firm would develop a smartphone to compete with the Apple iPhone and Google Android. We now know that Apple never became a competitor in ad networking, and in fact, abandoned the field entirely in 2016 when its shutdown iAd, it's mobile advertising application. And we still only have two smartphone operating systems.

In Google DoubleClick, 2007, the FTC also issued a closing statement, this time saying, "We have concluded that the ad intermediation market is not likely to tip to a single ad intermediation provider.". That prediction, also, was incorrect. According to a recent Wall Street Journal article, Google now dominates that market with 70 percent share in the ad service segment and 50 percent share in the ad exchange segment.

Finally, in FacebookInstagram transaction 2012, the FTC didn't bring an enforcement action. Also, didn't issue a closing statement, so we really don't know the reason for that decision. But, the United Kingdom Office of Fair Trading did issue a decision explaining its conclusion that the transaction was not anti-competitive, and it gave among its reasons that Google Plus would be a "constraining influence". And that it would be easy for another application to duplicate Instagram's success. Again, this predication was wrong. Google Plus limped along for years before shutting down earlier this year and no app has since been able to come close to Instagram.

I understand nobody can predict the future. And I know that you're here to represent an agency that could use more resources. But, as I listen to Mr. Simon talk about the settlement with Facebook, on privacy, not antitrust, but privacy, what I saw was in effect, as a former prosecutor, an attitude of if it looks tough, don't do it. I know as a former prosecutor, if you're not willing to try cases, you're not going to get good settlements. And so, I guess my question to you is, in your merger, if you were considering whether the agency has been making predictions that have systematically led to less aggressive enforcement? This question is not meant to personal criticism. I hope you don't take it that way. You're a distinguished attorney, but the agency as a whole seems to lack the aggressiveness that is necessary.

HOFFMAN: Thank you, Senator. First of all, there's a really good lawyer I know once said, I take nothing personally. So, that doesn't bother me at all.

But I'd say a couple things. First of all, I'm very proud of the enforcement history of the Federal Trade Commission. I think we've been, and this is not just me saying this, there are multiple measures of international bodies and others on agency effectiveness and the FTC is routinely ranked at one of the best, if not the best agency in the world in terms of antitrust enforcement. Having said that, I think it would correct that we get things wrong from time to time. As you said, predictions are hard. And when we look at mergers, prospectively, it is entirely possible that we get things wrong about them.

It's also possible that sometimes courts get things wrong and that, for example, is as was illustrated in the hospital merger project that Professor Yun referred to where courts were getting wrong, we though, over and over and over again. And we, and the DOJ, and the states lost all of the hospital merger cases we brought over a decade. But we eventually reversed that by doing things similar to what we're doing today. We put together a hospital merger retrospective project run by our economists. We put together the merger litigation taskforce, the name coincidence is not accidental, it's not a coincidental if you like, which consisted of lawyers from the FTC who were dedicated to focusing primarily hospital transactions to understand them better. We found evidence that we had been right, and the courts had been wrong, but it required a new way of analyzing the data and understanding how competition worked in that industry. We brought cases and since then, we have won, I think we have an unbroken string now of hospital merger litigation challenges.

So, we get things wrong. Absolutely. We're never going to get things 100 percent right. But, when we determine that we're getting things wrong, we work really hard to try to fix that and get it right. And that's what we're trying to do now. I'm not saying that its necessarily the case that we had all this wrong, I don't know. That's what we're looking at. But we are dedicated to doing things right and that's what this agency works really hard to do.

BLUMENTHAL: And I just want to make clear, I am not accusing anybody of lack of goodwill or good intentions. I'm saying when it comes big tech, the FTC better start getting things right, because the stakes are so high, and I appreciate your comments. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

LEE: You're all going to be tremendously disappointed by this, but we're going to go ahead adjourn. We're a ways into this vote. We're going to have to sprint to catch this. In light of the--

KLOBUCHAR: --yeah--no I'm ok with it. But I do want to point out that I think this has been a very helpful hearing. And I hope you get some tips, Mr. Hoffman. And the concern that we all share, really, on a bipartisan basis, that we're going to have to look at some of these deals. And I've got some ideas for changing the standards that I think are important.

But I end where I began. And that is that there's been a 26 percent decrease in new business formation from 2006 to 2015. And we've seen a very low start up rate compared to other decades. And we should all be really concerned for capitalism. This is not a partisan issue. Everyone cares about maintaining this entrepreneurship system that has done our economy so good for so many, many years. So, let's bring it back and not have too many monopolies.

LEE: This has been a fantastic hearing. I thank each of you for your participation. I wish we could come down and personally thank you, but I think we're going to have to sprint to catch this.

The hearing--the record will remain open for two weeks. And we stand adjourned.

Senate Judiciary Subcommittee On Antitrust, Competition Policy And Consumer Rights Holds Hearing On Google And Competition In Online Advertising

September 15, 2020 02:30 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UTAH), CHAIRMAN

SEN. CHARLES E. GRASSLEY (R-IOWA)

SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO.)

After I and then Senator Klobuchar give our opening remarks we will hear from to panels of witnesses with seven minute rounds of questions from members of the subcommittee.

We have something interesting to deal with in the Senate and that every time they call votes, when they call votes during a subcommittee hearing or any hearing for that matter we are at their mercy. Senator Chloe and I have both cast our votes on the first of a series of three or four. At some point we are either going to have to pause or tag team as we allow other members to sit in for us. Just don't be alarmed if that happens.

The focus of today's hearing is Google's online advertising business, whether it's a monopolist and whether it might have engaged in any conduct that harms competition and harms consumers. But before we go into that I want to say just a few things about antitrust policy more broadly. I have been a member of the subcommittee ever since 2011 when I first arrived in the Senate and I have chaired the subcommittee for almost 6 years. Over that time as the public debate surrounding antitrust policy and enforcement has grown and in some cases the evolved. So too has the gulf between the opposing sides.

One extreme there are those who would rather that we have no antitrust laws at all and the alternative they advocate for an enforcement policy that's overly differential to speculative efficiencies and quick to dismiss actual evidence of competitive harm when--whenever it might conflict with unproven economic theories. This extreme end of the continuum sort of fetishize his freedom to the exclusion of the laws that maintain that very freedom. They forget that markets like governors do not keep themselves free and that liberty is only secure when power is defused. The other extreme however is a line of arguments that has four years now been pushing an agenda to sort of transform the antitrust laws in this country from a tool based and economic science to protect and promote competitive markets into a sort of panacea for all of their perceived social ills.

Built on the economically myopic premise that big is bad and that is the beginning and the end of the question. Assuming the end of the spectrum would use antitrust to address alleged labor, income, and racial disparities these may be laudable goals but they are not problems that antitrust law is meant to solve nor are they problems that antitrust law is even capable of solving at least not without creating a whole bunch of other problems even within those areas themselves.

Attempts to repurpose antitrust law into a social justice program would have scores of unintended consequences that would cripple our economy for generations and of course there is the hypocrisy in believing that big is bad applies only to corporations and not to government bureaucracy the very type of government bureaucracy that they would expand in order to dismantle and regulate them. You may be wondering where I see myself in those two extremes. Whose side am I on? Am I on the side of the American people? Yes. Am I on the side of the law? Yes. I believe vigorous enforcement of antitrust laws is essential to maintaining the free markets that have made this the most prosperous nation on earth and I believe that our current laws are for the most part sufficient to meet the challenges of the day.

I said a moment ago that liberty is only secure when power is defused. This is a bedrock principle of our constitutional republic. The concept of federalism perhaps the greatest contribution of the founding generation and of our founding document is what makes America unique among all other nations. This principle applies equally to the economic power as it does to political power. In a way antitrust laws might properly be described as federalism for the economy.

That brings us to today. We are here to discuss what may be the seminal antitrust case of the 21st century, one whose precedent will define the terms of competition and innovation in our dynamic economy for years, in fact for decades to come. Unlike some of my colleagues in the house I am not interested in staging a political spectacle to attack, to condescend and to talk over witnesses. Naive though it may be in 2020 my hope is that by looking at this specific question we can have a serious and frank conversation about the state of competition in digital markets.

Online advertising is an incredibly complex business and one that touches every single person on the Internet. The technologies involved in connecting advertisers and publishers have evolved rapidly in the last decade and the expansion of online advertising has facilitated an explosion of online content by allowing even the smallest website owners to monetize the content they produce. Small and local businesses have also benefited from being able to quickly and easily promote their businesses without any of the same capital investments that would have been required and indispensable for that effort just a few decades ago.

So at the same time this growth and this expansion has been largely consolidated onto a single platform, Google's online ad business. As that business has grown so to have complaints that Google which both operates the ad selling and add buying platforms and sells its own inventory through those platforms has conflicts of interest and this is manipulated or rigged online ad technologies and auctions to favor its own interest and protect its own market share. Whether this is true or not matters because so many businesses depend upon digital advertising to market their products or to monetize the content that they produce. Web users in turn benefit from free online content and being connected to relevant businesses in a way that helps them to make optimal business decisions. Simply put, markets function better when businesses thrive and consumers are in form. Ideally online advertising helps accomplish this.

If however online advertising has been monopolized and constrained by opaque pricing and exclusionry conditions everyone loses to that degree.

I would also add that Google and other big tech companies have been accused of a number of bad acts unrelated to antitrust or to competition. I myself have repeatedly expressed concerns about an anti-conservative bias by these firms and I will continue to pursue those concerns but while I believe that issues like anti-conservative bias certainly have implications for antitrust such as perhaps evidencing market power today's hearing is not fundamentally about those concerns.

This hearing is about an analytically distinct issue, it's about antitrust allegations in online advertising that are a legitimate subject of inquiry in their own right and to be clear just as I reject demands to use antitrust for social justice I also emphatically reject using antitrust to solve other non-antitrust concerns. Today's discussions will I hope help everyone to better understand the online advertising market and how competition works or should work and how it might not be operating as well as it could in that space.

I look forward to hearing from our experienced and highly qualified witnesses. Thank you and I will now turn to Ranking Member Klobuchar for her opening remarks.

HEIMLICH: I would say yeah Google makes most of its money from selling ads and search in YouTube and then they use that data to dominate the ad tech and exchange market. Right? So easy solution to separate those but the deeper you go, the deeper I've researched I'm concerned that there's significant data from Android and Chrome also being tied into this ad tech market such that even if you separated search and YouTube from ad tech Android would replace what they've already done with data from Android and Chrome.

LEE: Ok.

KLOBUCHAR: Just a few things. Mr. Szabo the oil industry case was successfully resolved in the oil industry standard oil was broken up under President Taft. That case went on for a while. Isn't that right?

SZABO: Yes. However, when you look at what Teddy Roosevelt has been lionized as is a trust buster it's important to look at what his intent was with respect to--

KLOBUCHAR: OK. I just think it's important that the record reflect that they did break up standard oil and it went through several administrations as I think some of these cases will. But that's my own political view. (LAUGHTER) And we will eventually et to the place we have to go if I have anything to do with it. I also want to point out that simply because we want to have new standards in place that fit our economy doesn't mean that we are antibusiness and it certainly doesn't even mean that you go into it saying everything should be broken up. I don't. I've tried to be responsible by putting forward bills that I think could fit regardless of what I think of a p--particular company. And I think that's an important point to make.

And the third thing is, I'm glad there's some interest in beefing up resources on everyone's part. And I hope that we're going to be able to make sense of all this. Because I think for too long people have just thrown up their hands and said these are cool companies so it's ok. I don't think it is OK anymore and it's not going to be ok as we see these growing monopolies and it is on us to make those changes.

I just want to put on the record before we go vote Mr. Chairman, a letter from Consumer Reports dated it is dates September 15th, to the two of us on their views on the subcommittee and their concerns about what is happening with online advertising.

LEE: That'll be admitted into the record without objection. And the record in--for this hearing will remain open for one week. The committee stands adjourned. Thank you very much for your participation and your testimony today.

UNKNOWN: Thank you.
